DOC.TEXT: EEUU vota en ONU contra deportaciDon de palestinos NACIONES UNIDAS, 20 (AP) - Estados Unidos, negDandose a proteger a su aliado israelDi, respaldDo hoy una resoluciDon del Consejo de Seguridad que deplora la deportaciDon de palestinos por Israel y pide a la ONU que los proteja. El voto unDanime fue de 15-0. En una declaraciDon separada y no obligatoria, el consejo de 15 miembros acordDo que una conferencia internacional apropiadamente fechada y estructurada debDia facilitar una paz duradera entre Darabes e israelDies. La declaraciDon aInadiDo que el conflicto Darabe-israelDi es un diferendo singular y debe ser tratado independientemente por sus propios mDeritos, forma indirecta de decir que no debe haber conexiDon alguna con la crisis del golfo PDersico. El respaldo norteamericano fue interpretado como un intento de reforzar el compromiso Darabe con la coaliciDon multinacional dirigida por Estados Unidos contra Irak. Un veto estadounidense de un asunto considerato vital por los Darabes pudo haber socavado su confianza en la misiDon estadounidense, dijeron los diplomDaticos de Washington. Fue la tercera vez en mDas de dos meses que Estados Unidos se niega a proteger a Israel de una crDitica internacional mediante su derecho al veto como miembro permanente del Consejo de Seguridad. En el pasado, Estados Unidos ha bloqueado frecuentemente los intentos de miembros del consejo de condenar a Israel. DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Russ Roars over Guam
DOC.TEXT: Residents waited behind boarded windows or fled to shelters early Friday while Typhoon Russ battered the island with winds topping 100 mph. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, officials said. Russ was the strongest typhoon to hit this western Pacific island in more than a decade. It toppled trees, pushed surf to more than 20 feet high and made movement around the 30-mile-long island virtually impossible. ``Everybody's just sitting tight,'' Guam Civil Defense spokesman Mike Franquez said. ``We'll wait for the winds to pass and then assess the damage.'' About 145,000 people live on Guam. The last storm to cause major damage here was Typhoon Pamela in 1976. Winds were clocked at 90 mph with gusts to 115 mph when the storm made its closest pass before dawn, said Navy Capt. Dieter Rudolph, commander of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The wind readings were taken at the typhoon center, near the north end of north-south lying island. The storm's center brushed Guam's south coast, and southern areas were pummelled by the strongest winds. The storm's maximum sustained winds were 145 mph, with gusts to 175 mph, Rudolph said. It was moving west-northwest at 13 mph. About 2,300 people went to shelters at schools. The windows of most buildings had been boarded up, Franquez said. To avert the potential problem of dangling live wires if power lines break, electricity was shut off to most of the island. Water also was cut off. Some coastal roads were closed because the high surf left them strewn with debris. ``There's downed power lines, downed trees, flooded streets,'' said Dave Ecret of KGUM Radio. ``It's just an eerie kind of feeling.''

DOC.HEAD: Courts Reject Woman's Request to Reconnect Nancy Cruzan's Feeding Tube

Ed: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with new legal efforts and CORRECT name to Mandina, sted Mandino in 3rd graf. Pick up 5th graf, `Ms. Cruzan ...' ADDS 3 grafs at bottom with specifics on new legal effort.
DOC.TEXT: Two courts Thursday denied a request to have Nancy Cruzan's feeding tube reconnected as demonstrators kept a vigil at the hospital where she is dying and launched new legal efforts to keep her alive. Yvette Williams, who cares for severely disabled children, asked the courts to require the state to provide nourishment to Ms. Cruzan, who has been in a persistent vegetative state since a 1983 traffic accident. Miss Williams' request was denied by the Missouri Supreme Court and the Missouri Court of Appeals. She was represented by Mario Mandina of the anti-euthanasia group Lawyers for Life. Mandina said he planned to return to the Missouri Supreme Court to seek a rehearing. At least two new legal attempts to force Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube to be reconnected were launched. Ms. Cruzan, 33, is the central figure in a right-to-die case that went to the U.S. Supreme Court and culminated Dec. 14 with a probate judge's decision that her parents could order her feeding tube removed. The tube was withdrawn hours later. Doctors estimated Ms. Cruzan would die within two weeks without food and water. Her condition deteriorated Thursday. ``Our laws protect life,'' Miss Williams, who lives in Kansas City, said in a prepared statement. ``What is happening here offends me. I cannot in conscience be a party to the killing of Nancy Cruzan.'' Protesters from the anti-abortion movement have converged since the tube was removed on the Missouri Rehabilitation Center, where Ms. Cruzan is looked after in this southwestern Missouri town of 3,400. The protesters say the Cruzan case is an extension of their cause. Police arrested 19 demonstrators Tuesday after they refused to leave. They remained Thursday in the Lawrence County Jail. About 15 protesters gathered Thursday on the porch of the hospital, where they said they would maintain a vigil until Ms. Cruzan dies. The Supreme Court rejected Ms. Williams' request in a two-sentence order. It was signed by Judge Edward Robertson, who wrote the court's November 1988 decision that denied a request from Ms. Cruzan's parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan, for authority to remove the tube providing their daughter food and water. That ruling sent the case to the U.S. Supreme Court, which ruled in June in its first right-to-die case that Missouri could require ``clear and convincing'' evidence Ms. Cruzan would not want to live in the vegetative state. At a hearing last month, former co-workers testified Ms. Cruzan had said she would never want to live like a vegetable. In a separate effort to have Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube reconnected, a civil rights lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court in Springfield by the Rev. Pat Mahoney, director of the Center for Christian Activism in Boca Raton, Fla. ``Nancy Cruzan has no advocate, no one to stand for her, no one to appeal this decision,'' Mahoney said. A hearing was set for Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Reassures Aylwin on Army Action
DOC.TEXT: President Patricio Aylwin on Thursday called in the army commander and former Chilean ruler, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, to demand an explanation of why the military refused to leave its barracks the day before. As Pinochet entered and left the downtown presidential palace, hundreds of people demonstrated against him, chanting anti-military slogans and urging Aylwin to demand his resignation. Pinochet said the military moves Wednesday were just an exercise, but government officials and others had described them as a protest over news reports on an illegal financial institution involving high-ranking officers. The Chilean media has widely reported on the scandal for weeks, alleging that a savings and loan operation run by people in the military resulted in losses for individual depositors that ranged as high as $500,000. Wednesday's action by the soldiers was the first instance of military unrest since Pinochet's military rule ended nine months ago. It raised fears that the military might challenge civilian control. But the civilian government said democracy was not in danger. The goverment said Thursday in a communique that Pinochet spoke to the president during an hourlong meeting at the presidential palace, where the former military ruler was summoned by his civilian successor. Aylwin, the communique said, ``required from the commander in chief and explanation for the unusual measures taken by the institution he commands.'' Pinochet explained that ``it was a security, readiness and coordination exercise, which ended this morning, and it had no extra-institutional connotations,'' the brief communique said. As he left the presidential palace, a smiling, relaxed Pinochet also told reporters the confining to barracks was an exercise. Asked why the goverment was not informed beforehand, he replied: ``We don't have to tell the government. This is army business. The army has not bothered anybody, has not taken to the streets.'' Aylwin is constitutionally prohibited from firing Pinochet, who remained commander of the 60,000-man army after handing over the presidency to the new civilian government. Meanwhile, politicians from left to right on Thursday expressed full support for the country's newly restored democracy. ``What we all want is to maintain the democratic system, and I believe no one should do anything against it,'' said Jose Pinera, a former Cabinet minister under Pinochet and a close ally of the 75-year-old general. Sergio Bitar, a socialist leader, called the military action ``a blackmail and a threat.'' He said, ``Nobody in Chile wants the consolidation of democracy to be halted.''

DOC.HEAD: Burma Outlaws Opposition Party
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military rulers have outlawed an opposition party whose leader declared a rival government, an official report said Friday. The Party for National Democracy was declared illegal on Thursday, the official Working People's Daily reported. Sein Win, the chairman of the party, announced a provisional government Tuesday at the headquarters of an ethnic rebel group on the Thai frontier. His party was allied to the National League for Democracy, which won the May 27 election by a landslide but has been barred from office by the military government. The Party for National Democracy was set up as a affiliate of the league in case it was ever declared illegal. Sein Win is a cousin of the league's detained leader Aung San Suu Kyi.

DOC.HEAD: Letter Says Castro Opposed Pre-Emptive Strike Against the US in '62
DOC.TEXT: Cuban President Fidel Castro has released a 28-year-old letter that appears to put to rest the notion that he favored a pre-emptive nuclear attack against the United States during the Cuban missile crisis. Instead, Castro said in his letter to Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev that the Soviets should exercise the nuclear option only if the United States invaded Cuba for the purpose of occupying it. Two years ago, at a Moscow conference of American, Soviet and Cuban participants in the 1962 crisis, Khrushchev's son, Sergei, was reported to have told some American delegates that Castro had recommended an immediate nuclear strike against the United States at the height of the crisis. The purported comments of the younger Khrushchev were widely reported at the time. Philip Brenner, an American University professor and expert on the crisis, said Wednesday that Sergei Khrushchev has retreated somewhat from his allegation about Castro. According to Brenner, Sergei Khrushchev now says that his authority for his comments was his father's memory, which may have been faulty. The Castro letter, dated Oct. 26, 1962, and reprinted in a Communist Party newspaper in Havana recently, showed that the Cuban leader believed U.S. military action was likely within 24 to 72 hours. Castro said he saw two options: an air attack against specific targets - presumably the Soviet nuclear facilities in Cuba that had provoked the crisis - and, less likely, an outright U.S. invasion of Cuba. Castro's letter asserted that the danger for humanity of a U.S. invasion would be such that the only solution would be ``to eliminate forever that danger ... notwithstanding how hard and terrible that solution might be.'' Castro warned that the Soviets could be the target of a U.S. nuclear strike if the United States were able to invade and occupy the island. Two days after the Castro letter, at a time when the crisis had eased considerably as a result of an agreement, Khrushchev wrote Castro that it would be necessary, of course, to repel a U.S. invasion ``by all means necessary.'' The letter added: ``One must not be carried away by provocations, because the unchecked Pentagon militarists ... want to thwart the agreement and provoke you into actions which they could use against you. We would ask you not to provide any excuse for this.'' Khrushchev said the conflict was being resolved in Castro's favor because the agreement provided for a U.S. pledge not to invade Cuba. Brenner said Khrushchev's letter indicates that he viewed Castro as a ``loose cannon.'' As a followup to the Moscow conference on the crisis, the Cuban government plans to host a meeting of its own in October during the 29th anniversary of that episode. A preparatory session for that meeting will be held on the Caribbean island of Antigua Jan. 4-6. Among the Americans scheduled to participate are former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and Arthur Schlesinger, an adviser to President Kennedy. Brenner said the Cubans and the Soviets have indicated they plan to bring documents that have never before been revealed.

DOC.HEAD: Where American Junk Gets Top Dollar
DOC.TEXT: It may not do wonders for solving the trade imbalance, but the Japanese finally have found U.S. products for which they are willing to pay big bucks - secondhand goods. A U.S.-style thrift store in southern Tokyo called Panic Melon Studio Beverly Hills has three floors crammed with bits and pieces of postwar Americana that look as though they belong in a forgotten attic corner. But in Japan, they sell for eye-popping prices. A gallon 1957 Coca-Cola bottle sells for $285, a worn out but working General Electric refrigerator from the 1960s for $1,880, a 1975 Mattel talking Pink Panther for $210. An old-fashioned Hoover vacuum cleaner goes for $285, a faded, chipped dresser for $620 and a diner counter stool for $285. Even empty egg cartons are available at $3.60 each. ``This is an aesthetic of the passe, dirtiness and ruin,'' Panic Melon supervisor Bonjour Watanabe says with a wave of his hand. ``We spend a lot of effort trying to present unfashionable American things as fashionable for the Japanese.'' There is indeed a fashion move toward `50s and `60s Americana, says Hiromi Egawa, an editor at a monthly magazine for young middle-class women. ``Jackie Kennedy is very popular now,'' she says. Watanabe, 33, says the store rakes in about $45,000 a month on sales and rental of goods that he and his staff collect from thrift stores, flea markets and individual collectors in Los Angeles. More than half of Panic Melon's income comes from rental for props for fashion magazine shoots and television commercials, he says. A number of other stores in Tokyo also sell used American goods from stone-washed denim to bird-shaped decoys. ``Sometimes an American customer will wander into the store and pick up an item with an old American price tag of $3 still stuck on it,'' Watanabe said. ``When we tell them the actual price, say $210, the American usually gets very angry, and we almost get into a fight.'' Then Watanabe explains to the visitor that a sizable investment went into obtaining the wares because of air fare, lodging and gas in the United States, as well as shipment and duty costs. ``But most of the time the American won't buy it,'' Watanabe says with a smile. Japanese, however, are a different story. ``I come here often. I have bought a road sign that I hang in my home and small items like forks and knives,'' said Junichi Yamamoto, a 23-year-old architect clad in a leather jacket. ``I usually spend about 10,000 yen ($75) on each visit.'' Those who studied in the United States are drawn to the functional dining tables and chairs that remind them of their younger days, he says. There are also the mechanically inclined, who are thrilled to buy scrap motorcycle parts, and there are the rock 'n' roll freaks with greased-back hair for whom all the rubbish is high-class fashion. ``There are things here that are practically garbage,'' Watanabe admits. ``But we need to keep the space filled, and you'd be surprised at what gets bought.'' Watanabe says Japanese, who typically wouldn't be caught dead wearing last year's clothes, are awed by the unwillingness of Americans to throw anything away. ``It allows this to exist,'' he says, lifting a basket of discolored fake flowers.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Faces Recruiting Problems, Committee Says
DOC.TEXT: NASA, an agency that literally relies on rocket scientists, should be allowed different personnel rules than the rest of government if the space program is to keep its edge, a federal committee says. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration likely will have trouble recruiting the best and brightest during the 1990s if it has to stick to civil service pay restrictions, the Advisory Committee on the Future of the U.S. Space Program said in its final report Wednesday. The committee issued a summary of the report last week, c emphasis on science, less dependence on the space shuttle by developing new cargo-carrying rockets and a simpler, more easily maintained space station than the one being planned. ``We are at an appropriate time to step back and view where we are galling for moreoing and what is the best way to get there,'' the panel said. ``Among the most needed ingredients of America's space program is a consensus of support for its goals and its resource needs - whatever they may be.''' Private industry is able to pay $5,000 to $10,000 a year more than NASA to new college graduates and the gap is widening, the report said, pointing to science and engineering as especially acute staff problems. At the other end of the scale, post-emp, ``rather than a mission whose design is frozen in time.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA's Mission Possibly Most Difficult in World, Report Says
With PM-Space Revamping, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NASA's mission is ``probably more difficult than that of any other organization in the world,'' says a report by the advisory committee on the future of the U.S. space program. It offered this illustration of what makes the National Aeronautics and Space Adminstration's job so tough: ``Each Voyager spacecraft has the electronic circuitry of over 2,000 color television sets, yet is required to work for 12 years while traveling from Earth to Neptune. ``The two Voyager spacecraft schedules were absolutely unforgiving, the planets in their paths aligning themselves only once every 176 years. Yet by the time Voyager 2 reached Neptune, 4.4 billion miles away and 12 years later, the spacecraft was a mere 22 miles off its charted course and only one second off its updated flyby time. ``Mechanical challenges are equally impressive. Each space shuttle contains some 300 miles of electrical wiring, over 3,000 feet of welds and over 2.5 million lines of software code. Its pumps propel 65,000 gallons (the capacity of a large swimming pool) through its engines each minute. ``The power turbine on the shuttle operates at a temperature of 1,300 degrees Fahrenheit. Just four feet away, the pump turbine operates at minus 400 degrees Fahrenheit .... ``The Hubble Space Telescope involved a total of over 40 million hours of work. To process a space shuttle for flight requires that 1.2 million separate procedures be accomplished. ``Furthermore, NASA must do all that it does in the public spotlight - which is, of course, as it should be.''

DOC.HEAD: Experimental Drugs Open New Strategy for Stopping Asthma and Allergies
DOC.TEXT: New medicines tailored to block a troublesome body chemical appear to stop allergic reactions before they start and could also provide relief to millions of asthma and hay fever sufferers, scientists reported today. The drugs, still in their experimental stages, thwart the body's production of substances known as leukotrienes. Thy are among the chief culprits in triggering common allergic reactions. ``What makes this important is that it's a new way of treating asthma,'' said Dr. Jeffrey M. Drazen of Boston's Beth Israel Hospital. ``Other drugs put out the fire once it's started. We haven't had a way to prevent the problem in the first place, which is what these drugs do.'' Unlike many other allergy medicines, these drugs appear to have no side effects. If they prove safe and effective in additional testing, they could have widespread use. ``Asthma and hay fever are incredibly prevalent diseases. These are potential approaches that could impact on the lives of 25 percent of the people in the United States,'' said Dr. Michael Kaliner of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Doctors said the drugs could supplement or replace several of the asthma drugs already in use, such as cromolyn and theophylline. Some of these drugs have side effects including tremors, nausea, vomiting, headaches and drowsiness. An estimated 35 million to 40 million Americans get hay fever, and 12 million to 15 million have asthma. ``This is an area people have been studying for a long time,'' said Dr. Suzanne Hurd of the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. ``This is the first example that we might have some payoff here. It's very promising and exciting.'' Dr. Howard R. Knapp of the University of Iowa used the experimental Abbott Laboratories drug zileuton to prevent hay fever symptoms in people allergic to ragweed and grasses. In the other studies, researchers from Beth Israel used the same drug to prevent asthma induced by breathing cold air, and doctors from McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario, gave the Merck Sharp and Dohme drug venzair to prevent asthma triggered by exercise. The three studies were published in today's New England Journal of Medicine. Elsewhere, doctors are experimenting with similar leukotriene-blocking drugs against such ailments as rheumatoid arthritis, the skin disease psoriasis and the digestive illness ulcerative colitis. Leukotrienes are known to cause tightening of the air passages in the lungs and increase mucous production in the nose. But until the recent development of drugs that block leukotrienes, scientists could not prove their importance in allergic reactions. Knapp gave the drug to eight people with hay fever. When they were exposed to ragweed or grass, seven of them had a lot less congestion. In the Beth Israel study, doctors tested zileuton on 13 people whose asthma is triggered by cold, dry air. The drug increased their tolerance of cold by 47 percent. In the McMaster study, Dr. Patrick J. Manning and others tested venzair on 12 people who regularly got asthma during exercise. The treatment reduced their asthma by 70 percent and in three people prevented it entirely.

DOC.HEAD: District Attorney's Office Unsure if Space-Trip Contest Legal
LaserPhoto NY25 of Dec. 19
DOC.TEXT: The district attorney's office says it's hitting the law books to learn whether a sweepstakes offering an American a ride aboard the Soviet space station is legal. The sweepstakes had been called a hoax earlier this week by the Soviet news agency Tass, but Soviet officials Wednesday confirmed they had a contract with Space Travel Services of Houston to take someone aboard Mir. Two company executives Wednesday went before a grand jury investigating whether the giveaway, which contestants can enter by dialing a 900-number for $2.99, violates Texas law against charging someone for a chance to win something. Space Travel Services contends that because contestants can also enter for free by mail, the sweepstakes complies with the law. ``It's our position, maybe not,'' said Russel Turbeville, head of the district attorney's consumer fraud division. ``Our concerns are whether or not they are in good faith, and even if they are in good faith, whether this constitutes an illegal lottery.'' ``We're going to do a little more legal research,'' said Turbeville. If the contest is found to be illegal, the operators could face penalties of up to 10 years in prison and a $5,000 fine. David Mayer, president of Space Travel Services, and James Davidson, senior vice president, had been subpoenaed to appear before the grand jury, but the subpoenas were dismissed after they agreed to cooperate, Turbeville said. ``You do something big and different and people are going to look into it,'' Davidson said. ``We think that's the way it should be. These folks at the district attorney's office are doing their job. ``We expect a clean bill of health from this investigation.'' A person will be selected in a drawing in December 1991 for a space trip in 1992 or 1993 plus $500,000, the company said.

DOC.TEXT: ``What is so magic, why does it have to be that on Jan. 15th we must be ready to go and initiate hostilities at midnight on the 16th?'' - Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller, second in command of Operation Desert Shield. --- ``What he really said is they might not be as ready as they would like to be ... for all the contingencies. We are assured they will be ready to do whatever they are called upon to do.'' - White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater's response to Waller's statement that U.S. troops will not be ready to fight Iraq by Jan. 15. ---- ``No. I'm not ready to do the job.'' - Waller. He said he'd tell President Bush that if he is asked to launch an attack before he's certain U.S. troops are ready.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Transplant Drug Linked with High Cancer Risk
DOC.TEXT: A treatment intended to weaken the immune system temporarily to prevent orga rejection has been linked with a sharply increased cancer risk in heart transplant patients, doctors reported today. Doctors from Loyola University Medical Center said 11 percent of their patients who got the treatment developed lymphoma, a blood cell cancer. The cancers typically developed a month or two after the surgery and were rapidly fatal. The treatment, called OKT3, is a tailor-made antibody that attacks a variety of white blood cells that play a key role in making the body reject the transplanted organ. OKT3 gained widespread use about three years ago. The new study shows that even if OKT3 prevents rejection - and this is in doubt - the benefit comes at a high cost. ``We found that the addition of OKT3 was statistically strongly linked with a sharp increase in this form of cancer,'' said Dr. Lode J. Swinnen, who directed the study. People who get transplanted organs routinely receive a variety of medicines that temporarily weaken their defenses. This is intended to thwart the body's tendency to attack the alien organ. Doctors have long recognized that these medicines increase the risk of blood cancer. However, Swinnen's study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, found that OKT3 heightened the risk dramatically. Of 79 heart transplant patients who got the treatment at Loyola, nine developed lymphoma, and six of them died. In an accompanying editorial, Dr. Israel Penn of the University of Cincinnati Medical Center said the use of these drugs and the development of cancer ``indicate that we have much to learn about walking the tightrope between preventing rejection and inducing lymphomas.'' But overall, he said, only about 1 percent of all transplant recipients die of cancer. Penn said the risk should not stop transplants but instead should spur research to find better alternative drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Canada's National Broadcasting Network Facing Hard Times
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollar figures U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Pink slips go out next month for about 1,000 employees of the Canadian Broadcasting Corp., the government-owned network many see as the glue that holds together this vast and diverse nation of 26 million people. The bad news comes from budget-cutters who are slashing 10 percent of the corporation's staff, closing television stations and reducing services. Their goal is to make up a projected shortfall of $91 million in next year's $935 million budget. Declining advertising revenues, reduced government funding and rising TV production costs have hurt the network deeply. About 75 percent of production costs comes from the government. Angry public protests have occurred from Newfoundland to Ontario to the Gaspe Peninsula of Quebec over what many feel are cuts in one of the few things that make Canadians really different from Americans. The CBC will cut 1,100 of its nearly 11,000 permanent positions, effective April 5. The CBC is known internationally for highly rated dramas. Fully 82 percent of its television prime time is Canadian in content, this year featuring such drama series as ``Road to Avonlea,'' ``De Grassi High,'' and ``Street Legal.'' Previous budget cuts have slowed efforts to make CBC prime time 95 percent Canadian. The latest round of layoffs are aimed mainly at local stations, but are also expected to have some impact at the national level. In announcing the cutbacks and closures Dec. 5, CBC President Gerard Veilleux said they were permanent and would not be reversed even if there is a turn in the 54-year-old corporation's economic fortunes. A major element in the cost-saving program was closure of three television stations entirely and reducing eight others to small news reporting bureaus feeding their reports into regional and national centers. Windsor, a city of 200,000 inhabitants just across the Detroit River from a megalopolis of 4{ million, was particularly hard-hit because cancellation of the CBC's local programming there left it only with news canned in Toronto. ``This is Windsor, and we're sick of getting shoved around,'' Mayor John Millson told the 5,000 people who took to the streets on Sunday. Most major Canadian cities have competing private radio and television stations, some providing popular local newscasts. But the loss of a strong CBC presence in Windsor means it is even more difficult to maintain a separate identity from Detroit, which has more than 60 television and radio stations beaming into Canada. Getting local news is very important to Windsor residents, particularly on weekends when there is no Sunday paper. Employees in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan have received a provincial grant to study the feasibility of buying the local CBC station, reduced to a reporting bureau for the regional center in Regina. The corporation says there have been a number of queries to purchase stations, which will be considered. The CBC says that henceforth it will be not have more than one English-language station and one French-language station per province. That means for example that Calgary, Alberta, no longer has its own local CBC newscasts but instead must transmit versions it receives from rival Edmonton. Closure of Goose Bay, which served 35 small communities, means news for Labrador will be produced in St. John's, 450 miles away. The same is true for Saskatoon and Regina. The CBC also announced it no longer will operate the parliamentary channel, which broadcasts debate in the House of Commons, or Radio Canada International, the shortwave service that broadcasts in 14 languages abroad. Iqbal Rahemtulla, a spokesman for the corporation, said the House of Commons may take over the funding of the parliamentary broadcast and the Ministry of External Affairs, because of international ramifications, is considering ways to maintain Radio Canada International's services. If all that wasn't bad enough, the CBC's projections show that there will be another shortfall of about $42 million in the 1992-93 budget. Emerging relatively unscathed, except for a 1 percent budget reduction, is CBC Radio, broadcasting in both French and English to every Canadian in this gigantic country. The radio, which carries no advertising, features news, current events, talk shows and music to a wide range of audiences on both AM and FM. Its Northern Service also broadcasts in English, French and eight native languages and dialects. Also continuing are the network's well-regarded national televison news programs ``The Journal'' and ``The National,'' as well as its 24-hour all-news channel, ``Newsworld.'' ``It is certainly sad,'' said Rahemtulla. ``The CBC has been cut to the bone now.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Urged to Change Scholarship Policy
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee led a chorus of complaints about the Bush administration's ``misguided efforts to turn back the clock on equality'' by changing policies on scholarships for minority students. Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., used a hearing of his committee Wednesday to alternate criticisms of the Education Department's civil rights chief and an administration ruling that limits race-designated college scholarships. ``This first hearing is to examine yet another of the administration's policies and misguided efforts to turn back the clock on equality,'' said Hawkins, who is retiring at year end. He said a decision by Assistant Education Secretary Michael L. Williams, head of the civil rights office, not to appear before the panel to explain the new policy on minority scholarships ``is an affront to the committee, to the Congress and to American people.'' Rep. Kweisi Mfume, D-Md., described Williams' absence as ``a snub of his nose'' at the committee and called on him to ``do the right thing and resign your position, move out of the way'' so a more rational policy can be developed. In testimony, educators and civil rights officials urged the administration to reverse the policy, arguing that Tuesday's partial backtracking had merely confused the issue. They said Congress should step in and act if the administration failed to do so. Williams declared last week that the 1964 Civil Rights Act prohibited reserving scholarships for members of minority groups. The administration backed off in part after protests from civil rights groups and from educators, who said such a ruling would hurt the chances of thousands of minorities to get college educations. Under the revised policy, which brought new criticism from the right and left as well as promises of legal challenges, public universities and private schools that receive federal funding would be allowed to award such aid if they used only private money earmarked for that purpose. Race-based scholarships funded by state and local governments generally would not be allowed, although congressionally mandated scholarships for minorities would continue as in the past. The Education Department set a four-year transition period for schools to review programs under Title Six of the Civil Rights Act and comply. Robert Atwell, president of the American Council on Education, representing colleges and universities, said the new policy ``creates a distinction without a difference.'' He explained that once money is given to a school, it generally is considered institutional funds. ``We hope the administration recognizes the error of this approach and the foolishness of pursuing such a policy,'' he added. ``If not, we certainly hope the Congress will undertake to reverse the policy and deny the administration the opportunity of putting it into effect.'' Richard Rosser, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, testified the ruling draws a distinction between restricted funds and other funds available to private colleges and universities to award minority scholarships. Rosser described as ``patently absurd'' and without legal foundation the notion that private colleges and universities may accept money from donors who designate minority scholarships but cannot use their own funds for the same purpose. Rosser said 82 percent of all black undergraduates attending independent institutions received financial assistance, as did 72 percent of Hispanic undergraduates and 59 percent of Asian-American undergraduates. In 1986, he said, 309,000 minority students attending public and independent colleges and universities received some $750 million in aid from the institutions' own resources. David S. Tatel, a Washington attorney who served as director of the Office for Civil Rights from 1977 to 1979, said Williams' office ``has no authority to tell anyone that some minority scholarships are now suddenly illegal simply by making an announcement.'' Tatel said the office can bind recipients of federal funds only by formal regulation or by initiating formal fund termination proceedings and prevailing before an administration law judge and, if necessary, a federal court.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Drops Recycling Provision Under White House Pressure
DOC.TEXT: White House opposition is prompting the Environmental Protection Agency to scuttle proposed requirements for recycling by trash incinerators. The agency decided Wednesday to delete from incinerator regulations to be issued Dec. 31 a provision that would require at least 25 percent of incoming garbage be recycled as a condition for a burning permit. The recycling requirement met strong opposition earlier Wednesday during a meeting of the president's Council on Competitiveness, an interagency panel chaired by Vice President Dan Quayle that reviews regulatory proposals for their impact. In the face of the stiff criticism, EPA Administrator William Reilly agreed to withdraw the recycling provision, although he argued in favor of it during the session, said administration sources familiar with the White House discussions. They spoke on condition of anonymity. In a telephone interview, Reilly confirmed the decision to withdraw the recycling requirement in the rules that will establish new standards for air emissions for garbage incinerators. ``We will not propose source separation of at least 25 percent ... in these new standards,'' he said. Reilly said it was decided that the planned regulation was not the ``appropriate vehicle for a major mandatory (recycling) program with significant potential to disrupt local government plans'' for incineration programs. Environmentalists had praised the EPA when it included the recycling provision in a proposed incineration rule a year ago. They argued the provision would reduce the amount of wastes burned and, therefore, air pollution. ``This is a major environmental retreat,'' David Doniger, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said after Wednesday's action. ``The administration is retreating on its own commitment for recycling.'' Administration sources said Reilly had tried to enlist support for the recycling provision and reiterated his defense of the requirement at the meeting of the regulatory review panel. Among those reported arguing against mandatory recycling for incinerators were Henson Moore, the deputy energy secretary; Richard Darman, the White House budget director; and Michael Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, the sources said. They maintained that the costs of recycling a quarter of the garbage destined for incineration outweighed the benefits and could hinder development of waste-to-energy programs in some communities. They argued that the issue of recycling should be dealt with separately next year when federal laws on waste disposal come up for reconsideration in Congress. The EPA incinerator regulation will set stricter air pollution standards for trash burning at a time when an increasing number of communities see incineration as a means of dealing with a growing shortage of landfill space, especially in the East. Reilly argued forcefully for the recycling measure in Cabinet-level discussions, but when no compromise could be reached the matter was turned over to the Quayle review group. Reilly could have appealed the matter to President Bush but declined to do so. The waste disposal industry had opposed the recycling provision and argued that it could jeopardize some potential garbage incineration programs, which already are often highly controversial. ``Waste combustion is now seen as a cost-effective and environmentally sound means of solid waste management for many communities. This could change if burdensome, and perhaps costly, recycling requirements are a condition,'' Allen Moore, president of the National Solid Waste Management Association, recently wrote Reilly. The group represents 2,500 companies involved in waste disposal.

DOC.HEAD: Reindeer Bring Cheer to Lapland's Yuletide Tables
DOC.TEXT: Reindeer aren't pulling many sleighs in Scandinavia's arctic Lapland these days. But they do have an honored place at Christmas: on herders' holiday dinner tables. Snowmobiles have largely replaced reindeer-drawn sleighs in the region that stretches across Norway's mountains, Sweden's forests and Finland's tundra and is home to the world's largest herds of reindeer. The creatures fabled in many countries as pullers of Santa's sleigh are mostly raised for meat in Lapland. A few remain half-wild, roaming Lapland in a constant search for moss and other food. Animal rights activists complain that reindeer starve in the winter because of overgrazing or suffer needless pain when they are neutered and their ears notched to mark ownership. But Lapps say they feed the herds in the winter, and that other practices stem from centuries of tradition. Reindeer are a common festive dish. ``Of course we eat reindeer for Christmas,'' says Jan Amundsen, a Lapp who has herded the animals in north Norway for 25 years without ever driving reindeer sleigh. Ole K. Sara, Norway's reindeer administrator, says the herds provided the Lapps with meat, milk, transport and clothing until about 25 years ago. ``Now they are mainly food,'' he said. ``Not everyone likes the taste of the meat because it is sharper, tastier and takes some getting used to,'' said Hannu Kononen, a Finnish restaurateur. In the spring, herds are driven to summer pasture, often swimming to coastal islands. They run loose until the autumn roundup, when about one-third of them are slaughtered. ``Reindeer have a free life,'' said Bjarne Ornstedt of the Swedish Agriculture Ministry. ``They have to be able to roam a large area to find food ... and even when they are rounded up for slaughter they only spend a day or so in a corral.'' Tom Schandy of the World Wildlife Fund in Oslo agreed. ``Basically they have a pretty good life, certainly better than a cow in a barn,'' he said. Some reindeer are still used to take tourists for sleigh rides or in reindeer races. The reindeer weigh up to 250 pounds and can pull twice their weight more than 40 miles a day. Since most Scandinavians prefer other Yuletide foods, reindeer had little to fear from Christmas until U.S. cards, films, songs and advertisements made them popular in shopping malls. At least two half-wild reindeer, rescued from U.S.-inspired Christmas display by animal welfare activists this month, may now cringe every time they hear ``Jingle Bells.'' The Oslo activists said carols, lights and the shopping center crowds relentless petting sent the terrified reindeer into shock.

DOC.HEAD: Dole Asks Administration to Review University Admission Preferences
DOC.TEXT: A top Republican is urging the Bush administration to rethink government support for a practice whereby private universities give admission preferences to children of alumni. ``Let's face it, equal opportunity means just that - equal admissions opportunities for all, not just a few. These alumni perks have absolutely nothing to do with an individual's qualifications or merit,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said Wednesday. He asked the Education Department to reconsider a recent agency finding that ``legacy preferences'' in college admissions were lawful under the 1964 Civil Rights Act. Dole's request came as criticism continued to mount over another administration education policy. Civil rights activists and educators are asking the Education Department to abandon its policy limiting race-based college scholarships. Dole, in a statement, complained that the university admission preferences created unfair advantages for children of alumni, who often are wealthy contributors to the school. ``Now is the time to take the next logical step on the fairness front. The last thing we need in American education is a caste system,'' said Dole. ``If we are serious about a national re-examination of preferential policies in employment and education, then we have an obligation to be both fair and consistent in our approach.'' Dole sent a letter Tuesday to Lamar Alexander, nominated as education secretary by President Bush, asking the department to re-examine whether the admission preferences were permissible under civil rights law. In October, the acting director of the Education Department's regional office in Boston concluded there was nothing unlawful about Harvard University's admissions preferences for children of alumni. The finding came as part of a department investigation to determine whether there was discrimination against Asian-Americans who applied for admission to Harvard. Dole, in his letter to Alexander, said, ``If non-merit-based criteria like the legacy preference are used to determine who gets access to the best educations in this country, then the very assumptions undergirding our society (that `the rules of the game are fair to all' and that `merit will prevail') are called into question.'' The senator also made clear that Republicans had a political stake in the issue of educational fairness. ``At a time when the Republican Party is promoting the ideal of a `merit society,' we ought to be applying this principle across the board and not selectively,'' Dole wrote. He pointed out that Republicans, including Bush, had opposed civil rights legislation this year largely on grounds that it would lead to sex- and race-based hiring quotas by employers. ``We were silent, however, on college admission practices, like the legacy preference, that had the effect of benefiting those at the upper end of the income scale to the detriment of the economically less advantaged,'' Dole wrote. ``This silence is understandable since almost all of the debate was over employment policy, not education policy. But the two are linked.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Thursday, while share prices fell. The dollar closed at 134.58 yen, up 1.31 yen from Wednesday's close of 133.27 yen. After opening at 134.00 yen, it ranged between 133.85 and 134.65 yen. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average finished at 24,524.94 points, down 351.84 points or 1.41 percent from Wednesday's close of 24,876.78 points. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 88.06 points from Wednesday's 88.23-point close. Their yield stood at 7.055 percent, up from 7.020 percent Wednesday. Currency dealers said expectations of lower Japanese interest rates weakened the yen, although Bank of Japan Gov. Yasushi Mieno has denied any plans to follow the U.S. Federal Reserve's example. The U.S. central bank injected reserves into the U.S. banking system Wednesday to push the federal funds rate - the interest banks charge to make loans to each other - to 7 percent. That cut followed a Fed decision Tuesday to cut its discount rate - the interest charged to lend money to banks - to 6{ percent from 7 percent. The lower federal funds rate had little direct effect in the Tokyo market because it was already taken into account, said a dealer at Yasuda Trust and Banking, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But the approach of the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait was strengthening the dollar, dealers said. Investors tend to buy dollars as a shelter in times of uncertainty. On the stock market, the Nikkei average fell in early trading from profit-taking, but investors expecting the Bank of Japan to lower interest rates refrained from active selling, traders said. The weaker yen also discouraged buying, they said.
