The gunman demanded to be taken to where the air traffic controllers were and took the hostage up toward the control room on the third floor, the FBI said. But on the second floor, the hostage was able to talk Andersen out of going into the tower, Smith said. Andersen fired several additional shots, including some at military police, and kicked out some windows, the FBI said. He then left the building, leading base police on a chase. Andersen was arrested when he tried but failed to smash his car through a chain-link fence, suffering superficial injuries, Smith said. Police did not fire any shots during the attack, he said. Andersen fired 16 shots, according to the FBI. Andersen, besides wanting to go to the control tower, had other demands, but Smith said he could not discuss them early today.

DOC.HEAD: State Says Police Department Discriminated Against Hispanics
DOC.TEXT: Police Chief Daryl F. Gates rebutted charges from a state agency that his department has denied Hispanic officers promotions and maintained that a quota system would harm the force's quality. ``If we were simply to put people in positions because they were of a specific background, we would not be the kind of world-class department we are,'' Gates said at a news conference Wednesday. Gates made the comments in response to a complaint brought by the Department of Fair Employment and Housing on Tuesday. It alleged Hispanic officers have been unfairly held back for a decade because of biased and inconsistent promotion procedures. State agency lawyers said there was a great disproportion between the pool of qualified Hispanic officers who have applied for promotions, raises and choice assignments and those who have moved up the ranks. Gates denied the claims. ``Hispanic officers have the same kind of opportunities in this organization anyone has,'' he said. ``Ask them, what do they want me to do? Do they want me to hold their hand?'' Esteban Lizardo, a lawyer with the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, responded angrily to Gates' comments. ``I don't see how Chief Gates can say all is well,'' Lizardo said. ``Either he isn't looking at reality, or he is confused about what is occurring within his department.'' About 21 percent of the 8,400-officer police force is Hispanic, but most are concentrated in the lowest ranks. Only 10 percent of the captains are Hispanic. Under terms of a federal discrimination lawsuit, the department has been required for 10 years to boost recruitment of minorities and women. The department maintains it has been meeting its recruitment goals for Hispanics, who make up about a third of the city's population.

DOC.HEAD: Precede ABILENE, Texas
DOC.TEXT: B-1Bs Grounded After Engine Failures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with announcement from SAC headquarters, further details, quotes, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Strategic Air Command has grounded all 97 of its B-1B bombers because of recurring engine failures. ``SAC Commander-in-Chief Gen. John T. Chain, Jr. today grounded the command's B-1B fleet after two B-1Bs experienced catastrophic engine failures within a three-month period,'' SAC said Wednesday. The command said it would return the bombers to full flying status as soon as possible. No B-1Bs are based at Offutt, where SAC's headquarters is located. Wednesday's action marks the fifth time in less than two years that the bomber fleet has been grounded. Chain ordered the planes grounded after a B-1B engine failed Wednesday while flying near Dyess Air Force Base, Texas. On Oct. 4, an engine on a B-1B from McConnell Air Force Base, Kan., failed while the bomber was flying over southeastern Colorado. In both cases, the airplanes landed safely and no one was injured. B-1Bs have four engines. SAC said it suspects fan blades at the front of the engines were to blame for the failures. After the October incident, SAC spokesmen said the fan's failure caused the rest of the engine to be destroyed. The grounding means that B-1Bs will be flown for no reason other than war. The bombers will remain on nuclear alert at U.S. air bases, ready to launch if superpower tensions reach a crisis point. B-1Bs have been certified for use in conventional bombing missions, but SAC still has not trained the bombers' crews for anything other than its strategic nuclear mission. SAC used the word ``grounding'' in announcing the Wednesday's action, which is unusual. In most cases the command says troubled planes have been ordered to ``stand down'' until all planes can be inspected. A ``stand down'' is a more temporary step than grounding, SAC spokesmen have said in the past. SAC said Chain ordered the planes grounded after discussions with Gen. Charles C. McDonald, commander of the Air Force's Logistics Command in Ohio. Logistics Command is working with the engine's manufacturer, General Electric, to solve the problem, SAC said. B-1Bs are permanently based at Ellsworth Air Force Base, S.D., Grand Forks Air Force Base, N.D., Dyess and McConnell. Previous groundings occurred in March 1989 for fuel tank problems, in April 1989 for escape hatch problems, after a crash at Dyess in November 1989 and after an engine fell off one of the planes at Dyess in October.

DOC.HEAD: Klan Upset by Council's Passage of Anti-Mask Ordinance
DOC.TEXT: Ku Klux Klan members who plan a holiday weekend rally will have to leave their hoods at home, the City Council has ruled. Council members voted 5-4 Wednesday in favor of an emergency ordinance banning hoods or masks in public, despite arguments at an emotional meeting that the ban violates the Klan's right to free expression. A Klan leader said the the group will go ahead with the rally on Fountain Square and will sue the city in federal court, challenging the ban on civil rights grounds. The Klansmen plan to wear their traditional robes and individual Klan members will decide whether to wear hoods, said Ron Lee, vice president of the U.S. Knights of the Ku Klux Klan. ``Maybe a few of us will go to jail. I don't know,'' Lee said. ``We just want to put Christ back in Christmas.'' The Klansmen have a permit to set up a 10-foot wooden cross for one hour Saturday morning and to present speakers at the rally. The Klansmen are not allowed to set the cross on fire. A free-lance artist and a gospel choir plan competing demonstrations on Fountain Square at the time of the Klan rally. A church also is planning a prayer vigil Friday night. ``We will peacefully convey to all in Cincinnati the love of Jesus Christ for all races and our deep hurt at the misinterpretation of the meaning of the cross by the KKK,'' said Ray K. Nandyal, a member of Prince of Peace Lutheran Church. Council members voted for the ban on hoods even after city lawyers, Councilman David Mann and Mayor Charles Luken argued that it violated First Amendment guarantees of free expression. ``I think this city can survive a one-hour demonstration by a group that we all abhor,'' Mann said. The measure's sponsor, Councilman Nick Vehr, said the ordinance was vital for public safety because it would let police identify lawbreakers. Vehr said it also showed the city's opposition to the Klan and other white supremacy groups. The maximum penalty for violating the ordinance is 30 days in jail and a $250 fine. The state Supreme Court in Georgia earlier this month upheld a 39-year-old ban on masks. In rejecting an appeal from a Klansman arrested for wearing his hood in public, the justices said the 1951 law does not violate free-speech rights, and is a legitimate attempt to prevent violence and intimidation.

DOC.HEAD: Ershad's Vice President Arrested
DOC.TEXT: After a nine-day manhunt, police today tracked down and arrested the former vice president in the government of ousted President Hussain Muhammad Ershad, a news agency reported. Moudud Ahmed, a member of Ershad's inner circle, was found in a friend's home and placed under house arrest in his luxurious villa in the Gulshan diplomatic enclave, United Press of Bangladesh reported. Moudud was ordered held for 120 days under the Special Powers Act, which permits arrest without charges. The law was used to confine Ershad on Dec. 12, and an inquiry commission was appointed to investigate charges of corruption and abuse of power. Moudud was one of Ershad's closest advisers during the seven-week campaign of street demonstrations and violent anti-government protests that led to Ershad's ouster on Dec. 6. He was the third important official of Ershad's government to be arrested. Police earlier jailed former Deputy Prime Minister Shah Moazzem Hossain and placed ex-Home Minister Mahmudul Hassan under house arrest. Thirteen more former ministers and senior officials are being sought. Bangladeshis, meanwhile, began preparing for the country's first free elections, scheduled for Feb. 27, by painting walls with graffiti depicting the symbols of the main contending parties. All previous Bangladesh governments took power through coups and assassinations. Most of the elections called to legitimize any of these governments were marred by fraud and vote-rigging. Caretaker President Shahabuddin Ahmed, who replaced Ershad, has promised a free and fair vote in the upcoming election of 300 parliamentary seats. He has prohibited anyone working in his transition government from running. The main contenders are the Awami League led by Sheik Hasina and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party of Khaleda Zia. Both parties plan to contest all seats and each claims it can win a majority, despite a profusion of more than 100 other parties. It is not clear what role Ershad's Jatiya Party will play in the elections. It has not been banned from participating, but with the arrests of Ershad and other party officials of the ousted government, it may be difficult for the party to recoup.

DOC.HEAD: New Hampshire Governor Opposes Monday King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Judd Gregg has recommended creating a weekend holiday honoring the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., but backers of a Monday holiday see the proposal as an insult. ``It's a slap in the face for the governor to say that we need his permission to celebrate the holiday on a Sunday,'' Rep. Lionel Johnson, head of the state chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today. Gregg proposed a Sunday holiday to end years of wrangling over a King observance. ``The time has come for the state to put the issue of a Martin Luther King day behind us,'' Gregg said Wednesday. Backers of a Monday King holiday plan to introduce legislation for the legislative session that begins next month. The federal government and all states except New Hampshire, Arizona and Montana observe a King holiday on the third Monday in January. The idea has failed repeatedly in the Legislature, and Gregg said he continues to oppose a Monday holiday on economic grounds. Gregg said another day off would be costly to municipalities and hurt New Hampshire's productivity in the increasingly competitive world economy. ``Creating another holiday in a work-week situation obviously undermines that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Colors Switched on Tulsa Police Cars
DOC.TEXT: Black and white, white and black, what's the difference? Plenty, say Tulsa police after learning that half of the 90 new squad cars had the colors reversed. ``I went out the other day and looked at one and boy, was it ugly,'' said police Sgt. Ollie Harris. Tulsa police cars are black with white tops, doors and trunk lids. Harris said 45 new squad cars, which he called ``ugly turtles,'' had the colors the other way around. Riverside Chevrolet won the contract to provide 45 of the 90 new cars that police ordered in July. Harris said the color mix-up happened at the factory. The white-and-blacks are being sent to a New Jersey dealership, where they will be sold to a police agency there, officials said. Harris said Riverside hopes to deliver the replacements, with the correct color scheme, by Feb. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Helicopter Crashes In South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli army helicopter crashed in south Lebanon during the night, injuring two airmen on board, security sources said today. Israeli military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there was no crash but a ``difficult landing.'' They said no crew members were injured and that they were brought back to Israel by a rescue team. The Lebanese security sources said the aircraft plunged into a rocky ravine Wednesday evening near the southern town of Shebaa on the snowy slopes of Mount Hermon. One source said the accident apparently was caused by poor visibility. ``The area was covered with thick fog,'' he said. He said the Israelis quickly sent two other helicopters that evacuated the wounded airmen. Neither report said how many airmen were aboard the copter. Shebaa is within Israel's self-proclaimed ``security zone'' in south Lebanon. Stretching from the Mediterranean coast in the west to the slopes of Mount Hermon in the east, the buffer covers about 440 square miles. Israel established the security zone in 1985 after withdrawing the bulk of its invading army that occupied the region for three years. The strip, policed by 1,000 Israeli soldiers and 3,000 allied militiamen, serves as a buffer against cross-border guerrilla infiltrations into northern Israel. Helicopter gunships and air force jets often strike suspected guerrilla targets within the zone and farther north.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Dealers Kill Girl, 5, for Revenge on Brother
DOC.TEXT: Two drug dealers seeking revenge on a 16-year-old boy who allegedly stole from them shot and killed his 5-year-old sister, police said. Katherine Staples was shot several times in the chest when the drug dealers burst into her house late Tuesday night, police said. ``These two drug dealers wanted to leave a message to the 16-year-old who ran off with their drugs: We don't have you, but we got your family,'' Inspector Hubert Yopp said Wednesday. ``These two men mercilessly and methodically tracked this 16-year-old for over a month. And when they could not find him, they killed his sister and tried to kill his girlfriend as a message.'' The two dealers stormed the house shooting and searching for the 16-year-old, police said. They instead found the youth's 18-year-old girlfriend and his sister, shooting them as they fled. The youth's father escaped out the back door, and the girl's mother was unharmed. ``Katherine didn't even have any inkling of what crack is,'' said Eugene Littleton, 34, a neighbor. ``The innocent always suffer.'' The 18-year-old woman, whom police declined to identify, was treated and released from Detroit Receiving Hospital. Police said witnesses reported the 16-year-old boy stole some of the dealers' cocaine, $50 cash and a gun. He now is in protective custody. The youth's father, Freddie Banford, 36, earlier told the dealers he would repay them for the stolen property and cash, but they refused, police said. Police had no one in custody today.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Police Reservist in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen ambushed and killed a police reservist today and two apparent bomb attempts misfired elsewhere in the province, police said. No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attacks, but suspicion inevitably fell on the Irish Republican Army, which has targeted police and British troops in its campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland. Belfast police identified the dead man as Wilfred Weathers, 46, and said he was shot early today as he drove to his home near Lurgan, 20 miles southwest of Belfast. He was hit several times and died at the scene, said a police spokesman. ``Sooner or later the people responsible will be caught,'' said Richard Needham, the Northern Ireland junior minister responsible for law and order in the province. ``The arm of the law is remorseless, it is long and it never, ever forgets.'' A burned-out car believed to have been used by the gunmen was found after the attack in a Roman Catholic district of Lurgan, the police spokesman said. Weathers was married with four children and had served with the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the province's predominantly Protestant police force, for 15 years, said the police spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. Also today, police said they sealed off a checkpoint on the border with the Republic of Ireland after armed men forced a civilian to drive up to the crossing in a milk truck that they told him contained explosives. Up to four armed men wearing masks held a relative of the driver hostage as they forced him to drive through the checkpoint at Kilturk in County Fermanagh, 60 miles southwest of Belfast, said a spokesman for the Royal Ulster Constabulary police force. There was no explosion and the driver, who abandoned the vehicle 65 feet from the checkpoint, was not harmed, said the spokesman. The relative was also released unharmed, he said. He said police could not immediately say whether there were any explosives in the truck. Earlier, 80 families in Londonderry were evacuated from their homes after the discovery of a suspect device near the Coshquin border post. Five soldiers and a civilian were killed at that post on Oct. 24 when the IRA forced a civilian to drive an explosives-laden vehicle through the checkpoint. The domestic British news agency, Press Association, reported the IRA claimed today it tried to explode a 400-pound bomb in Londonderry's White House Park district as an army patrol drove by. Only the detonator exploded, Press Association said. A spokeswoman for the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the province's police force, said she could not confirm the device was a bomb.

DOC.HEAD: Bent Barge Threatens Allegheny River Commerce
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Coast Guard officials halted traffic on the Allegheny River because a sunken scrap barge threatened craft on the surface today. A four-mile stretch of the river was closed from Point State Park in downtown Pittsburgh to the Highland Park Bridge northeast of the city, Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Rhea Giacoma said. ``We have personnel on a towboat who are sounding the river to try to determine the barge's location,'' she said. ``We sent word to the waterways associations that the river was closed, and the locks and dams are not letting traffic through.'' Barges were backing up this morning at U.S. Army Corps of Engineers locks above the sunken barge, Corps engineer Jim Mershimer said. The sunken barge broke loose from its moorings Friday and floated about 400 yards from the Azcon Scrap Corp. steelyard. It sailed over a dam, got stuck in the river mud and bent at a 45-degree angle. Two barge workers jumped to safety. Giacoma said she believed the barge broke free from the dam during Tuesday's more than 2 inches of rain, a record for the date. Coal and steel barges travel the Allegheny and Monongahela rivers to the Ohio River through Pittsburgh, the nation's busiest inland port. Tuesday's rainfall forced closure of four locks on the Monongahela but all had reopened today, Mershimer said. The Monongahela Wharf parking lot, which serves hundreds o Pittsburgh commuters, was closed because of flooding for the second consecutive day.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Approves Five-Year Military Plan
DOC.TEXT: Caught between U.S. pressure to boost its military posture and Asian and domestic pressure not to, Japan's government did both in the new five-year defense plan approved today by the Cabinet. On one hand, the $171 billion program calls for Tokyo to bear more of the costs of basing 50,000 U.S. soldiers in Japan as part of the postwar security arrangement. In response to U.S. demands, Japan agreed to increase its share by $1.65 billion, from 40 percent to 50 percent. At the same time, the government slashed overall spending growth in the new defense budget to 3 percent annually from the more than 5 percent over the past five years. That was a response both to the lapsed Soviet threat and renewed Asian fears of a strong Japanese military, as well as powerful public opinion in Japan against more defense spending, government spokesmen said. ``The Soviet Union was a potential threat for Japan in the past, but we now believe that ... has disappeared,'' Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto said at a news conference. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto said he hoped the new defense plan would be acceptable to Asian nations. China, North and South Korea and others, alarmed by a government proposal to send Japanese troops overseas, had repeatedly urged Japan to reconsider in recent months. The government proposal to send troops to the Persian Gulf for non-combat roles under the U.N. flag was defeated in Parliament early last month. A proposal to send non-military personnel to aid gulf peacekeeping forces is being discussed. Critics charged that the first bill violated Japan's ``peace'' constitution, under which the Self-Defense Forces should have no other mission than to repulse a ``limited, small-scale'' foreign attack. ``Generally speaking, this is a wait-and-see budget,'' said Tomohisa Sakanaka, a leading defense expert at Aoyama Gakuin University. ``After three years or so, we can see what the post-Cold War situation may be. ``At the same time, the Japanese government is not well prepared to think of Japan's future mission, for example, whether we'll have a United Nations peacekeeping force or not.'' Asked whether the plan to divide the cost of maintaining U.S. troops equally represents a formal U.S-Japan agreement, Foreign Ministry spokesman Toshimitsu Mori said, ``Appropriate coordination has already been made between us.'' ``The Japan-U.S. security treaty is the core of Japan's defense policy, and therefore we will continue to increase our support for U.S. troops in Japan,'' Sakamoto said. The U.S. Embassy had no comment on the five-year plan or the ongoing negotiations over burden-sharing. Japan now pays about $3 billion annually to station U.S. troops on its territory, including many of the expenses for the 22,000 Japanese base workers. Yen-denominated salaries, overtime pay and welfare expenses for Japanese workers at U.S. military bases have been covered by the U.S. government. But Japan now has agreed to pay almost all expenses for those workers, Mori said. Essentially, the new five-year plan cuts costs by keeping the number of Japanese army soldiers at 153,000 and reducing the amount of big-ticket hardware purchased under the previous five-year buildup.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Resignation Stuns the Kremlin
With PM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Moments after Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze stunned the Kremlin today by announcing his resignation, Soviet political commentators began debating why he did it. Was it an emotional reaction to the rise of the more conservative forces in the nation? Was it part of some long-building disagreement with the military over the Soviet Union's increasingly independent foreign policy? Or was it - as Tass commentator Andrei Orlov wrote - a clever ruse to somehow split the conservative forces and scare the reformers into giving President Mikhail S. Gorbachev the support he needs to impose presidential rule? Whatever the reasons, Shevardnadze's departure represents a serious blow to Gorbachev. Not only is he losing a shrewd diplomat who shaped Soviet foreign policy on Afghanistan and nuclear disarmament, but also a key ally among reformers. As another Tass commentator put it, Gorbachev ``has so far been able to avoid open conflicts with the truly democratic wing in the Soviet leadership in his middle-of-the-road approaches to domestic and international problems.'' The resignation comes at a critical time for Gorbachev, as he weighs taking harsh actions to hold the Soviet Union together amid a worsening economy, against the need to preserve the democratic reforms that he has launched. It also comes during the Persian Gulf crisis and less than two months before a summit with President Bush to conclude a treaty to slash nuclear arsenals - possibly a contentious issue among hard-line military officers. In this light, Shevardnadze's move could almost be seen as an act of disloyalty. But this would be out of character for Shevardnadze, who was widely admired for his personal modesty, integrity and, above all, unflagging loyalty to Gorbachev - a friendship that dates back to their teens. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said that in resigning, Shevardnadze wanted to add his deep feelings of ``respect and friendship'' for Gorbachev. Shevardnadze's motive most likely is the most obvious possibility: he wants to send a strong message to Gorbachev and other reformers in the Soviet Union about the dangers of dictatorship and instability. Churkin let one hint fall when he told reporters that Shevardnadze spent ``many sleepless nights'' before making the decision. ``The minister believes that this move, made by a man of his status and authority, will become a serious warning to all, that people will soberly and quietly look at themselves and the state of affairs,'' Churkin said. ``Only the people can prevent dictatorial elements from taking power.'' Tass noted that Shevardnadze has spoken often in the past about the need for stability at home. ``In his addresses to parliament and a number of interviews, Shevardnadze said repeatedly that economic weakness and mounting instability could reduce to naught all his country's efforts on the international scene,'' the Tass commentary said. In noting this, Tass said Shevardnadze may have been influenced by Wednesday's statement to the Congress of People's Deputies by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, who said ``perestroika, as originally conceived, has failed to materialize,'' and not even a Cabinet reshuffle would ensure its success. The irony is that thousands of people in recent months have filled the streets calling for Ryzhkov's resignation, but he remains and it is Shevardnadze who is stepping down. ---
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Brian Friedman is a correspondent in the Moscow bureau of The Associated Press who has been writing about Soviet affairs since 1988.

DOC.HEAD: White House, Democrats Trade Claims on Drug Use
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf pvs bgng, `The number,' to UPDATE with survey findings on groups with higher-than-average drug use; INSERTS 4 grafs after 18th graf pvs bgng, `But Mason,' to UPDATE with details of the survey's sample, techniques, comment from treatment specialist
DOC.TEXT: Democrats say the White House is ignoring the fact that the nation's population of drug addicts is bigger than ever as it touts a new survey that indicates a drop in casual use of cocaine. ``While the Household Survey is dramatic proof that the Reagan and Bush administrations have succeeded in reducing casual use, it is equally dramatic proof that (they have) failed terribly in reducing hard-core addiction,'' said Rep. John Conyers Jr., D-Mich. ``We are fighting a two-tiered drug war,'' said Conyers, chairman of the House Government Operations Committee. ``The fact that daily cocaine use has risen, not dropped, indicates that only one drug war is being effectively fought - the one for the educated and middle-class. ``The drug strategy does not yet fight for our inner cities, where addiction rates have gone up among poor people and minorities.'' The Household Survey on Drug Abuse, released Wednesday, found that current use of any illicit drug dropped 44 percent over the last five years, from 23 million in 1985 to 12.9 million this year. The survey also found a huge 72 percent drop in current use of cocaine, the most virulent drug of the 1980s. The number of current cocaine users fell from 5.8 million in 1985 to 1.6 million this year. ``Current use,'' also called ``casual use,'' means using a drug at least once a month. ``The magnitude of the progress is impressive indeed,'' President Bush said at a news conference releasing the survey findings. ``The news we have today suggests that our hard work is paying off and our national strategy is having an effect.'' However, there also was bad news: -The number of people who use cocaine daily or almost daily rose by 37 percent over five years, from 246,000 in 1985 to 336,000 this year, according to the survey sponsored by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, or NIDA. -The number of current crack cocaine users has remained stable the past two years at about a half-million, and the survey undercounts them, according to NIDA Director Charles R. Schuster. -While current use of any illicit drug fell during the past five years from 12 percent to 6.4 percent of all Americans age 12 and above, the rates remained higher among several groups: young adults age 18-25 years, 14.9 percent; the unemployed, 14 percent; blacks, 8.6 percent, and people living in large metropolitan areas or living in the West, both 7.3 percent. Officials also conceded that the survey's estimate of 48,000 current heroin users was inaccurate, as NIDA has been saying for a decade that there are about a half-million heroin addicts. Even with such acknowledgments, Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, condemned the survey. He said it ``misses more addicts than it counts.'' A Judiciary Committee staff report estimates that 2.4 million people use cocaine at least once a week, not the 662,000 cited in the Household Survey. The report also said the number of such cocaine users has increased by 200,000, rather than declining by that number as the NIDA survey found. As for heroin, the Judiciary Committee staff report estimated there are some 940,000 weekly heroin users, not 500,000 as the government says. John P. Walters, acting director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, said he realizes the Household Survey fails to check ``certain populations in which heavy drug use is assumed to be unusually concentrated.'' Those groups include homeless people as well as those in prison, shelters, drug-treatment centers and other institutions such as dormitories. Schuster estimated that as many as 50 percent of the more than 1 million people imprisoned nationwide were drug users. In addition, some 18 percent of the households contacted for the survey refused to participate, said Dr. James O. Mason, assistant secretary for health in the Department of Health and Human Services. But Mason said the survey's tracking of trends - if not the precise numbers of users - is accurate because the survey has been administered the same way all 10 times since 1971. He also said the findings are similar to those of other studies. The survey interviewed 9,259 people age 12 and older from March 12 to June 20. Interviews were conducted in person, but respondents completed their own answer sheets to assure them that their responses would remain confidential and anonymous, the report says. Some in the drug treatment community stressed that use of drugs in some areas continues unabated. ``While the survey reflects progress in mainstream America, it overlooks chronically intoxicated and heavy using populations in America,'' said Mitchell Rosenthal, president of New York-based Phoenix House, the large private, non-profit drug abuse treatment agency in the country. ``We haven't even made a dent in areas most in need of help, areas where the drug problem continues to run rampant,'' Rosenthal said. Rep. Charles B. Rangel, chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics, said the survey indicates that ``drug abusers who have something to lose - jobs, families, homes and status - are turning away.'' But other population groups that have little to lose have not gotten the message, and the nation's punishment-oriented drug strategy isn't helping, the New York Democrat said.

DOC.HEAD: Duke Says He'll Announce For Governor Next Month
DOC.TEXT: State Rep. David Duke says he intends to announce his candidacy for governor next month. On Wednesday, he said he will make an ``informal'' announcement Jan. 4 in Metairie and a formal announcement later. Kenner Mayor Aaron Broussard and Louisiana Public Service Commission member Louis Lambert, both Democrats, have begun campaigns. Incumbent Buddy Roemer, and former Gov. Edwin Edwards, also Democrats, are expected to run. Duke is a Republican whom state and national party leaders have repudiated because of his past past leadership of the Ku Klux Klan and sale of Nazi literature from his Metairie office even after his 1989 election to the state Legislature. Duke's response: ``My background more and more recedes every time I run.'' He predicted he will be in a runoff with Edwards or Roemer. He said he has pledges for $1.5 million in campaign contributions and believes he can raise millions more. Duke received 44 percent of the vote in this year's U.S. Senate race against incumbent Democrat Bennett Johnston, who received 54 percent in a four-man race.

DOC.HEAD: New York Assembly Speaker Pleads Innocent to Real-Estate Scam Charges
DOC.TEXT: State Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and his top aide pleaded innocent today to cheating their law firm's clients out of hundreds of thousands of dollars in a real-estate scam. ``I've done nothing illegal, immoral, unlawful or unethical,'' Miller said outside federal court in Brooklyn where he and Jay E. Adolf were arraigned. U.S. District Judge Raymond J. Dearie allowed both men to remain free on their own recognizance. The judge set the trial for September 1991. Miller and Adolf were named last week in a 19-count indictment charging them with mail fraud, conspiracy and falsifying documents. The felonies are each punishable by up to five years in prison and $250,000 fines. Miller, the state's most powerful Democrat after the governor, would be expelled from the Legislature if convicted. He told reporters he had no intention of stepping down. His lawyer, Gerald B. Lefcourt, called the charges politically motivated and ``an attempt to stretch the mail-fraud statute out of all proportion.''

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts Of Eduard Shevardnadze's Resignation Speech
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze announced his resignation Thursday during a speech to parliament in which he defended his policies and spoke of a possible dictatorship in the country. Here are his remarks, as translated by The Associated Press:

I have the briefest and most difficult speech in my life. I didn't ask to take the floor, but some of the deputies have insisted, and I know the reasons this group insisted I speak, and I have prepared the text of the speech and am giving it to the secretariat of the congress. Deputies can acquaint themselves with what has been done in the sphere of foreign policy by the leadership of the country, the president and the Foreign Ministry, and how the external conditions for development are shaping up, for implementing our democratic reforms, renewing the country, for economic development, etc. Something really has been accomplished, and it is set forth in the speech. I want to make a short statement consisting of two parts. First, yesterday there were speeches by some of our comrades. These were our veterans. They have raised the question of adopting a declaration forbidding the leadership and the president from sending troops to the Persian Gulf. This was the approximate content of their speeches. ... There were quite few such statements and speeches in the press, on television. I will be frank, yesterday's statements were the last straw. What is going on in the Persian Gulf in the long run? I have had to speak on this subject and explain the policy of the Soviet Union in this country and outside this country more than 10 times. This policy is very serious, and very well thought out and conceived, and corresponding to all the standards of civilized relations among states. We have very good friendly relations with Iraq that have been built for years, and these relations are still preserved, but we do not have any moral right to agree to the aggression by Iraq, to the annexation of a very small country that cannot defend itself. Then we would have crossed out everything that has been done in recent years by all our people in the sphere of establishing the principles of new political thinking. That's the first point. Second. I have explained more than once, and Gorbachev in his speech in the Supreme Soviet (legislature) mentioned the fact that the Soviet leadership has no plans - I don't know, maybe there is some plan, there is some group. ... But some speakers say the Minister of Foreign Affairs has plans to deploy troops to the Persian Gulf. I have said that we have no plans. They do not exist, and no one is planning to send even one soldier, even one representative of the Armed Forces of the U.S.S.R. And this was stated. Again, somebody needs this. Again, this question, this problem arises. And I know that this arises in the lobby of the congress. The third question. Yes, I have said and I reaffirm it right now, to everyone who is listening: I state that if the interests of the Soviet people suffer, if even one person suffers, no matter where it happens, not only in Iraq, the Soviet nation and the Soviet government will defend the interests of its citizens. And I think that in this respect, the deputies should support the Soviet leadership. And I want to touch upon another question. Is all this accidental? Was the statement of two members of parliament accidental that it was possible to remove the interior minister and the time has come to settle accounts with the foreign minister? This statement has gone around literally the entire world press and our newspapers. Are those fellows so brave? I will say, because my age allows me to, because they are really too young, with colonel epaulets, to make such statements addressed to a minister, addressed to a government member. Read newspapers. I will not name any names today. And what is surprising? I think it requires serious thought: Who is behind those comrades, and what is it? Why doesn't anyone refute (them)? ... That there are no plans, or maybe there are such plans (for a coup). In this connection, allow me to say a few words about the personal dignity of an individual, about the personal feelings, because many people think that ministers who sit there, or members or the government, or the president or someone else, that they were hired, are hired, and that they can treat them however they wish.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: they wish.
DOC.TEXT: I think that this is inadmissible. In this connection, I recall the party congress. Was it an accidental phenomenon or a real struggle that unfolded during the congress. The sharpest struggle between reformers (and) I won't say conservatives - I respect conservatives because they have their own views acceptable to society - and reactionaries. Precisely reactionaries. (applause). That battle, I must say directly, was won by progressive members, delegates, progressive delegates to the (party) congress, was carried out with dignity. Against my will, without consulting with me, my name, I, my candidacy, was entered in a secret ballot, and 800 delegates voted against me. What was this, accidental or not accidental? Was it that the policies carried out by the foreign minister were no good? Or did his personality fail to suit someone? It's a serious question, a more than serious question. I think, in fact, this phenomenon is not accidental. I apologize, but I am recollecting now the Supreme Soviet session. On (Supreme Soviet Chairman) Comrade (Anatoly) Lukyanov's initiative, just before the beginning of the session, a serious question was included into the agenda on treaties with the German Democratic Republic. I happened to be away, and my deputies were called in and they were put in a foolish situation, and the (discussion) of the question failed. I had to speak the next week, and what happened was that the same people who are now acting as authors leveled serious charges that the foreign minister made one-sided concessions (over the treaty), that he is incompetent, illiterate, etc., etc. There was not a single person, including the chairman, who would respond and say that it is not fair. It's persecution! All kinds of publications appear. And what expressions: `Away with the Gorbachev clique!' They also add Shevardnadze and several other names. I was shaken, I will say it directly, by the events of the first day, the beginning of the work of our congress. The pushing of a (voting) button decided not only the fate of the president, but also perestroika, democracy. Is it normal? Comrade democrats, in the broadest sense of the word, you have scattered. Reformers have gone and hidden in the bushes. Dictatorship is coming - I say this with all responsibility. No one knows what kind of dictatorship it will be, and who will come - what kind of dictator, and what kind of system. I want to make the following statement. I am resigning. Don't react and don't curse me. Let it be my contribution, protest if you will, against dictatorship. I express my great gratitude to Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev. I am his friend. I think as he does. I have always supported and will until the last day, support the ideas of perestroika, the idea of renewal, the ideas of democratization. We have done great work in the international area. But I think that it is my duty as a person, a citizen, as a Communist. I cannot accept those events that are happening in our country, or accept those trials that are in store for our people. And still I think the dictatorship will not come to pass. The future belongs to democracy and freedom! Thank-you very much.

DOC.HEAD: New German Parliament Poised to Begin Making Unity Work
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to CLARIFY that legislator hopes lawmakers from former East Germany will vote as a bloc in support of eastern Germany. Pickup 8th graf pvs:``It's going...''
DOC.TEXT: The newly elected Parliament of the united Germany convened for the first time today and began the challenging task of forging a common future for two distinct societies. The 662 members of the Bundestag, the policy making lower house, held their inaugural session in Berlin's Reichstag building, the historic seat of German legislatures. Lawmakers, however, will return to the seat of government in Bonn for subsequent meetings. They eventually will decide whether to move permanently to Berlin, the new nation's symbolic capital. The first session was opened by Willy Brandt, former chancellor and veteran politician. The guests of honor included Italian President Francesco Cossiga. The lawmakers were elected by Germans from both East and West on Dec. 2, the culmination of a series of milestones that began with former East Germany's peaceful revolt against its Communist government. The first session may indicate whether the legislators from former East Germany will act as a single voting bloc on behalf of eastern Germany even though they are affiliated with different political parties. Lawmaker Wolfgang Thierse, who prior to unification and the December elections led the Social Democrat faction in the first freely elected East German Parliament, said he hopes the east German legislators will vote as one bloc. ``It's going to be more difficult for us to stay in the picture,'' Thierse said. ``There's going to be a perception we're not as intelligent, not as politically clever, and that doesn't wash. ``We have to keep our interests alive. We have to treat these new five states (that East Germany has become) as a single land. We'll have to be united by common interests and common problems of the five new states,'' he said. Thierse's Social Democrats are the main opposition to the conservative Christian Democrats of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Among the eastern Germans who took a seat in Parliament today is Lothar de Maiziere, the Christian Democrat who was the first and last freely chosen leader of East Germany. De Maiziere resigned from Kohl's Cabinet this week amid allegations that he may hve been an informant for the Communist secret police. De Maiziere has denied the allegations. Thierse said such stigmas will be East Germany's legacy for many years. He said western Germans still don't understand the society they have absorbed. ``We must not bring some abstract morality to this past, but a sense of real-life history as it was,'' he said. Thierse, who worked in the Culture Ministry under the former regime, said most East Germans did not fight the old system or work closely with it. Most merely adapted to it.

DOC.HEAD: San Diego Leads in Race for 1992 GOP Convention
DOC.TEXT: The 1992 Republican National Convention likely will be in San Diego because of White House concerns about the possible political fallout from having it in Texas or Louisiana, a newspaper reported today. The problms with those two sites involve unwanted ties with David Duke in Louisiana, where the former Ku Klux Klansman and disowned Republican recently lost a U.S. Senate race, and Democratic Gov.-elect Ann Richards in Texas, who blasted President Bush at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, GOP sources told the Los Angeles Times. Representatives from Houston, New Orleans and San Diego - the three cities in the running as the site - met with the GOP site selection committee in Washington this week. The committee will make its recommendation by Jan. 11 to the full Republican National Committee, which will select a city at its winter meetings Jan. 25. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu said last week that he favors meeting in San Diego.

DOC.HEAD: The Political Rise of Eduard Shevardnadze
With PM-Soviet-Politics
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronology of the political career of Eduard Shevardnadze. --- 1948 - Joins the Communist Party. 1958 - Named full member of the Georgian party's Central Committee. 1965-1972- Minister of Internal Affairs in Georgia. 1972 - Communist Party leader in Georgian republic. 1978 - Appointed non-voting member of national Communist Party's Politburo. 1985 - Made a full member of the Politburo. 1985 - Appointed to succeed Andrei Gromyko as foreign minister.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Pleads Innocent in Teaneck Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A white policeman charged with fatally shooting a black teen-ager pleaded innocent to reckless manslaughter charges today. Officer Gary Spath, 29, was indicted Nov. 28 in the April 10 shooting death in Teaneck of 16-year-old Phillip Pannell. The shooting touched off race riots and divided the town, a New York City suburb of 39,000. Spath's lawyer, Robert Galantucci, entered the plea and told Superior Court Judge Charles DeGisi that his client should be released on bail because of his strong ties to the community. Deputy Attorney General Charles Waldron did not object. DeGisi set bail at $50,000. Police said Pannell was reaching for a gun in his pocket when he was shot in the back. But witnesses said his hands were above his head as if in surrender, and an autopsy by a pathologist hired by Pannell's family supported that contention. Spath could get up to 10 years in prison if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Court Turns Down Request To Resume Nancy Cruzan's Feeding
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Missouri Supreme Court turning down request to re-insert feeding tube, Operation Rescue founder arriving in Mount Vernon. Picks up 10th graf pvs: `Probate Judge...'
DOC.TEXT: The Missouri Supreme Court today turned down a request to resume food and water for Nancy Cruzan, while demonstrators camped on a hospital's steps to protest removal of the comatose woman's feeding tube. The court rejected a plea by an anti-euthanasia group that state officials be forced to provide nourishment to Ms. Cruzan, whose condition was deteriorating six days after the tube was removed. The court's two-sentence order issued at Jefferson City was signed by Judge Edward Robertson. He wrote the court's November 1988 decision that denied a request by Ms. Cruzan's family to halt her food and water. That 1988 ruling sent the case to the U.S. Supreme Court, which ruled in June in its first right-to-die case that Missouri could require ``clear and convincing'' evidence that Ms. Cruzan would want to die. The request to resume feeding was filed by attorney Mario Mandina of Lawyers for Life. It listed a Kansas City woman, Yvette Williams, as the plaintiff. ``Nancy can receive love. From what I've been told, she responds to her nurses. She can follow people with her eyes. I care for four kids who can't track people with their eyes. That does not mean we should kill them,'' said Ms. Williams, a 27-year-old graphic artist who works part-time at a mental retardation center. She was quoted in The Joplin Globe today. Joining her quest this morning was Randall Terry, founder of the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue. He arrived at the rehabilitation hospital and was trying to meet with Ms. Cruzan's parents, a spokesman said. Joe and Joyce Cruzan will not meet with Terry, their lawyer, attorney, William Colby, said. ``There is enough pain from the auto accident that to compound that by having a group of strangers who never knew Nancy interfering with the medical decisions is inappropriate,'' the lawyer said. The Cruzans contend their 33-year-old daughter would not want to live in the persistent vegetative state she has experienced since a 1983 car accident. After the U.S. Supreme Court set the standard of ``clear and convincing'' evidence, the Cruzans went back to local court. There, three of Ms. Cruzan's co-workers testified they had talked about such a situation and Ms. Cruzan had indicated she would want to die. Probate Judge Charles Teel ruled Friday sufficient evidence existed to allow the tube to be removed. Ms. Cruzan's condition went from stable to deteriorating on Wednesday, rehabilitation center spokeswoman Barbara Shoun said. Doctors expected her to live a week or two after the tube was removed Friday. About a dozen people, wrapped in thin blankets and sleeping bags, camped out overnight on the state hospital steps in this southwest Missouri town. ``We're calling upon people from around the country to come and camp out and stand with Nancy Cruzan at the hour of her death,'' said the Rev. Matt Trewhella, a minister from Milwaukee. Police banned demonstrators from the building after 10 of them refused to leave the director's office and a hallway Wednesday. They ``flopped out on the ground'' and refused to move so police pushed them out the main entrance in wheelchairs, Mrs. Shoun said. No one was arrested. About 25 to 30 police officers patrolled the rehabilitation center and stood guard outside Ms. Cruzan's second-floor room, authorities said. Nineteen people arrested Tuesday for trespassing and illegal assembly remained jailed on $1,000 bond each. All assumed the name Nancy Cruzan and police said they could not post bail until they gave their real names. All but one was fasting.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Scare Turns Up Something Smelly - Fertilizer
DOC.TEXT: The Secret Service sealed the entrance to the White House for an hour today after an explosives-sniffing dog detected something amiss in a congressman's car. It turned out to be fertilizer. ``Great fun,'' said Rep. Herbert H. Bateman, R-Va., after a bomb specialist wearing a flak jacket and a protective helmet combed through his car. Bateman was in a group of Congress members just back from Saudi Arabia and was meeting with the president. The Northwest gate to the White House, the official entrance used by visitors to the president, was closed. The driveway where Bateman's and about a dozen other congressional cars were parked was sealed off. Reporters were ordered to leave the grounds and kept in the nearby press briefing room as Bateman's car was carefully examined. Finally, Bateman was summoned from the White House and interviewed by Secret Service agents. Later, after the emergency was called off, he chatted briefly with reporters from the front seat of his car. ``It was fertilizer from some azaleas that were hauled in the back seat a few weeks ago,'' he said. Many fertilizers contain nitrogen compounds, which are also present in some explosives. The Secret Service said it bought Bateman's account. ``The car was declared safe (after) about an hour,'' said Rich Adams, a Secret Service spokesman. ``More than likely it was the residue from the fertilizer.''

DOC.HEAD: Siberian Log Imports Temporarily Banned
DOC.TEXT: A temporary ban has been placed on Siberian log imports because of the threat of introducing agricultural pests into the United States, the Agricultural Department said today. The Soviet Union first shipped Siberian logs to the United States last summer under tightly controlled test conditions, said James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. ``We inspected the logs upon entry and found two potentially harmful pests,'' he said. ``Since then, we have learned that Siberian raw wood can harbor over 100 organisms not native to the United States.'' Based on these findings, Glosser said, further imports of the logs will be put off until more information is available. Glosser said the duration of the ban will depend on the results of a risk assessment, which will examine the possible pest hazards of Siberian log imports to U.S. agriculture. ``We are currently working with regulatory and forestry officials from Oregon, California and Washington, USDA's Forest Service and the timber industry to gather and examine available data on Siberian logs,'' he said. After the assessment is completed in early 1991, Glosser said agency officials will evaluate the need for developing regulations to restrict or prohibit the entry of Siberian logs.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet Politics
DOC.TEXT: Here are some world reactions to the resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. --- ``All of us in the West want to see the Soviet people continue on a track that will lead to full democracy, free enterprise and respect for human rights. But this has to be done in a way that maintains order without sacrificing democratic principles.'' - U.S. Gen. John R. Galvin, NATO's military commander in Europe. --- ``We can only hope that the reforms are carried out. They are good for the Soviet Union and they are good for the relationship between our people and for developments in Europe.'' - German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. --- ``A lot was lost with his departure.'' - Former Hungarian Foreign Minister Gyula Horn. --- ``I hope that this cry of alarm ... will be heard. It will serve as a warning to Western countries and others who are dragging their feet over aid which must be given.'' - French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. --- ``This appeal is more urgent than ever before.'' - German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. --- ``(The resignation) is certainly a sign of the great tension existing at this moment in the USSR and Moscow.'' - Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis of Italy.

DOC.HEAD: Father of Three Wins Shouting Contest
DOC.TEXT: A 36-year-old father of three won a shouting contest Thursday with a roar louder than apassing train. ``If YOU want a war, YOU go!'' Yoshihiko Kato shouted. The sound meter registered 115.8 decibels, more than 15 percent louder than the racket of a train passing overhead on an elevated railroad. For that, the self-employed Kato, who admitted he probably built up his voice shouting at his children, won the $750 grand prize of the 10th Annual Halls Year-End Loud Voice Contest. Kato didn't explain the content of his yell. Some thought it was directed against the Japanese government, which has heeded strong opposition and dropped a proposal to send troops to fill non-combat roles in the U.S.-led multinational forces deployed against Iraq. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, however, was a target of some of the 54 contestants, who were watched by a few hundred chuckling shoppers during lunch hour at a Tokyo shopping center. The sponsors, who make cough drops, asked contestants to shout their feelings about what happened in 1990 in keeping with the Japanese custom of ``toshi wasure,'' or forgetting the past year. They challenged the shouters to top a ringing telephone (70 decibels) or, if possible, damage a few ears (150 decibels). Hiroshi Okawa, 32, pocketed the $225 second prize with the 114.2-decibal plea, ``The day after a typhoon I crashed my car and I want the money to get it repaired.'' Kazuo Kazama, 28, won the $150 third prize with a cheer for his favorite race horse: ``Go Oguri!'' Yoshihiro Yamanashi, 30, drew chuckles when he bellowed, ``President (Saddam) Hussein, please pay my gasoline bill!'' Takeshi Oohashi, 23, who said he has never had a girlfriend, shouted, ``I want a girlfriend! I'll do anything to get one!''

DOC.HEAD: India's Longest Criminal Trial Ends After 33 years
DOC.TEXT: A court cquitted four men of fraud after a 33-year trial that cost the state more than 130 times the amount the men were accused of appropriating, newspapers reported Thursday. ``This trial is the biggest waste of public time and money,'' Judge V.B. Gupta was quoted as saying Wednesday in The Hindu daily. News reports said the case was the longest criminal trial ever recorded in India. India's judicial system is well known for its slowness. Civil suits can sometimes drag on for decades, and all courts, including the Supreme Court, have a backlog of hundreds of cases. The trial began in 1957, two years after four employees of a state-run transport company were accused of buying spurious motor parts, which led to a loss by the company of some $4,500. One of the acquitted men, J.M. Kochar, is now 82 and was the general manager of the now-defunct Madhya Bharat Roadways. His co-defendants were R. M. Banthiya, 71, a former store manager, and S.N. Murteja, 62, and J.K. Batra, 63, former storekeepers in the company. The newspaper quoted Judge Gupta as saying the prosecution failed to prove the fraud charges despite the 33 years of hearings. He said over the years the cost of the trial mounted to a total of $588,235. ``Here is a case where the mighty state with all the enormous resources...has fought this case for more than three decades against the aged citizens who have already suffered much more punishment than deserved even if the present case would have resulted in conviction,'' Gupta said. As the trial dragged on, only 12 of the 64 witnesses cited by the prosecution ever testified and 16 others died, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Maldives Deports Tamil Mercenaries
DOC.TEXT: The Maldives government on Thursday deported 33 Tamil mercenaries convicted of a 1988 coup attempt, diplomats and officials said. The mercenaries were sent to Sri Lanka aboard a scheduled Air Lanka flight, airport officials said. Upon arrival, they were driven away in heavily guarded police vehicles, the officials said. Police said the mercenaries are among 68 Sri Lankan citizens of Tamil origin sentenced to life in prison for the attempted coup, which was crushed by Indian forces. At least 15 people were killed in the coup attempt. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne had earlier told journalists that the Tamil mercenaries ``will be dealt with under the law.'' Wijeratne did not disclose what action the Sri Lankan government would take. A spokesman in the Maldivian Embassy in Colombo said the 33 Tamils were deported under a mutual arrangement between the two island countries separated by 450 miles of sea. He said the remaining 35 mercenaries also will be deported to Sri Lanka. The Maldives, a string of 1,190 small islands in the Indian Ocean with a population of 200,000, had no prisons and no standing army until the 1988 coup - the first in its history. The Maldives government said the Tamils had been hired by President Maumoon Abdul Gayoom's political rivals. Gayoom has been criticized for forbidding the creation of opposition parties.

DOC.HEAD: Minor Earthquake Hits Indiana
DOC.TEXT: A minor earthquake rattled Central Indiana residents this morning, but no injuries or damage were reported. Scientists at the National Earthquake Center in Golden, Colo., said the temblor registered 3.4 on the Richter scale and was centered 30 miles southwest of Indianapolis. Terry Stigall of the Indiana University Geological Survey said the quake lasted about 25 seconds. She said it didn't appear related to the New Madrid fault zone, which reaches into southern Indiana. Today's quake was the second to hit Indiana this week. On Monday, a temblor registering 3.0 on the Richter scale shook a nearby area of west-central Indiana. ``We had calls from Martinsville (and) Indianapolis that they felt a shaking, and calls from Greencastle where they felt a sharp thump,'' said John Hill of the university's Geological Survey. ``Where a sharp thump occurs, that would indicate close proximity to the epicenter. ``There were no reports of damage anywhere in the state.'' Ross Allee of Greencastle, near the quake's center, was startled by the quake. ``It shook my building pretty hard. It was like a bomb went off,'' he said. Merle Coffman of Greencastle said the temblor ``felt like a ripple across my floor.'' The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of magnitude 3.5 can cause slight damage.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Blasts Army Jeep, 4 Soldiers, 7 Civilians Injured
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded Thursday alongside a military jeep escorting an army bus, injuring 11 people, including four soldiers, a police spokesman said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but police suspected the Basque separatist organization ETA. The explosion sent shrapnel flying across the intersection of streets in this eastern city, the police spokesman said. Most injured were not seriously hurt, he said on condition of anonymity. ETA seeks independence from Spain for the three-province northern Basque region and has killed more than 650 people in attacks since 1968 aimed at reaching that goal. So far this year, ETA has claimed responsibility for killing 25 people. The police spokesman said the car bomb apparently had targeted the army bus, which picks up soldiers each morning in central Valencia to take them to work. But the main force of the explosion hit a military jeep escorting the bus, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Plan Could Get 60,000 Palestinians Fired
DOC.TEXT: Economics Minister David Magen said Thursday he has won wide government backing for a plan under which tens of thousands of Palestinians would lose their jobs in Israel. There are now 108,000 Palestinians from the occupied lands working in Israel. Under Magen's plan, nearly two-thirds of them would lose their jobs. The plan is designed to free jobs for Soviet Jewish immigrants and cut the number of Palestinians coming to Israel at a time of increased Arab attacks on Jews, said Magen adviser Eldad Halachmi. Such attacks have been urged by leaders of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Last week, three Jews were stabbed to death inside an Israeli factory, and the Moslem fundamentalist group Hamas claimed responsibility. ``Employers now prefer Jewish workers instead of Arabs because of the recent violence. There is a lot of apprehension and fear,'' said Yossi Ahimeir, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Magen's plan calls for strict enforcement of labor laws that have been ignored in the past, requiring Israeli businesses to employ only Arabs with work permits and pay them the minimum wage. Some Palestinians hailed the plan as a first step toward economic autonomy from Israel, but others warned that it would spell disaster for the occupied lands. Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza observed a general strike Thursday called by pro-PLO uprising leaders to protest the ``Judaization of Jerusalem'' -the settlement of Jews in the eastern Arab part of the city captured in the 1967 war. In a related development, three left-wing legislators alleged the government was funneling million of dollars to Jewish settlers seeking to buy property in the Moslem Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City, the Jerusalem Post reported. The legislators asked for a halt to the transfers until it was determined if they were legal. The Old City is part of east Jerusalem, which Israel annexed after its capture from Jordan. Western countries do not recognize Israel's sovereignty over the area, and the United States has recently demanded that U.S. aid not be used to settle immigrants in east Jerusalem. Of the 108,000 Palestinians working at menial jobs in Israeli construction, manufacturing and agriculture, about 70,000 don't have work permits. It is unlikely Israelis will continue to employ as many Arabs if they must have work permits, meaning they must receive the minimum wage and such benefits as pensions and health insurance. An inter-ministerial committee headed by Magen's office recommended raising fines for employers from $250 to $1,000 for each violation of labor laws, along with an extra fine of $450 for each day an illegal worker is employed, Halachmi said. Magen told Israel radio on Thursday that the plan won approval this week from all ministries involved. It now has to go to the Cabinet for formal approval. Magen said he expected about 60,000 Palestinians to lose their jobs as a result of the new restrictions. Palestinian economist Fawaz Abu Sitta said layoffs would have disastrous consequences in the impoverished Gaza Strip, where 70 percent of the 750,000 people are refugees. About 65,000 Gazans, or half the local labor force, are employed in Israel, including 40,000 working without permits, Abu Sitta said. ``There is little chance that those fired will find new jobs in Gaza,'' he said. Abu Sitta said several Gaza laborers have reported being turned away at an army checkpoint at the entrance to Israel in recent days after they could not produce work permits. The situation in the West Bank is only slightly better than in Gaza. Palestinians have charged that Israel has systematically hampered economic development in both territories to safeguard a pool of cheap Arab labor and create a captive market for Israeli goods. Palestinian journalist Daoud Kuttab said the Magen plan was a positive step toward Palestinian autonomy. ``It might be a bit too quick, and it's going to cause a lot of hardship, but it's going to lead to economic separation, which we hope will be at the forefront of a political separation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Resigns, Blames Soviet Reactionaries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11-12 graf, `The White...gulf ciris.' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Baker's praise for Shevardnadze. Pickup 13th, `Shevardnadze's resignation...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY15,22,25 MOSB4,6,7, LON2
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze resigned without warning today, telling parliament that a reactionary resurgence threatened the Soviet Union with dictatorship. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he was stunned by the resignation of his longtime ally. ``Dictatorship is coming,'' Shevardnadze told the parliament, his voice choked with emotion. ``No one knows what kind of dictatorship it will be, what kind of dictator will come, and what order things will take.'' Hard-liners have been pushing Gorbachev to declare a state of emergency in troubled areas of the country, and he is asking the Congress of People's Deputies legislature to amend the constitution to further strengthen his power. Gorbachev took the podium hours later and said that before the resignation he had planned to make Shevardnadze his vice president, under a government reorganization that would put more power under presidential control. He did not say whether he still considered Shevardnadze for the job. Speaking slowly and calmly, Gorbachev said: ``I don't want either to simplify the situation or overdramatize it. The main thing is not to fall into panic or, even worse, hysteria.'' ``I personally condemn'' Shevardnadze for abandoning the perestroika reform program during a difficult time, the Soviet president said. Gorbachev said he knew nothing about any attempt to establish a dictatorship, but told deputies such a condition could arise if the country continued to sink into disorder. Immediately after Gorbachev spoke, parliamentarians voted 1,540-52, with 11 abstentions, to ask Shevardnadze to stay in the job. Gorbachev said he had spoken with Shevardnadze shortly after his speech to persuade him not to quit. But Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vitaly Churkin, said the resignation was ``irreversible.'' He said Shevardnadze would remain in the job until the Congress session ends next week, when a new foreign minister would be chosen. There was immediate speculation that Deputy Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov, an Arab speciaist who has been Gorbachev's personal envoy to the Persian Gulf, was a possible successor. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who had forged a close working relationship with Shevardnadze on issues ranging from arms control to the gulf crisis, said he forsaw no change in U.S. and Soviet relations. Baker also warmly praised Shevardnadze. ``On a personal note, let me state that I've known Eduard Shevardnadze to be a man of his word, a man of courage, conviction and principle,'' the secretary of state said during a news conference at the State Department. ``I'm convinced that he is committed to peaceful reform, political and economic, in the Soviet Union. ``And I'm also convinced that the dramatic moves toward democratization and freedom in Central and Eastern Europe and the new thinking in Soviet foreign policy would never have happened without his and President Gorbachev's courageous leadership.'' Shevardnadze was to have participated in a Feb. 11-13 summit on arms control and other issues with the United States in Moscow. Shevardnadze's resignation also provoked concern around the world over the future course of the Soviet Union and Gorbachev's reforms. Germany and France, in particular, appealed urgently for an international effort to bolster Gorbachev's reform program with financial aid. Shevardnadze's unexpected announcement could deal a serious blow to Gorbachev, who has been asking for stronger powers to keep his ethnically diverse nation together and make the daunting transition to a market economy. Shevardnadze, waving his finger at lawmakers, blamed what he called reactionary forces for pushing the president to take dictatorial steps, but he also implied Gorbachev was acceding to their demands. The white-haired Georgian and second most visible figure in Soviet politics decried the influence of hard-line lawmakers ``with colonels' shoulder-stripes'' in the Congress, the country's highest legislative body. ``I express my great gratitude to Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev,'' he said. ``I am his friend. I think as he does, I have always supported and will until my last day support the ideas of perestroika, the idea of renewal, the ideas of democratization.'' ``But I think that resignation is my duty as a person, a citizen, a Communist,'' he said, declaring that ``the future belongs to democracy and freedom.'' Gorbachev has asked the Congress to streamline the executive branch to replace the Council of Ministers with several bodies under direct presidential control. He also has said stronger emergency steps may be needed. Earlier this year, he received sweeping emergency powers to ensure economic reform. But Shevardnadze, giving what he called ``one of the shortest and saddest speeches of my life,'' urged Congress not to approve measures that he said would give Gorbachev dictatorial rights. ``When you push the (voting) button, you decide the fate not only of Gorbachev but of perestroika and democracy,'' Shevardnadze said. Shevardnadze, 62, played an integral role in revolutionizing Soviet foreign policy since being appointed in 1985 by Gorbachev, who this year won the Nobel Peace Prize for his policy successes abroad. Shevardnadze was named foreign minister four months after Gorbachev became Communist Party chief in March 1985. He helped steer Soviet foreign policy away from confrontation and conquest in favor of appeasement and coexistence. Under Shevardnadze, the Soviet Union pulled out of Afghanistan and began negotiating huge cuts in nuclear weapons stockpiles. It also let East European countries oust hard-line Communist leaders without Soviet intervention, and reversed antagonistic relations with most Cold War enemies. But the ``new thinking'' policy, long resisted by hard-liners in government, has come under attack in recent weeks by right-wing lawmakers opposed to Soviet involvement in the gulf. Shevardnadze repeated that the government would not send Soviet soldiers to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, which it invaded on Aug. 2. Hard-line members of Congress have urged Gorbachev to declare emergency rule in unstable republics, and the Soviet leader has said he would not hesitate to do so. In his speech, Shevardnadze said sardonically that hard-liners ``have been able to remove the interior minister and now it's time to settle scores with the foreign minister,'' the official Tass news agency reported. The interior minister was replaced earlier this month with a former KGB officer after hard-line deputies demanded he be replaced for not cracking down hard enough on independence movements.

DOC.HEAD: Former Minnesota Gov. Karl Rolvaag Dead at 78
DOC.TEXT: Former Minnesota Gov. Karl Rolvaag, who was elected 28 years ago by the narrowest margin in state history, died today at age 78. He had been seriously ill the last month w state switched from two-year terms to four-year terms in 1962 for its constitutional officers. Rolvaag had served as lieutenant governor for eight years before running for governor in 1962. He was regarded as a long-shot candidate but pulled off an upset when the DFL unveiled what they called the ``Highway 35 scandal'' in the campaign's closing days. Republican Gov. Elmer L. Andersen allegedly had hurried construction on Interstate 35 near Sandstone so he could dedicate some bridges during the campaign. They said the concrete was of poor quality. Later investigation showed no major construction faults. Rolvaag was appointed ambassador to Iceland in 1967 by President Johnson after losing his 1966 re-election bid.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Tracks Down Paintings Stolen By Nazis
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-eight French masterpieces seized by the Nazis during World War II, including paintings by Monet, Renoir and Gauguin, have been found in a cupboard at a Berlin museum, a news magazine reported Thursday. This week's cover story in L'Express described how the works - seized from private citizens between 1942-1944 - have been locked away since 1972, their existence known to only a handful of people. According to the magazine, the Department of French National Museums learned the works existed in 1975, but ``was not interested because the works did not come from national collections.'' ``Never did the prestigious department think of consulting its experts or glancing through the catalogues of the artists in question,'' l'Express wrote. The paintings included Claude Monet's ``Route, Effet d'Hiver. Soleil Couchant (Road, Effect. Sunset);'' Eugene Delacroix's ``Jeune Homme (Young Man);'' Auguste Renoir's ``Coco Ecrivant (Coco Writing);'' and Paul Gauguin's ``La Falaise (The Cliff).'' They were examined by l'Express reporters who said they were in excellent condition. Sylvie Poujade, a French museum spokeswoman, told The Associated Press her department learned of the paintings' existence a month ago, when contacted by l'Express reporters. ``We searched our archives and did not find proof that the department had ever received a list of works from Berlin,'' Ms. Poujade said. Ms. Poujade said that French museums are considered ``depositories of state property which they are expected to conseve and display in good condition.'' ``Our role is not to track down or recuperate art works not considered state property. That's the job of other government offices,'' she said. The magazine quoted Lothar Brauner, curator at the Nationalgalerie, in formerly East Berlin, as saying he received the works on May 19, 1972 from an unidentified person claiming to have gotten them from a third party. A legal document drawn up that day shows that the person wished to hand over the paintings ``so that they would be properly preserved until being returned to their rightful owners.'' Brauner said he did not know who the rightful owners were. According to l'Express, French museum authorities were informed the works were in Berlin by the French Foreign Affairs Ministry, itself contacted by East German authorities. L'Express recounted how Brauner and his wife, a restoration expert, locked the paintings in a yellow, wooden armoire and equipped it with a pail of water and a hydrometer to measure the humidity. From time to time, they would take out the paintings and check their condition, the magazine wrote. During the war, the Nazis sought to amass as much art as possible to fulfill Hitler's dream of creating a European arts center in his native Linz, Austria. Several of his aides, including Martin Bormann and Hermann Goring, were also art collectors and rerouted much of the booty into their own hands. In July 1944, the Nazi Party's art unit drew up an inventory of 21,903 art works confiscated since 1940. However, the list did not include the thousands of paintings by Matisse, Chagall, Picasso and Leger and others considered ``degenerate'' or ``too Jewish'' and which were either sold to unscrupulous French and Swiss art dealers or destroyed. L'Express wrote the Jeu de Paume museum in Paris, once the temple of Impressionist art, was used to stockpile seized art works. On May 27, 1943, its interior courtyard was the scene of a giant bonfire in which some 500 paintings by Andre Masson, Joan Miro, Paul Klee, Max Ernst and others went up in smoke as Nazi chief Alfred Rosenberg and armed guards looked on. The magazine also described how the Gestapo got its hands on millions of dollars worth of art works following tips from French police. Based on months of investigative reporting, the magazine accused the collaborationist Vichy government of expecting to profit financially from selling the property confiscated from French Jews, who were later deported to concentration camps.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier on Alert for Saudi Arabia Marries Sweetheart Aboard Cargo Plane
DOC.TEXT: A couple who couldn't find a chapel quickly enough got married aboard a military cargo hauler. ``I've done a lot of these, and in some unusual places before, but never in a C-130,'' said Lt. Col. Jim Price, a California Air National Guard chaplain who performed the ceremony. Staff Sgt. David Higgins and Elizabeth English wed a year earlier than planned after learning that Higgins' medical airlift unit was put on alert for callup to Saudi Arabia last week. The hulking cargo plane became a makeshift church after the couple couldn't find a chapel on short notice. The ceremony took place Wednesday inside a camouflaged hauler on the tarmac of the Channel Islands Air National Guard Base. The groom, a 33-year-old medic, wore a green flight suit. The 23-year-old bride wore white. Asked what it felt like to be married in an airplane, the bride replied: ``What can I say? It was cold.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Small Mississippi Towns Bring Their Soldiers Home for Christmas
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two small towns wanted their Army National Guard unit to come home for Christmas from Fort Stewart, Ga., so they raised $3,600 for bus fare. Quitman and Lucedale, which combined have a population just over 5,000, collected the money for the 786th Transportation Company.
