Its 176 men and women, mostly from those towns and two surrounding counties, have been at Fort Stewart since Nov. 19. The unit is getting petroleum transportation equipment ready for use in Saudi Arabia, and is scheduled to ship out to the Persian Gulf early next month. ``They could get a 72-hour pass for Christmas if they could show they had a way home,'' said Archie Duke, chief of the volunteer fire department in Quitman. Duke's department shipped the money to the unit Monday and is already close to collecting what it needs to replace the fire funds. ``We're getting it back with quarters, dollars, fives, tens and twenties,'' Duke said. ``But it's coming in.'' Lucedale banker Phyllis Allen said her town has raised $1,100 more than the bus fare needed and will spend the rest buying meals for the company or helping Quitman if necessary. Lucedale's radio station and newspapers helped spread the word, and some businesses matched employee contributions, Allen said. Some of the reservists could not have paid their own fare, she said. ``Many of them haven't had a paycheck since November. It puts a hardship on some of their families,'' she said. ``I told my son not to worry about it, we'd get them home.''

DOC.HEAD: West Gets Deadly Cold, Snow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with new temperature readings, quote from stranded traveler, school closings in Iowa, Minnesota and Arizona, conditions in Colorado, new snowfall total in North Dakota; EDITS to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SE1
DOC.TEXT: Wicked weather wrapped the West in snow and deadly cold today, dropping wind-chill readings to nearly 80 below zero in the northern Rockies and bringing a blizzard to Southern California. Seattle dug out from under a rare heavy snowfall as icy temperatures and blinding winds spread south and east. Storm warnings or watches were in effect from the Mexican border to the Canadian line. Temperatures plummeted to 31 degrees below zero in Yellowstone National Park today and 23 below in Cheyenne, Wyo. Snow forecasts ranged from several inches in valley areas to 2 feet at higher elevations. The storms were blamed for at least eight deaths in California, Oregon and Washington since Tuesday. Power lines fell, schools closed, cars skidded off highways and owners of animals were warned to keep pets and livestock indoors. ``Basically, it's Christmas card beautiful, but it drives like hell,'' said Demetrious Deligiorgis of the Northwest Traffic Network, a syndicate that provides traffic reports for Portland, Ore., radio stations. Schools were closed in western Iowa, northeastern Minnesota and north-central Arizona today. Up to a foot of fresh snow was expected in the southern Colorado mountains, heightening the holiday mood at the state's ski resorts. But a Salvation Army truck touring downtown Denver to encourage homeless people to enter shelters met with some resistance. ``That's the hard part, waiting for it to get colder so they're more willing to go to a shelter,'' said Grant Wederski, the truck driver. ``It's called getting the knowledge.'' In Southern California, a blizzard weather forecasters warned about in the Tehachapi Mountains, about 100 miles northwest of Los Angeles, became reality. Eight inches of snow fell in about five hours in the area overnight and drifts were blown by 50 mph winds, said Kern County Deputy Otis Whinery, adding that snow and ice forced numerous road closures. At the Bogus Basin ski area near Boise, Idaho, spokesman Lew Peterson: ``It is dumping, truly snowing like mad.'' Six inches fell in 24 hours. A sandstorm in California's Mojave Desert caused a collision Wednesday between a Greyhound bus and a truck. Forty injuries, mostly minor, were reported. The entire state of Montana was below zero and a wind-chill reading of minus 79 was reported late Wednesday. Kalispell was the hot spot with a high of 6 below. In the snowbound Seattle area, 1,500 schoolchildren were reunited with parents after spending the night at 32 schools when they couldn't get home on buses. Classes were closed for the rest of the week. Thousands spent a second night without power in Washington state, after more than 120,000 homes lost electricity. In Whatcom County on the Canadian border, gusts near 80 mph blew roofs off buildings. On the Puget Sound a marina's docks collapsed under 55 mph winds. Dozens of small boats were destroyed. Freezing weather hampered firefighters in Plentywood, Mont., as they tried to put out a fire at a high school. School buses stood by with heaters running to give firefighters shelter. The cold froze hoses and slowed pumper trucks. Wind chills dipped past 70 below Wednesday in Idaho, where many roads were closed because of blowing snow. A 12-vehicle pileup occurred on Interstate 84 near Boise. In Northern California, wind gusts topped 60 mph. Snow dusted coastal mountains around the San Francisco Bay and above Santa Cruz, which like typically mild Monterey saw temperatures drop into the mid-20s. Another foot of mountain snow was likely today in Utah, where 12 inches fell Wednesday and winds pushed past 60 mph. More heavy snow was reported in the Lake Tahoe area, with up to 2 feet expected overnight. In North Dakota, the cold punch brought up to 7 inches of snow and wind-chill readings of 60 below. Ranchers worked to provide shelter and food for cattle in Nebraska, where wind-chill readings of 59 below were reported today. ``You try to keep them behind something and make sure the ice is chipped out of their water,'' Steve Lattin said. In the only weather-related fatality in Washington, a Bainbridge Island man was killed in his backyard by a falling tree, officials said. Four traffic deaths in Northern California and three in Oregon were blamed on slippery roads.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Shevardnadze Resignation Does Not Mean Policy Change
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with new material and editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's abrupt resignation does not mean a change in Soviet foreign policy. He paid tribute to Shevardnadze's professionalism and said, ``I'm going to miss him.'' White House Press Secretary Marvin Fitzwater called Shevardnadze ``an important figure in the positive evolution of U.S.-Soviet relations,'' and expressed hopes for the relationship to continue. Baker, speaking to reporters hours after the surprise announcement by his Soviet counterpart, said he was pleased to have President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's assurance that foreign policy, which has brought recent progress toward peace and disarmament, would continue on course. Baker, reacting cautiously, said he would not characterize the resignation as a sign that Gorbachev's reforms are coming unraveled. He added he had received no clue in his recent meeting with Shevardnadze that his negotiating partner was considering quitting. ``In my experience, Minister Shevardnadze has always worked as a professional who has served his country's interest,'' Baker said. Shevardnadze was a driving force in the Kremlin's ``new thinking'' abroad and democratization at home, he added. ``I am proud to call this man a friend,'' he said, adding that he had always found his Soviet counterpart ``a man of his word, of courage and conviction.'' Baker reiterated in response to questions that he does not anticipate any change in policy, particularly in the Persian Gulf, where the United States is counting on Soviet backing of the United Nations resolution approving use of force if Iraq fails to withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15. ``This is clearly a critical time for the process of political and economic reform in the USSR. President Bush emphasized our commitment to this process just a few days ago when he expressed his concern that democratization continue,'' Fitzwater said. ``Minister Shevardnadze has been an important figure in the positive evolution of U.S.-Soviet relations over the past few years. We have every reason to want to see that process continue.'' Acknowledging his surprise, Baker said he ``was not notified in advance'' of Shevardnadze's decision, announced in a brief statement to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow. While being careful not to say anything that could be interpreted as interference in Soviet domestic affairs, Baker indicated his personal disappointment at the loss of a man with whom he has conducted intensive negotiations for nearly two years. ``I think that we achieved some significant things in the 23 months that we were able to work together,'' the secretary said. Fitzwater said the U.S. government had no advance notice of Shevardnadze's decision, and the White House had not had any direct discussions with Soviet authorities. Baker and Shevardnadze, working with European negotiators, concluded the recently signed agreement to reduce conventional forces in Europe. They are reported near accord on a treaty to cut long-range nuclear arsenals by 30 percent, a measure Bush hopes to sign at his next summit meeting with Gorbachev scheduled to take place Feb. 11-13 in the Soviet Union. The two foreign ministers also worked to defuse regional conflicts around the world, including the Persian Gulf. Shortly after their meeting in Siberia to discuss arms control issues, Baker learned of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. He broke off a hunting trip to Mongolia in August to fly to Moscow, where he and Shevardnadze issued an extraordinary joint statement calling on Iraq to abandon its aggression.

DOC.HEAD: WHO Urges More Action Against Sexually Transmitted Infections
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization on Thursday urged greater efforts to reduce the estimated 250 million cases of sexually transmitted infections that occur each year. The U.N. agency said although education and medical programs have helped combat the spread of infections such as gonorrhea in industrialized countries, the number of cases in the Third World remains ''unnacceptably high.'' Dr Andre Meheus, a senior WHO official, told a press conference that sexually transmitted infections pose an ``important public health problem,'' and may lead to sterility, infertility, stillbirths, blindness, brain damage, cancer or death. A WHO report said the most common infection is trichomoniasis, a parasitic infestation causing vaginal discharge in women. It estimated there are 120 million cases each year. The report said some 50 million cases of the bacterial infection chlamydia occur worldwide. It said in some U.S. inner city areas, from 10 percent to 30 percent of sexually active young women are infected. Although it does not always produce clear clinical signs, persistent infection can lead to infertility in some women. WHO pointed out that although there are effective treatments for many of the infections, lack of medical infrastructure in developing countries hinders control efforts. The report stressed the need for more health education and prevention programs. It pointed out that in Sweden, where all school children have sex education classes, backed up by clinical services for adolescents, gonorrhea and syphilis have almost disappeared.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
U.S. Joins Security Council Vote Against Deportation Of Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: The United States, declining to shield its Israeli ally, on Thursday supported a Security Council resolution deploring Israel's deportation of Palestinians and calling for U.N. monitoring of their safety. The vote was unanimous among the 15-member council. In a separate, non-binding statement, the council agreed a properly timed and structured international conference should be held to facilitate a lasting peace in the Arab-Israeli conflict. The separate statement was issued by this month's council president, Yemen. The statement also said the Arab-Israeli conflict is unique and must be addressed independently on its own merits, an indirect way of saying there must not be linkage to the Persian Gulf crisis. The U.S. vote was seen as an effort to reinforce Arab commitment to the U.S.-led multinational coalition arrayed against Iraq. A U.S. veto on an issue considered vital to Arabs could have undermined their confidence in the U.S. mission, diplomats said. It was the third time in more than two months that the United States declined to shield Israel from international criticism by exercising its right of veto as a permanent council member. In the past the United States frequently has blocked council efforts to condemn Israel. The council action had been bogged down for about two months, as the United States sought to ensure that there was no linkage between the Arab-Israeli conflict and a settlement of the gulf crisis. The separate, non-binding statement was a compromise intended to keep the two issues apart. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has tried to link the Israeli withdrawal from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to his withdrawal from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Won't Transfer Terrorist to Italian Prison
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department refused Thursday to transfer convicted terrorist Silvia Baraldini to a prison in her native Italy because she is likely to be paroled there from her 43-year U.S. sentence. The department informed Italy by letter of its refusal to transfer Baraldini to an Italian prison under an international convention that allows sentenced criminals to serve time in their native country. Assistant Attorney General Robert S. Mueller III said in the letter that Baraldini's sentence for conspiring to commit a series of terrorist acts in the United States would be considerably if it fell under Italian law. ``The serious and violent nature of the crimes committed by Ms. Baraldini, in our view, demand a sentence commensurate with those imposed by the courts in the United States,'' Mueller said. The Justice Department wants to ensure Baraldini serves a long sentence because ``we believe that, if released, Ms. Baraldini would continue in criminal activities detrimental to the United States.'' Mueller also expressed concern over Italian parole policies that have ``allowed convicted terrorists and organized crime figures to be furloughed or placed on work release after only relatively short periods of incarceration.'' Italy requested a Justice Department review of Baraldini's case under the international convention on the transfer of sentenced prisoners. Baraldini, who came to this country at age 13, retains Italian citizenship. She was convicted in 1983 of being part of a conspiracy by left-wing terrorists to rob armored cars, including a 1981 holdup of a Brinks truck near Nyack, N.Y., that resulted in the death of a guard and two policemen. Baraldini was also convicted of racketeering for her participation in the 1980 armed robbery of an armored truck and the 1979 kidnaping of prison guards to help convicted murderer Joanne Chesimard escape from a New Jersey prison. Baraldini was sentenced to 40 years imprisonment and later received a three-year term for criminal contempt because she refused to answer questions to a grand jury investigating left-wing terrorism. The Justice Department said that it had information Baraldini was still in communication with fellow members of the terrorist May 19th Organization and would assist them if released from prison. Mueller's letter said authorities also had information indicating that Baraldini may have participated in a series of bombings in New York and Chicago by the FALN, a Puerto Rican separatist group. These bombings included a 1975 blast that killed four people in New York, the department said. Mueller said the Justice Department might reconsider its decision if Baraldini expressed remorse for her crimes and cooperated with investigations of terrorist fugitives. ``Alternatively, if we could be assured Ms. Baraldini would serve a sentence in Italy equivalent to that imposed by the judges here, we would, of course, reconsider this decision,'' Mueller said. Baraldini is being held at the Marianna Federal Correctional Institution in Marianna, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Providence Ex-Mayor Can Reassume Office Despite Conviction, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: Flamboyant former Mayor Vincent A. ``Buddy'' Cianci Jr., who's also a convicted felon, again may hold the office to which he was re-elected in November, the state Spreme Court ruled today. The high court's ruling struck down two challenges to his re-election and completed his political comeback. Cianci is scheduled to be inaugurated Jan. 7. Chief Justice Thomas F. Fay dissented in the 4-1 voted, but the two-page order provided no reasons. The order said a more detailed decision would be filed later but gave no time. ``I'm happy that they allowed the people's voices to be heard. It's now time to bring this city together. I intend to be the best mayor the city ever had,'' said the mayor-elect, a former Republican who ran as an independent. His previous administration, spanning 1975 to 1984, was marked by widespread corruption. Lawyers argued the case before the high court Monday. Frederick Cass, a lawyer for those who had challenged Cianci's right to hold office, said he would not pursue the matter further. ``There is no next step,'' Cass said. Although Cianci's lawyers had threatened to take the matter to federal court if he lost, Cass said state issues were involved and he saw no federal jurisdiction. Cianci, who was forced from office in 1984 by a felony assault conviction, won the Nov. 6 election by 317 votes over two challengers. Two groups of citizens challenged Cianci's right to hold office under a 1986 state constitutional amendment that prohibits felons from running for office until three years after they have finished their sentences. Cianci pleaded no contest to charges he used an ashtray and a fireplace log to assault a man he suspected was having an affair with his estranged wife. Cianci was given five years' probation. His challengers asserted that meant he could not run for office until 1992. Cianci's lawyers argued that the constitutional amendment could not be applied to past convictions. In Rhode Island, a no-contest plea is considered a conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Monroe-Miller Marriage Certificate Sold at London Auction
DOC.TEXT: The Jewish marriage certificate of Marilyn Monroe and Arthur Miller was sold Thursday in London for $13,700, auctioneers Christie's said. The ketubah, a printed and framed marriage certificate with a decorated border in the style of a medieval manuscript, was sold by the executors of Miss Monroe's estate and bought by an unidentified American. The marriage between one of America's most famous movie stars and the intellectual playwright in Katonah, N.Y., on July 1, 1956, received worldwide publicity. Miss Monroe was given away by actor and teacher Lee Strasberg, who signed the certificate as a witness. The other witness was Miller's brother, Kermit. The marriage ceremony took place after Miss Monroe received instruction in the Jewish faith by Rabbi Robert Goldberg. The certificate reads: ``In accordance with the rite of Israel and in compliance with the law of the State of New York...'' The couple flew to England for their honeymoon. At the same auction Thursday, a bullwhip used by Harrison Ford in his Indiana Jones movies was bought for $24,300 by French restaurant owner Michel Axel who said, ``I would have paid anything for it.'' Axel said he will display the 9-foot, kangaroo-hide whip in his City Rock Cafe in Paris, alongside Elvis Presley's Cadillac and Michael Jackson's gloves. Axel had to compete against other bidders who took the price well above the autioneers' top estimate of $9,600. Ford, who plays an archaeology professor in the movies, donated the whip to the Institute of Archaeology of London University, which had appealed for funds for a building renovation. A worn black-leather wallet that belonged to film star James Dean was bought for $1,160 by an unidentified European. It formerly belonged to Hollywood stuntman Bill Hickman and then to actor Steve Rowland. The wallet had Dean's name stamped inside in gilt lettering and a photograph of him with actress Kathleen Case at Santa Barbara racetrack, two months before Dean died in a car wreck in 1955.

DOC.HEAD: No Change in Gulf Policy, Soviet Spokesman Says
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze defended himself against conservative criticism of his foreign policy in his resignation speech Thursday, denying that he planned to send Soviet troops to the Persian Gulf. ``No one is planning to send there even one soldier, even one representative of the armed forces of the U.S.S.R.,'' Shevardnadze said. But he said that ``if the interests of the Soviet people suffer, if even one person suffers, no matter where it happens, not only in Iraq, the Soviet nation and the Soviet government will defend the interests of its citizens.'' The Soviet Union has been highly critical of the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, a close Kremlin ally, and has supported a U.S.-sponsored United Nations resolution allowing the use of force if Baghdad does not pull out by Jan. 15. The cooperation between the superpowers has been closer than on any other issues since World War II. The Kremlin, however, has refused to send its own forces to the gulf. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the current Soviet policy on the gulf ``responds to the interests of our people'' and said he hoped it would not change under Shevardnadze's successor. In his resignation speech to the Congress of People's Deputies, Shevardnadze bristled and appeared exasperated at suggestions that lawmakers adopt a resolution forbidding the leadership from sending troops to the gulf, labeling such calls ``the last straw.'' ``Some of the speakers say that the Minister of Foreign Affairs has plans to deploy troops to the Persian Gulf,'' Shevardnadze said. ``I have explained, I have said that we have no plans. They do not exist.'' ``Again, somebody needs this (explanation). Again this question, this problem arises. And I know it will arise in the lobby of the Congress,'' he said. Shevardnadze said the Soviet Union has ``very good, friendly relations with Iraq, which have been built for years, and these relations are still preserved, but we do not have any moral right to agree to the aggression by Iraq, to the annexation of a very small country which cannot defend itself.'' ``Then we would have crossed out everything that has been done in recent years by all our people in the sphere of establishing the principles of new political thinking,'' he said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin, speaking later Thursday, said Shevardnadze believed the foreign policy enacted in the name of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would continue under the next foreign minister. Asked about the gulf policy, Churkin said that the Foreign Ministry was convinced that ``this course, this policy responds to the interests of our people.'' ``We hope that this main orientation will not be changed, and I would like to stress that the guarantee of this is that this policy is associated first of all with the name of our president, Mikhail Gorbachev,'' Churkin said. Asked whether there would be any changes in Soviet policy toward Washington and February's scheduled summit, Churkin underscored Shevardnadze's contributions in establishing good relations with the United States. ``We would wish that this steady process of enlargement and improvement in our relations with the United States ... should continue and develop,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Saddam will `Get His Ass Kicked' in Event of War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with new material, editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush told members of Congress today Saddam Hussein must be made to realize ``he's going to get his ass kicked'' if the United States goes to war against Iraq, a lawmaker said. Emerging from a White House meeting, Rep. Elton Gallegly, R-Calif., quoted Bush as saying he was convinced the Iraqi leader does not understand what he is up against. ``The greatest potential for preventing any kind of an armed confrontation is to make sure that Saddam Hussein be made really aware that, to quote him (Bush), that `If we get into an armed situation, he's going to get his ass kicked','' Gallegly said. Bush's remark was confirmed by another person at the meeting. The president met with a delegation of lawmakers just back from the Persian Gulf. Rep. Anthony C. Beilenson, D-Calif., said military commanders told them ``they were able to do the job, if asked to'' to drive Iraq out of Kuwait with force. ``But nobody was suggesting over there, I think that it could be done terribly quickly or terribly easily or that there wouldn't be some casualties,'' the congressman said. Meanwhile, the White House joined the Pentagon in trying to blunt a general's warning that U.S. ground troops in the Persian Gulf might not be ready to fight Iraq by the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. ``It never hurts to build in a little uncertainty about what our intentions are as it relates to Jan. 15,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. He said the warning by Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller ``doesn't cause us any grief.'' On another matter, Fitzwater said the White House would welcome approval by Congress of a resolution along the lines of the U.N. measure authorizing the use of force against Iraq. On the other hand, he said Bush always tells lawmakers, ``If you're going to debate this for months and not reach a conclusion and argue about it, then that may not be that helpful, or if you're going to water it down ...'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, who returned Thursday with a seven-member Democratic delegation from seven days in the Middle East, said the group had sought to quash any notion that debate in Congress means U.S. divisions over Bush's announced policy. ``We made it clear that whatever the debate about timing and strategy and tactics in the gulf, the United States is united behind the policy that assures that Saddam Hussein and Iraqi forces must leave Kuwait,'' Mitchell said. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said the trip had led to changes of views for some of the senators, and said the group now agreed that military force must be used to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait if all else fails. The administration also moved to blunt criticism in Congress about the contributions of U.S. allies in the Persian Gulf. Officials said allies have spent more than $9 billion for the American-led military showdown with Iraq and ``the support is there.'' Some lawmakers have accused Germany and Japan - wealthy nations dependent on oil imports - of letting the United States shoulder the financial and military burden of the Persian Gulf crisis. Sen. Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., said Saudi Arabia was reaping a windfall profit of about $150 million a day in increased oil sales and have contributed only $987 million in cash and material - equivalent to about 6.5 days' worth of those profits. Sasser, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said Japan had pledged $4 billion to the gulf effort and had paid $374 million through Nov. 30. Germany, he said, had offered $900 million and paid $330 million. The White House said it was not disturbed by the pace of the contributions. ``We're confident that the money will be there,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``The support is there. The leaders have all made their commitment to us. And we don't think there is any special problem there.'' Fitzwater on Wednesday also distanced the White House from predictions that any war with Iraq would be over quickly. Sens. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, and Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, said U.S. military commanders in the Middle East indicated a war could be wrapped up within five days. They said they got that impression during classified and other briefings during their tour of Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Egypt and Israel. Asked about their predictions, Fitzwater said, ``We would be most reluctant to try and put numbers of days on it.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon To Saddam: We Can Still Bomb You Jan. 15
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, Cheney spokesman, to UPDATE with new Fitzwater comment; SUBS 14th graf pvs, At the, to delete first reference to Fitzwater.
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon warned Saddam Hussein today that U.S. air power will be ready to attack Iraq by Jan. 15 - even if all ground forces are not ready for war by that U.N.-imposed deadline for him to withdraw from Kuwait. The statement came from a top aide to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney the morning after a senior U.S. commander here raised eyebrows by saying American ground troops might not be ready to fight Iraq until a month or more past the United Nations deadline - and that he would urge President Bush not to order any attack until the full U.S. deployment was ready for war. Cheney spokesman Pete Williams said Cheney ``was not displeased'' by Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller's candid assessment. At the White House, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Waller's comment ``doesn't cause us any grief.'' ``It never hurts to build in a little uncertainty about what our intentions are as it relates to Jan. 15,'' Fitzwater said. Still, today's statement by Williams and other comments by senior military officers here appeared clearly designed to give the deadline more teeth to counter any interpretation of Waller's remarks as possibly undermining Bush's demand that Saddam meet the deadline or risk attack. Williams said Cheney would not reach a conclusion on the readiness of U.S. troops until the end of his five-day trip here and would not, as Waller did, share with reporters his advice to Bush. But Williams said not having all ground forces fully ready for combat did not mean the American-led forces deployed against Iraq could not initiate hostilities to free Kuwait. ``The air part of the force, for example, reaches its level of readiness earlier than the others,'' Williams said. And the three-star officer in charge of Army forces here, Lt. Gen. John Yeosock took a far more aggressive posture than Waller, saying: ``I'm ready today for whatever mission I'll be called upon to perform. ... My perspective is, `Saddam get out of Kuwait or be prepared to face the consequences.''' If war erupts, Yeosock said, ``We will do everything in our power to apply maximum power in minimum time to maintain the highest up-tempo battle ever recorded.'' Speaking privately, a senior Pentagon official agreed that Waller went well beyond Cheney and other senior military officials in discussing the U.S. deployment. But this official said Saddam should not interpret Waller's remarks as an extension of the Jan. 15 deadline, from a military standpoint. ``This ain't no break for Saddam Hussein,'' the official said. Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, were in daylong meetings today with senior American and Saudi commanders. They met Wednesday with Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah and over dinner with Prince Sultan, Cheney's Saudi counterpart. In his blunt remarks Wednesday, Waller, second in command of Operation Desert Shield, said American troops might not be ready until well into February and that if asked by Bush to launch an attack sooner his answer would be: ``No. I'm not ready to do the job.'' Fitzwater brushed aside Waller's appraisal of the troops' readiness. ``What he really said is they might not be as ready as they would like to be ... for all the contingencies,'' Fitzwater said. ``We are assured they will be ready to do whatever they are called upon to do.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, asked today about Waller's comments, said one of the important principles he learned in the Marine Corps was that ``it is critical to preserve the element of surprise.'' Other officers in Saudi Arabia said Waller's remarks might undermine diplomatic efforts that center on convincing Saddam he must comply with the deadline or risk a U.S.-led attack. Cheney fired Gen. Michael Dugan as Air Force chief of staff in September after Dugan talked openly of the likelihood of bombing certain Iraqi military and economic targets if hostilities began. ``We supposedly want Saddam to take this deadline seriously, don't we?'' said one officer who demanded anonymity. He and another officer expressed concern that Waller's remarks could be interpreted by Saddam to render meaningless the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations for Iraq's complete withdrawal from Kuwait. But Waller said, ``What is so magic, why does it have to be that on Jan. 15th we must be ready to go and initiate hostilities at midnight on the 16th? ``I would say to the president and the secretary as well as to the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff that until our full complement of forces are on the ground that we should not initiate hostile activities,'' he said. Waller said some crucial heavy ground forces likely will not arrive in Saudi Arabia by the deadline. The three-star general said he believed Bush was aware of the readiness timetable and would not order an attack until ground commanders said they were ready. Other senior military officials, however, said even if that was the case Waller should not be discussing the readiness of U.S. troops publicly, particularly less than a month before the deadline. Bush said Monday that U.N. resolutions against Iraq, which include one authorizing force if Iraqi troops aren't out of Kuwait by Jan. 15, should be enforced ``right on schedule.'' Baker has been pressing allies to be ready to use force if Saddam ignores the deadline. Waller said several vital components still were missing, including Navy carriers due to leave home port just after Christmas, combat aircraft due to arrive by Jan. 15, and about 117,000 armor troops coming from Fort Riley, Kan., and from Germany. Even if those troops do arrive by the U.N. deadline, he said, ``there's a distinct possibility that every unit will not be fully combat-ready until sometime after the first of February.''

DOC.HEAD: Faced with Troubles at Home, Soviet Jews Flee to Germany
DOC.TEXT: Nearly a half-century after the Nazi Holocaust, Jews fleeing the Soviet Union are looking to Germany as a land of opportunity, with many heading to the newly united country rather than the United States or Israel. They have been pouring into Berlin in growing numbers this week, in an effort to beat a decision expected Friday that many fear will tighten rules on their entry into Germany. Since Monday, about 125 Jews have arrived each day, compared with a total of 350 in the first half of the month, according to Berlin city officials. The new arrivals cite anti-Semitism as the main reason for leaving the Soviet Union, which for months has been riddled with rumors of possible pogroms against Jews. Israeli media reported Thursday that panic has spread among the Soviet Jews and they are trying to leave their homeland by all the means available. The accounts gave no reason for the reported panic and did not say when it started. ``I am afraid of the situation of the Jews in the Soviet Union,'' said one woman in Berlin, who identified herself only as Ina. ``People discuss Jews on Moscow's streets and in buses.'' Asked to summarize the remarks, she said: ``When the situation is difficult, they try to get the people they think are responsible. And they say the Jews are responsible.'' Ina stood in line with more than 30 other Soviet Jews Thursday at a counseling center in a mammoth, Communist-era building in former East Berlin. Many of the newcomers clustered together, nervously discussing the latest snatches of information gleaned from their German surroundings and the language almost none of them understood. ``Everyone has been very friendly, starting with the doorman,'' Ina said in English, which she said she learned at a Moscow foreign language institute. Because it is the first major German city on rail lines from the east, Berlin is the first stop off for most of the arriving Soviet Jews. Once there, they face a round of questions to make sure they are Jews. On Thursday, families sat together on well-worn benches waiting to be called into the cramped counseling rooms. There, they would be given an orientation before being sent to refugee housing centers. One refugee center is a building that once belonged to the dreaded East German secret police. Between 2,000 and 4,000 Soviet Jews have already reached Germany this year, according to Michel Friedman, a spokesman for Frankfurt's Jewish community. He says many arrived in East Germany without a visa before unification Oct. 3, making it difficult to establish a precise figure. Along with hundreds of thousands of refugees from dozens of other countries, the Soviet Jews are straining Germany's social services. The Jews are given shelter in Berlin before being sent to other parts of the country. Friday's meeting, in Munich, of the governors of Germany's 16 states is aimed at adopting new regulations to provide for the orderly entry of Soviet Jews. But many of the current refugees reaching Berlin say they are worried that the new rules will keep them out. As a result, German Jewish leaders have appealed to government leaders for a ``generous'' quota for Soviet Jews, saying Germany has a moral responsibility to take them in because of the Nazi Holocaust, in which more than 6 million Jews perished. ``As hundreds of thousands of other people, whom I have nothing against, are accepted in Germany, there is also the political and moral duty to help these Jewish people in their acute distress,''said Heinz Galinski, a survivor of the Auschwitz death camp and president of Germany's Central Council of Jews. The newly arriving Soviet Jews cite rising anti-Semitism as their many reason for leaving the Soviet Union. ``I had problems at my job,'' said 25-year-old Jan Stelmakh from the Soviet Asian city of Ashkhabad in the Turkmenistan republic. ``They wanted to fire me because I am Jewish.'' Stelmakh, who worked as an archeologist in a government history institute, left behind his wife and 2-month-old daughter when he fled. He said he hopes they will be able to join him in Germany. Another refugee summed up her concerns about Jews in the Soviet Union in three words of halting German. ``Alles nicht gut (all not good),'' she said, then broke into tears. Even in their new refuge, the newcomers face occasional anti-Semitic threats. In Brandenburg outside Berlin last month, three men stormed into a temporary shelter shouting ``Jews out, Jews out!''

DOC.HEAD: Arts Agency Grants $15.6 Million to 37 Groups Around Country
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts announced Thursday it is awarding $15.6 million in long-term grants to support ``exciting, innovative and far-reaching'' projects by 37 arts organizations from Hanover, N.H., to Tacoma, Wash. Every federal dollar spent on the highly competitive, three-year ``challenge grants,'' which range in size from $50,000 to $1 million, must be matched by $3 in new or increased non-federal funds. Construction projects require a 4-1 match. Challenge grants are awarded to ``assist projects of exceptional merit with the potential for benefiting the arts locally and nationally,'' the arts agency said. Million-dollar grants were awarded to New York choreographer Merce Cunningham, public television's ``American Playhouse'' series and the Houston Grand Opera. The smallest grant, $50,000, went to public radio station KLON-FM in Long Beach, Calif., to expand the national audience for its jazz programming. New York City arts organizations were the biggest winners, with nine grants totaling $4,655,000. The next highest total, six grants worth $2,660,000, went to San Francisco, including an $850,000 award to the city's Fine Arts Museums to reinforce the California Palace of the Legion of Honor against earthquake damage. Geographically, the grants ranged from the Dartmouth College Hopkins Center in Hanover, N.H., which received $175,000 to present works by female artists of diverse cultural backgrounds, to the Pantages Center Corp. in Tacoma, Wash., $420,000 to create a downtown performing arts district of three theaters. ``While the projects vary greatly in both size and scope and come from organizations large and small, all of the grant recipients are to be congratulated for developing projects that are exciting, innovative and far-reaching,'' said NEA chairman John E. Frohnmayer. Other recipients included: A Contemporary Theater, Seattle, $200,000; Alabama State Council on the Arts, Montgomery, $250,000; American Federation of Arts, New York, $200,000; Arts Council of New Orleans, $440,000; Baltimore Museum of Art, $400,000; Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra, N.Y., $500,000; California Institute of the Arts, Valencia, $175,000; Charleston (S.C.) Division of Cultural Affairs, $200,000; Dance Bay Area, San Francisco, $100,000; Dance Theater Workshop, National Performance Network, New York, $255,000; Grand Center Inc., St. Louis, $500,000; Guthrie Theater Foundation, Minneapolis, $500,000; Indiana Repertory Theater, Indianapolis, $85,000; Mexican Museum, San Francisco, $110,000; Michigan Council for the Arts, Detroit, $350,000; Museum Education Consortium, New York, $400,000; Museum of Modern Art film department, New York, $825,000; Musical Traditions, Paul Dresher Ensemble, San Francisco, $100,000; National Public Radio, Washington, $750,000; New Freedom Theater, Philadelphia, $500,000; New Haven (Conn.) Symphony Orchestra, $200,000; New Museum of Contemporary Art, New York, $275,000; Chicago Symphony Orchestra, $750,000; Painted Bride, American Festival Project, Philadelphia, $90,000; San Francisco Ballet, $750,000; San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, $750,000; Santa Barbara (Calif.) Contemporary Arts Forum; $60,000; Theatre de la Jeune Lune, Minneapolis, $450,000; Trisha Brown Co., New York, $200,000; Utah Arts Council, Salt Lake City, $750,000.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Anti-Israel Resolution, Separate Statement
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of Security Council Resolution 681, criticizing Israel's plan to deport Palestinians from the occupied territories and giving U.N. staff authority to monitor the situation: The Security Council, Reaffirming the obligations of member states under the United Nations Charter, Reaffirming further the principle of the inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war set forth in Security Council resolution 242 (1967), Having received the report of the secretary-general submitted in accordance with Security Council resolution 672 (1990) on ways and means for ensuring the safety and protection of the Palestinian civilians under Israeli occupation and in particular taking note of paragraphs 20-26 therein (S-21919), Taking note of the interest of the secretary-general to visit and send his envoy to pursue his initiative with the Israeli authorities, as indicated in paragraph 22 of the report of the secretary-general (S-21919), and of their recent invitation extended to him, Gravely concerned at the dangerous deterioration of the situation in all the Palestinian territories occupied by Israel since 1967, including Jerusalem, and at the violence and rising tension in Israel, Taking into consideration the statement made by the president of the Security Council on 20 December 1990 concerning the method and approach for a comprehensive, just and lasting peace in the Arab-Israeli conflict, Recalling its resolutions 607 (1988), 608 (1988), 636 (1989) and 641 (1989) and alarmed by the decision of the government of Israel to deport four Palestinians from the occupied territories in contravention of its obligations under the Fourth Geneva Convention, 1. Expresses its appreciation to the secretary-general for his report contained in document S-21919; 2. Expresses its grave concern over the rejection by Israel of Security Council resolutions 672 (1990) and 673 (1990); 3. Deplores the decision by the government of Israel, the occupying power, to resume deportations of Palestinian civilians in the occupied territories; 4. Urges the government of Israel to accept de jure applicability of the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949, to all the territories occupied by Israel since 1967, and to abide scrupulously by the provisions of the said Convention; 5. Calls on the high contracting parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 to ensure respect by Israel, the occupying power, for its obligations under the Fourth Geneva Convention in accordance with Article 1; 6. Requests the secretary-general in cooperation with the International Committee of the Red Cross to develop further the idea from the report of the secretary-general (S-21919) of convening a meeting of the high contracting parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention and to discuss possible measures that might be taken by them under the Convention and for this purpose to invite these parties to submit their views on how the idea could contribute to the goals of the Convention as well as on other relevant matters and to report to the council; 7. Requests the secretary-general to monitor the observe the situation regarding Palestinian civilians under Israeli occupation, making new efforts in this regard on an urgent basis, and to utilize and designate or draw upon the United Nations and other personnel and resources present there in the area and elsewhere needed to accomplish this task and to keep the Security Council regularly informed; 8. Requests further the secretary-general to submit a first progress report to the Security Council by the first week of March 1991, and every four months thereafter and decides to remain seized of the matter as necessary. --- Here is the text of the non-binding statement on the prospects for a Middle East peace conference: The members of the Security Council reaffirm their determination to support an active negotiating process in which all relevant parties should participate leading to a comprehensive, just and lasting peace to the Arab-Israeli conflict through negotiations which should be based on resolutions 242 (1967) and 338 (1973) of the Security Council and which should take into account the right to security of all states in the region, including Israel, and the legitimate political rights of the Palestinians people. In this context they agree that an international conference, at an appropriate time, properly structured, should facilitate efforts to achieve a negotiated settlement and lasting peace in the Arab-Israeli conflict. However, the members of the Council are of the view that there is not unanimity as to when would be the appropriate time for such a conference. In the view of the members of the Council, the Arab-Israeli conflict is important and unique and must be addressed independently, on its own merits.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Asks U.S. Attorney to Prepare Contempt Charges Against CNN
DOC.TEXT: MIAMI (A) - A federal judge said today he has notified the U.S. attorney's office to represent him in criminal contempt proceedings against CNN for broadcasting Manuel Noriega's taped prison phone calls. Legal scholars have said a contempt hearing could provide a judicial test of whether the government can practice prior restraint on the news media. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler eventually allowed Cable News Network to broadcast the audio tapes after ruling they did not violate Noriega's right to a fair trial. But he announced in a court hearing last week that he intended to press contempt charges against the network if it were found to have defied his initial order banning use of the tape. On Wednesday, he notified U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen to draw up an order asking CNN to show cause why it should not be held in contempt. The network will be allowed to respond in writing, Lehtinen's spokeswoman Diane Cossin said today. A hearing will be set if necessary. Because the order is against CNN and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. as corporations, any penalties would take the form of fines, not jail terms, Ms. Cossin added. Hoeveler said he decided to go forward with the criminal action because the network defied his restraining order without waiting first for the outcome of the legal process. In Atlanta, network spokesman Steve Haworth said: ``CNN is confident that if and when a trial is held on the issue of contempt, its actions will be vindicated.'' The tape at issue involved a conversation between Noriega and an investigator, with a defense attorney's secretary translating. The network broadcast the tape for a day despite Hoeveler's order, but withdrew it when the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta backed the lower court judge. The U.S. Supreme Court refused to involve itself in the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Rights Group Praises Congress, Blasts Administration
DOC.TEXT: A leading civil rights group on Thursday praised the 1990 Congress but said President Bush had continued the ``awful'' record of Ronald Reagan. ``Unfortunately, on issues of race and sex discrimination, the president has so far given virtually a blank check to the right wing,'' said Ralph G. Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights. The group, in a report card on lawmakers in 1990, praised Congress for bills designed to guarantee rights of the disabled and boosting minority hiring by reversing five Supreme Court decisions. It also said Congress deserves credit for measures designed to combat crimes involving bigotry, expand child care, raise the minimum wage, reauthorize the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights and provide payments to Japanese Americans placed in camps after Pearl Harbor. The conference is a coalition of 180 groups representing minorities, women, labor, the disabled and others. It often spearheads civil rights lobbying in Washington. Its chairman is Benjamin L. Hooks, head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``While the Bush administration has regrettably continued the Reagan administration's awful record on issues of race and sex discrimination, the 101st Congress continued the remarkable bipartisan congressional record on civil rights that has characterized the past decade,'' Neas said. He said the major disappointment in Congress from a civil rights perspective was ``the Senate's failure to override by one vote the president's veto of the Civil Rights Act of 1990.'' ``By joining Andrew Johnson and Ronald Reagan as the only presidents in our history to veto a civil rights measure, President Bush has forever stigmatized his presidency,'' Neas said. Bush vetoed the measure saying it would lead employers to adopt racial hiring quotas. Civil rights forces scoff at that notion, saying it would merely restore the law against job discrimination to its status before a complex 1989 Supreme Court decision. Both sides agree that the bill would make it easier for those claiming to be discrimination victims to win in court against employers.

DOC.HEAD: Expatriates Expected to Leave Saudi Border Province Before Jan. 15
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Western women and children are leaving Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province quickly as the U.N. deadline approaches for Iraq to retreat from Kuwait. The U.N. Security Council has approved the use of force if Iraq does not pullout of the neighboring emirate by Jan. 15. That would put Eastern Province residents near or on the battlefield between Iraqi troops and a U.S.-led multinational force. Western residents surveyed at random said 90 percent of the 1,000 British women and children in the province bordering Iraq and Kuwait plan to leave as soon as possible, and those departing on scheduled vacations would not return. Ireland and Sweden on Thursday joined the growing list of nations warning their citizens to leave the region. Hundreds of thousands of foreign workers are among the 2 million people in the region. ``In view of the danger of hostilities, Irish people are strongly advised to send home dependents, especially children,'' said a statement from the Foreign Office in Dublin. On Monday, the British Foreign Office advised all dependents to leave the area by Jan. 15, echoing similar warnings issued by France and other Eropean states. The United States has not changed its advice since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, that leaving was strictly a personal decision. But diplomats said they expect the State Department's advisory to be upgraded within two weeks. Diplomats said there is no immediate danger, but that in the event of war, civilian air traffic would stop immediately and roads would probably quickly be flooded with refugees. It now can take up to three days to get through to a travel agent on the phone. Waiting lists in early January are clogged and many expatriates are shipping family photographs and other valuables home. Tt is difficult to tell how many of the people leaving the region now were prompted to do so by the European governments' travel advisories because the Christmas season is a heavy time of travel. The tempo of daily life has not changed. Many women said they wanted to be near their husbands who work in the Eastern Province, but will take the precaution of moving 600 miles east to the port of Jiddah around Jan. 15. The U.S. civilian community of 12,000 has shrunk to at least 8,000 since the invasion, embassy officials said. Of those about half are women and children. Some companies reacted immediately to the British government's advisory that Britons leave. British Aerospace, which services the Saudi Air Force's Tornado jet fighters, ordered 370 wives and children to be out of the country by Jan. 10 or risk loosing family benefits. ``If there is a conflict in the north it will be impossible for anyone to get away from Dhahran for several days because all international flights will stop,'' said Don MacLean, director of British Aerospace in Saudi Arabia. ``We don't think there is significant danger, but there is a risk.'' Such measures displease the government of the Eastern Province, which stresses that the main urban center around Dhahran is far removed from any direct threat from Saddam Hussein's army. ``We feel that there will be no danger and this (announcement) will cause panic among other nationalities and even Saudis,'' said Hassan Ali Al-Jasser, director of public relations for the Eastern Province. The largest area employer, government-owned Aramco, is not advising anybody to leave. But preparations for a possible war are being made in the region. The Dhahran International Hotel, which serves as headquarters for scores of correspondents, had its first air raid practice on Thursday. Saudi Arabia is scheduled to start testing its urban air raid sirens on Saturday. Americans working here said the U.S. government is reluctant to advise people to leave because the Saudi government depends on U.S. engineers for the most technical aspects of oil production.

DOC.HEAD: Damages for Job Discrimination Victims Barred in California
DOC.TEXT: California's civil rights commission may not award damages for emotional distress or other personal harm caused by job discrimination, the state Supreme Court ruled today. The 5-2 ruling eliminates the Fair Employment and Housing Commission's ability to order damages for bias victims who commonly suffer no losses in salary but sue for the trauma and humiliation caused by employers' mistreatment. Those victims of sexual or racial harassment could still go to court and sue for a full range of damages. But suits are available only to those who can afford a lawyer. The court said the commission was authorized only to order back pay and reinstatement for wrongfully fired employees and to require employers to take steps to prevent future discrimination. In a separate decision today, the court said discrimination victims were not required to file claims with the state before suing in court. The rulings come three years after the court prohibited the same commission from awarding punitive damages in flagrant cases of job discrimination. In that time, the Legislature has passed bills establishing the commission's authority to award both kinds of damages, but Gov. George Deukmejian vetoed them. Today's ruling was based on an interpretation of current state law and left open the possibility that the Legislature could pass a new law allowing the commission to award damages. But the opinion by Justice Edward Panelli hinted that unlimited damage awards by the commission, even if authorized by state law, might be found unconstitutional as a violation of the right to a jury trial. A jury in a court case ``is in the best position to determine just compensation for emotional and mental distress,'' Panelli wrote. The ruling overturned a $20,000 damage award by the commission to Rose Brown, a secretary for the Peralta Community College District in Oakland. She claimed she was fired in April 1981 for refusing sexual advances by an administrator at Laney College.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Keep Tight Grip on Wallets
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Consumers kept a tight grip on their wallets in November, spending just 0.1 percent more than they did in October while their income growth merely matched the 0.3 percent growth in inflation, the government said Thursday. Analysts said they see no immediate improvement. The Commerce Department said spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.73 trillion, up from $3.72 trillion in October. The October total was unchanged from September and was the first month spending had not increased since last May. At the same time, incomes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.71 trillion, up from $4.70 trillion the previous month when they rose 0.5 percent. But the department attributed the income gain solely to an increase in farm subsidies. Excluding those payments, it said, personal income essentially stalled in November. ``That explains why consumers are not spending very much,'' Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm, said. Economist Sandra Shaber of the Futures Group in Washington agreed, saying too much emphasis is being placed on ``the huge plunge in consumer confidence'' for the decline in spending. ``The real reason is much more serious ... and that's that the economy is so weak,'' she said. ``People's purchasing power is being squeezed.'' Squeezed so much that consumers apparently are dipping into their savings. Americans' savings rate - savings as a percentage of disposable income - was 4.0 percent, up from a 3.7 percent rate in October but dow from the 4.6 percent rate for all of 1989. Americans' disposable incomes - incomes after taxes - inched up 0.3 percent after remaining flat the previous month. The spending and income figures were not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, spending actually fell 0.2 percent after a 0.8 percent decline in October, the lowest since a 2.2 percent decrease in January 1987. Disposable incomes, when adjusted for inflation, did not budge from October, when they declined 0.8 percent, the steepest drop since a 1.1 percent decline in April 1989. A key component of the income category - wages and salaries - fell $3.9 billion following a revised $15.3 billion decline the previous month. The October drop was even worse than the $9.3 billion first reported. Spending on durable goods - usually expensive products expected to last at least three years - fell $9.0 billion in November after a $12.8 billion drop in October. Non-durable purchases were up $6.5 billion following a $2.2 billion gain a month earlier. Spending on services rose $5.4 billion, nearly half of the $10.7 billion advance in October.

DOC.HEAD: Condemned Inmate Changes Mind, Gets Last-Minute Stay
DOC.TEXT: A condemned inmate who had asked to die before Christmas changed his mind at the last minute and sought a stay of execution. Carson City District Judge Mike Fondi granted Jimmy Lee Neuschafer the stay Wednesday evening, less than six hours before he was to voluntarily die by lethal injection for killing a fellow convict in 1981, Nevada State Prison spokesman Glenn Whorton said. Neuschafer, 37, already had been taken to a ``last night'' cell near the death chamber and had eaten what was to be his final meal when he contacted his attorneys and asked them to seek the stay. Robert Bryan, a leader of the National Coalition to Abolish the Death Penalty, said he had told Neuschafer on Wednesday that his execution would only make it easier for other executions of inmates who didn't want to die, including some who may be innocent.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Gorbachev Speech to Congress
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Text of a speech by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to parliament on Thursday following the resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Text was translated by The Associated Press: --- I would not like either to simplify the situation, or overdramatize it. It's most important not to fall into panic, and especially hysterics. And not to slip into accusations that will make us all feel ashamed tomorrow. The situation that has emerged is really very serious. It really is the culmination - a certain, so to speak, situation has emerged here, that, in fact, we ought to try and understand. First of all, we found it possible, necessary and expedient that comrades (Prime Minister Nikolai) Ryzhkov, (KGB chief Vladimir) Kryuchkov and Shevardnadze should speak and even decided to allow them double the usual time so as to enable them to outline their evaluations, proposals and express their ideas. So all this seemed to fit well into a normal process as we foresaw it. And I will tell you, for me the statement by Eduard Amvrosiyevich (Shevardnadze) about his resignation was unexpected, and that, frankly speaking, is what hurts me most. The talks I had (with him) on the telephone - and there have been two - do not yet enable me to make a full evaluation of the reasons for the decision he took. We have agreed that we need to get together, sit down and talk and discuss everything. And I would not dot the `i's and pass a verdict on many issues starting withunequivocal condemnation of Shevardnadze's step. I think all this should be thought over, and I will try to say a couple of words and explain why. Or conversely, to ask (him), despite everything. All this needs to be thought over. What he said here and in my two telephone talks tells me that Eduard Amvrosiyevich Shevardnadze decided with the help of such a step, a protest, to come out against those who are trying to take advantage of the difficulties and question the course directed toward perestroika, on the main directions of struggle to reach the goals of perestroika and the renewal of the society. And since, as he thinks, this offensive has assumed the character of a planned offensive and uninterrupted assaults, (he) must resort to the sharpest forms in order to break the attacks against the implementation of this course and stop those who wish to take advantage of the acute situation and push us off course. Those are the arguments he outlined both here and to me. Because, after all (it is not in) his personal interests. I share this position in the sense that we must defend perestroika - I stated the thesis outright that it is the main task of our Congress as I see it in the real situation in which it proceeds when we all, the entire society, have reached the limit. We must either confirm our choice or alter the course. In essence the issue is such. Differences in tactical decisions, in the rates of perestroika - those after all are processes of (real) life, a matter of search, agreement. I said then that we must defend this course despite all costs, miscalculations, errors that have resulted in difficult consequences and for which (we) must bear responsibility. I am not evading responsibility, but I can see responsibility above all in bringing this course to its logical conclusion, so that it brings positive results for the entire society. Personally, I condemn Comrade Shevardnadze for acting so without consulting with the president, even more, I will tell you directly, since that matters have reached this point: my plans included recommending comrade Shevardnadze for vice president. This is what the situation is like. That is dotting the `i's. I did not decide this for nothing. This man made his choice long ago that we can no longer live in the kind of society in which we used to live. Confronting it as long as 10 years ago in a situation you know, he entered into the confrontation with certain forces. We knew about it and those who were near know all this well. He, like me, working in regions and here, came to the conclusion that even possessing the powers that we had we were unable to really unfold the processes. (Life) demanded that we go through all the trials, all the keen discussions - they were not public then - to come (to the understanding) that we must take every chance to begin changing everything in the society. He belongs to such a people. Even after all that I have said I do not want us to decide now that Shevardnadze is ``written off,'' and that he, so to speak, becomes history. No. I think we ought to support the opinion of our respected Deputy Academician (Dmitri) Likhachev, the writer (Sergei) Zalygin and other comrades who did not fly too far off with their fantasies - I cannot call it differently - frightening ourselves and the entire country. And to limit ourselves to the conclusion: a serious event has happened, that deserves that the president, the Supreme Soviet, the government try and sort it out in a normal situation as they should and then report their proposals and conclusions. To this, I think, we should limit ourselves.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Brandt Says germany responsible for Israel's Safety
DOC.TEXT: Willy Brandt, the elder statesman of German politics, on Thursday opened the first session of the newly elected parliament by saying the united nation was responsible for the safety of the Jewish state. The former chancellor also said he hoped for a settlement of Israel's conflicts with its Arab neighbors. The 662-member parliament, elected Dec. 2, met in the gleaming, flower-decorated chamber of the Reichstag building, near what was once the Berlin Wall. Lawmakers from east and west formally began work, while outside the imposing, battle-scarred edifice, German flags flew proudly in snowy skies. Legislators elected Rita Suessmuth as speaker, giving the politician the same job she held in the parliament of former West Germany and in the interim body that followed the Oct. 3 unification of the two German states. One day after his 77th birthday, Brandt delivered the keynote speech, an honor he received as the oldest lawmaker. ``Is there anyone in the chamber who was born before Dec. 18, 1913?'' he asked jokingly at the start of his speech. ``Apparently no one wants to admit it or can admit it.'' That drew a laugh from Chancellor Helmut Kohl, 60, and other lawmakers present. In addition to urging resolution of the 4{-month-old Persian Gulf crisis, Brandt touched on German relations with Israel. ``We cannot escape our joint responsibility for the security and well-being of the state of Israel,'' said the Nobel Peace Prize winner. ``To that I add the urgent hope for an agreement with the Arab neighbors.'' Brandt did not elaborate. Germans are agreed on the special responsibilities they bear following the Nazi Holocaust that claimed the lives of 6 million Jews. But German leaders also are increasingly insistent on resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflicts. The most prominent conflict includes resolution of the Palestinian question, which Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has said he wants to link to any withdrawal from Kuwait, which he invaded Aug. 2. Among those in the audience Thursday was President Francesco Cossiga of Italy, which now holds the rotating chairmanship of the 12-nation European Community. The German lawmakers present included members of the Party of Democratic Socialism, the renamed East German Communist Party that has become almost a pariah in the parliament. In his speech, Brandt said ``war is threatening at Europe's door,'' although he did not explain the reference. The Social Democratic leader urged Germans to live up to their country's growing importance in world politics. The Reichstag is the historic seat of German legislatures, and was the site of the moving German reunification ceremony on Oct. 3. Lawmakers, however, will return to the seat of government in Bonn for subsequent meetings. They eventually will decide whether to move permanently to Berlin, the capital of the newly reunited nation. Much of Brandt's speech was aimed at encouraging Germans to work together to complete the daunting task of unification. It will take years before the living standards are equal in eastern and western Germany. There have been estimates that up to 20,000 eastern Germans are heading west each month in search of better-paying work. Mrs. Suessmuth, in her speech, referred to the surprise resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Moscow. He was a key figure in the swift pace of German unity. ``We cannot be thankful enough that we were able to complete unity during the period in the past,'' Mrs. Suessmuth said. That appeared a reference to now-outdated German fears that if unification had not been railroaded through, political troubles in the Soviet Union could have blocked the process.

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: limit outselves.
DOC.TEXT: And something else. Of course, each of us plays his role. For those of my colleagues who joined it, and so to speak, made their choice from the first days, even before 1985, now, perhaps, is the most difficult time. But it is unforgivable to leave at such a moment. This must be condemned. And the demand expressed: that struggle be continued whatever turns, (that) the road upon which we stepped will stay, we will walk along it. This is the main thing. And today we must before our people and the world community confirm what we did at the first Congress, when we confirmed our course in foreign policies of our state, a course directed toward healthier international relations, new approaches that are already bearing fruit for the entire modern civilization, and have opened the way to a prolonged period of peace. This, without doubt we must do even today, immediately, as foreign correspondents are already asking questions, and academician (Vitaly) Goldansky when he spoke, so to speak, about three options, asked what could all this mean, a change of course? That's it. And something else. I would support the idea of the worker who spoke here - he did not introduce himself, and I forget his name. Let's not confuse things. We can see the state of our society, the political instability, the war of laws, the inefficiency of the executive power, gaps within it, etc., and this calls for immediate urgent measures to introduce order, strengthen discipline, to introduce tolerance into our society without which we cannot proceed with our transformations, and we have just reached the critical mark in those transformations. And please remember that many dozens of states had to go through such stages when they found themselves in this state at this or that period of their history and they always called for a strong power. If you have jelly you can eat too much of it and even gag on it. I can feel that what we have now is jelly-like power. It is not acceptable. It prevents us from doing our job, especially when people have such stresses when the patience has reached the limit. It must be done. And that does not mean talking about any dictatorship, but about strong power. And do not let's confuse these things. Because it would mean substituting one notion for another. Because the president now does not have information - and I get extensive information - that someone somewhere is preparing a junta or some other similar dictatorship, etc. No. I do not have such information. But if we are irresponsible, careless, if we do not listen to impulses coming from the society and miss the opportunity to strengthen our power and make it more dynamic, then of course, time may come when the society will start searching for solutions along those routes. We must be aware of it. These are the lessons of history. So all this is interconnected. And in this connection I reject Comrade Shevardnadze's thesis, because it smacks a little of panic. So I have been very open with you and I hope that you will support proposals put forward by the two deputies, patriarchs of our culture, and we will take this decision without going too far in our suppositions and accusations and ascribing things to our society that do not exist. Especially, I think, we must reject these emotional characteristics.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A sound stage where comedian George Burns exchanged one-liners with Gracie Allen is among four of Hollywood's oldest studios that have been saved from demolition. In an agreement announced Wednesday between two preservation groups and three studios, the George Burns Stage at the old Hollywood Center Studios and three other structures will not be changed or destroyed without approval from the preservation groups. Burns, who turns 95 next month, applauded the deal as he stood in front of the stage where he and Miss Allen, his late wife, starred in ``The Burns and Allen Show'' during the 1950s. The facility later was named after him. The studios said they will seek approval from a city-appointed task force before any of the structures are expanded or demolished. In return, preservationists agreed not to nominate studio buildings for blanket protection as city landmarks, thereby preventing renovations. Burns quipped that the agreement will help save studio buildings that are now almost as old as him. Hollywood Center Studios was built in 1919 and served as headquarters for silent screen comic Harold Lloyd. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Linda Ellerbee, who left NBC News in 1986, will return to the network in an entertainment show next month, producing and appearing in two of her own segments on NBC's new ``Sunday Best'' series. One segment will be a compilation of quirky news items. The other is called ``This Week in TV History.'' The one-hour series, airing opposite CBS' top-rated ``60 Minutes'' and ABC's ``Life Goes On,'' also plans to rerun highlights of NBC shows broadcast in the preceding week. The new show will premiere on Jan. 13. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - The country music duo the O'Kanes are breaking up to pursue separate careers as songwriters and record producers. Jamie O'Hara and Kieran Kane said Wednesday they have decided to change priorities in their careers. Their hit records during their four years together included ``Oh Darlin','' ``Can't Stop My Heart from Loving You'' and ``Daddies Need to Grow Up Too.'' They were finalists for four Country Music Association awards and one Grammy. O'Hara wrote the Judds' hit, ``Grandpa (Tell Me 'Bout the Good Old Days).'' Kane wrote Alabama's hit song, ``Gonna Have a Party.'' --- LONDON (AP) - Queen Elizabeth II invested former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher with the Order of Merit on Thursday. The investiture took place in private in the queen's audience room at Buckingham Palace, a spokesman said. The Order of Merit, founded in 1902, outranks all other royal honors and is a personal gift of the queen. The award was in recognition of Mrs. Thatcher's service as prime minister for 11{ years. Mrs. Thatcher, 65, resigned Nov. 22 after failing to win the first round of the Conservative Party leadership contest outright. Only the monarch and 24 others can be members of the Order of Merit, founded by King Edward VII. A vacancy was created by the death last year of Lord Olivier, the actor Laurence Olivier. --- SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Robert Mondavi, one of the leaders of the American wine industry as globe-trotting chairman of the Napa Valley winery that bears his name, retired Thursday from daily management operations. ``I've been a manager and I'll miss it,'' said the 77-year-old visionary who is credited with dragging the sleepy California wine industry of the early 1960s into the starry arena of world-class winemaking, alongside the French. He will remain chairman of the Robert Mondavi Winery. His two sons, Michael and Timothy, will run the winery. ``I want to see my sons achieve what I've achieved, and I think they will. ... The future is bright,'' Mondavi said. In 1966, Mondavi built the first new winery in California since Prohibition. Just past Oakville, he ordered the winery built in the Spanish mission style, with the winery on one side and tasting rooms on the other. It draws nearly 500,000 visitors a year.

DOC.HEAD: Ronald Reagan Chew Toys, Cards and Stockings Brighten Christmas For Fido
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Rowland Watson...', to CORRECT attribution of quote to John Ray sted Rowland Watson.
DOC.TEXT: Is Bowzer blue this holiday? Fifi feeling left out as everyone opens presents under the Christmas tree? Or maybe Fido just feels out-of-fashion, running around in his natural coat while everyone else wears designer clothes? As you may have guessed by now, there's a solution - a line of upscale gifts for the canine. Canine Caterers Inc., a suburban Philadelphia company, is among the purveyors of pet pampering products that offer holiday diversions for the discriminating animal. For the canine suffering the embarrassment of body odor, there's La Pooch perfume. For the curly-haired beast, there's tangle-removing fur shampoo. And what self-respecting pooch would go out in public wearing just a natural coat when there are three lines of clothing available? Among them: jean jackets for Dobermans and sweat suits for aerobic poodles. And speaking of sports, there are sweaters, collars and leashes with the logos of National Football League teams, not to mention rawhide chewable footballs that also bear team logos. For the politically aware dog, there are squeaky toys shaped in the heads of former president Ronald Reagan and Soviet president Mikhail S. Gorbachev. John Ray, vice president of sales for Canine Caterers, says the doggie gifts - and baubles for other animals as well - usually are sold in pet stores that ``have an upscale gist.'' ``Obviously,'' he said, ``the buyers have disposable income.''

DOC.HEAD: School Burglarized Same Night Board Approves Burglar Alarm
DOC.TEXT: School trustees voted this week to install a burglary system throughout the schools in this east Texas town. It wasn't soon enough. When school officials reported to work the next morning, they discovered that someone had broken into three buildings overnight, taking $300 in cash and change. ``It's ironic, to say the least,'' said Bob Iden, business manager for the Winona Independent School District. Winona is about 90 miles east of Dallas. Constable Charles Wilson said the burglars struck before dawn Wednesday. He said they broke into the elementary cafeteria, the junior high principal's office and the high school library. The money was stolen from the junior high principal's office. ``I guess it was their last chance before we put the alarm in,'' Wilson said.

DOC.HEAD: GATT Chief Urged to Pry Compromise from Europeans
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials said Thursday there's no point in resuming global trade talks until West European countries show they are ready to compromise on cutting farm subsidies. Arthur Dunkel, the director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, got that message in talks here on prospects for reviving the 107-nation negotiations that collapsed two weeks ago in Brussels, Belgium, the officials said.
