Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter told Dunkel on Wednesday that the United States does not favor another ministerial meeting ``until the European community changes its position on agriculture,'' Yeutter's spokesman said. The other main point made by Yeutter was that ``time is of the essence'' in concluding the negotiations, said spokesman Albert Maruggi. Carla Hills, the U.S. trade representative, told Dunkel the United States is ``ready to resume negotiations when there is a framework for agriculture'' negotiations, Mrs. Hills' deputy, Julius Katz, said Thursday. It was rejection by the European Community, Japan, South Korea and other countries of a compromise negotiating framework on the farm issue that brought the Brussels talks to an impasse two weeks ago. Dunkel told reporters during his meetings here he was consulting with GATT member countries on the situation, not negotiating. Katz said during a television interview beamed to Asia that a Jan. 15 meeting planned in Geneva to assess results achieved so far in the talks and prospects for restarting them ``does not necessarily signal resumption.'' The January meeting could last less than a day, he said, noting that the United States is in contact with all parties, resulting so far in ``lots of motion but not very much direction'' and no indication of more readiness for compromise on farm reform by the Europeans. Katz, who was a negotiator at Brussels, also accused Japan of failing to play a vigorous role in the talks and letting the West European Community take the blame for the collapse. ``I regret to say Japan has, I think, hidden behind the European Community and ... lagged in putting forward its own proposals and not negotiated vigorously,'' Katz said over Worldnet, a U.S.-government-sponsored television show. ``They've been permitted to enjoy this position because all the attention focussed on the European community, but should the negotiations be resumed, Japan will have to step up to its responsibilities and be an active participant in the negotiations,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomat Says 1,000 Soviets Prefer Winter in Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 Soviet specialists have opted to stay in Iraq to avoid a bleak winter in their country compounded by severe food shortages, Eastern European diplomats said Thursday. ``The news they receive from Moscow about the economic situation is so discouraging that they prefer to stay here rather than go home,'' one of the diplomats said on condition of anonymity. Moscow dispatched a senior official to Iraq this week to complete the evacuation of 2,565 Soviet citizens remaining in Iraq. The Baghdad government had said they could leave if their country accepted responsibility for the termination of their contracts. The Soviet official, Vladimir Mordinove, has informed the Iraqi government that Moscow was ready to compensate for the breach in contract, mainly in the oil, power and irrigation fields. Mordinove was told after a meeting with Hussein Kamel, Iraq's minister of industry and acting minister of oil, that all the Soviets could go home whether they finish their contracts or not. Soviet Embassy officials said they will do their best to persuade the 1,000 Soviets to leave before Jan. 15, the deadline set by the United Nations for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. More than 3,300 Soviets were in Iraq on Dec. 4 when the Revolutionary Command Council said they would all leave if Moscow paid compensation for breaking their contracts. That was down from 8,000 before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. For the past three weeks, the two sides have been involved in negotiations over the compensation.

DOC.HEAD: Students Shut Down Eastern Germany's Top Institutions
DOC.TEXT: Strumming a guitar, a folk singer sang protest songs Thursday at Humboldt University. Students, sprawled on blankets, uncorked wine bottles. Crude banners hung from elegant arches. Classrooms were dark and empty. ``Occupied'' read the gigantic cloth banner fluttering in the cold wind from the roof of Humboldt, the finest university in what used to be East Germany. Students shut it down Thursday, occupied its halls and closed its classrooms. In Leipzig, thousands of students set up blockades around prestigious Karl Marx University, and in Halle, another 4,000 students held a protest rally at Martin Luther University. While the new nation's united Parliament met for the first time Thursday and paid tribute to German unity, eastern German students occupied halls of higher education and symbolized the new nation's division. Eastern Germany's new leaders have begun implementing sweeping plans to restructure schools to fit the framework in the West. Scores of university departments, many entwined with socialist doctrine, will be closed. But the plans have met fierce resistance from students who have held protests at scores of schools in the past week. Many fear years of study will suddenly be rendered worthless. Some educators say the new conflict is only the latest product of the former nation's quick transition. ``This mirrors the situation in the entire land,'' said Humboldt sports science teacher Helmut Hiller, gesturing to the crowds of students packed in Humboldt's cavernous main lobby, a scene more reminiscent of Berkeley in the 1960s than Berlin in the 1990s. ``How fast should it go, what should go first, how should we deal with the past?'' he said. ``You can apply the same questions to everything.'' The newly created five eastern German states and the city government of Berlin now have responsibility for the school systems that were once run by the centralized Communist government. In the past week they have announced plans to begin ``restructuring'' the college system, focusing most - but not exclusively - on departments that often were grounded in socialist ideology. Philosophy, sociology, journalism, economics, and several other departments are the most likely candidates to be eliminated or sharply reduced. The Berlin Senate is to decide on Saturday how its planned restructuring at Humboldt will proceed and which teachers will go. The students and many faculty members say the universities should be given autonomy to operate as they choose, said Conni Sonntag, 25, a student council leader. ``There are changes that have to be made, but this univeristy has made many many changes'' in the year since the collapse of Communism in former East Germany, she said. ``We want autonomy. The Western government should not make these decisions.'' Stately old Humboldt, which has 15,000 students and 6,000 employees, was founded in 1809 in the heart of historic Berlin. It has produced 27 Nobel laureates and is known worldwide. In 1948, with the Soviets and the Western allies occupying opposite sides of the city after World War II, political tensions grew within the school. The alternative Free University was established as a counterpoint on the West side of the city. Humboldt became more a bastion of Communist ideology, but it also spawned many dissident intellectuals. Now, Free University has become the blueprint for what the Western-dominated government in Berlin wants Humboldt to be. Even departments that are expected to survive may face cutbacks. In Leipzig, thousands of students blocked entrances and took over the chancellor's office. They met with Saxony Education Minister Hans Joachim Meyer to discuss the department closings. He said new departments would be formed to replace old ones. Students at both schools vowed to continue the sit-ins through the Christmas break. In Frankfurt, the Union of Education Sciences promised to provide legal support for the students. Union chief Dieter Wunder called the planned changes necessary but said they were being undertaken in a ``cold'' and ``arrogant'' manner.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Abuse Down? Not In Inner City, Experts Say
LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Drug treatment experts disputed President Bush's statistics on declining drug use Thursday, saying they ignore the very populations affected most by addiction: the homeless and the inner-city poor. ``If you're in prison, if you're homeless, if you're mentally ill and on the street, you simply don't exist in these statistics,'' said Steve Dnistrian, a spokesman for New York City's Phoenix House, the nation's largest residential drug treatment center. ``I think the numbers are very misleading. You'll see declines out in, say, Scarsdale or parts of Orange County, California, but not in East Harlem or Watts.'' Nina Peyser, executive director of the chemical dependency institute at Beth Israel Medical Center, said there has been no evidence of a decrease in New York City in recent memory. ``Absolutely not. We have had waiting lists as long as I've been here, and I've been here 15 years,'' said Peyser, whose center treats 8,100 heroin addicts in the city. The study also fails to address drug-related problems such as pregnant addicts, AIDS, and the dysfunctional families created by drug use - all of which still plague the inner city, the experts noted. The Household Survey on Drug Abuse, released Wednesday, reported that use of any illicit drug dropped 44 percent during the last five years. The survey, conducted by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, also found a 72 percent drop in casual cocaine use during the past five years. The survey covered households with telephones, meaning it ignored large parts of society where drug problems are rampant, experts said. ``These people missed the cocaine epidemic. ... In the treatment field we don't pay much attention to NIDA studies,'' said Scott McMillin, director of the addiction treatment center at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. Rene Topalain, assistant director of drug abuse services for the Los Angeles County Department of Health, said it was too early to declare victory in the war on drugs. ``We are still dealing with the issue of cocaine babies, AIDS and the transmission of AIDS by people who are drug users and heavy alcohol use,'' said Topalain. ``So I would not sit here and say anything like we have turned the corner on the drug problem.'' Elected officials and prosecutors joined the treatment centers in questioning the study's findings. ``You look at the inner city, and there is no 70 percent reduction. You will see those statistics are invalid,'' said special narcotics prosecutor Sterling Johnson in New York City. Evidence of the drug problem is in the city and state jail population, said Johnson. In 1985, the state had 27,000 inmates; this year, it's 58,000. Inmates awaiting trial on Rikers Island numbered 10,000 in 1985; this year, it's 21,000, he said. ``I do nothing but prosecute narcotics felonies. In 1985, I had maybe 2,000 indictments. In 1990, there were 7,000 indictments. The drugs are out there,'' said Johnson. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, speaking Thursday morning in New York City, derided the Bush administration statistics and urged Mayor David Dinkins to invite the president to New York for a firsthand look at the drug problem. ``I think (Bush) has been misled by advisers with respect to where we stand in the war against drugs. We here in the city of New York know better,'' said Dinkins. ``And I'd be delighted to show him the evidence.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Charged Premium Rate for Mail to U.S. Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's national airline declined a Postal Service request that it waive international mail rates in favor of the lower fees observed by U.S. airlines for carrying mail to American troops in the Saudi desert, a postal official said Thursday. James E. Orlando, head of international services for the Postal Service, confirmed that Saudi Arabian Airlines had charged the service nearly $1.9 million to deliver about 1.05 million pounds of mail addressed to Desert Shield troops during the Sept. 1-Oct. 17 period. Rep. Benjamin Gilman, R-N.Y., had cited those figures in a letter of protest to the Saudi ambassador and the postmaster general, saying that was too much to pay. Orlando, questioned by a reporter, said the amount was reasonable, in that it complied with the rates set by the Universal Postal Union, an international organization of postal administrators. But he noted the Saudis had declined a Pstal Service request that the airline instead observe the mail-rate schedule set by the Department of Transportation for U.S.-flagged carriers. The UPU rates are about 2 1/2 times higher than the U.S. rates. Gilman, ranking Republican on the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee, said in his letter: ``Bearing in mind that the Congress had provided free mailing privileges to our military personnel in Saudi Arabia, permit me to express my strong disapproval ... and to recommend that the U.S. Postal Service work with the Department of Defense and the State Department to ensure that Saudi Airlines absorb these mail expenses.'' Orlando said that ``the whole issue that Congressman Gilman had, which is whether we should be paying that rate level to the Saudi government in view of the fact that we're over there defending them, as far as I'm concerned is a legitimate issue for the Congress and the administration, but not for the Postal Service.'' ``We approached Saudi Airlines and asked if they would be willing to accept the DOT rate level,'' Orlando said. ``They declined and insisted on the UPU rate level, which is what we did pay them.'' The Postal Service decided to use the Saudi airline at that time because it had more mail than it could send on U.S.-flagged carriers, which must accept the DOT rate, Orlando noted. Since mid-November, virtually all mail to Desert Shield troops has been carried by military aircraft, Orlando said. Under the law providing ``free'' mailing privileges to Desert Shield soldiers, the Defense Department must reimburse the Postal Service.

DOC.HEAD: Facing Rough Times, Businesses Slash Investment Plans
DOC.TEXT: American businesses, worried about a recession, plan a barely perceptible 0.4 percent increase in spending to modernize in 1991, the most pessimistic outlook for business investment in five years. The findings released in a Commerce Department report Thursday showed that the pessimism about the future that had been widely reflected in surveys of consumer sentiment has spread to American businesses. ``The plans for 1991 reflect increasingly tough times in the economy,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Co. The 0.4 percent increase, after adjusting for inflation, would follow a projected advance of 4.1 percent for this year. It would be the weakest showing since business investment fell 3.1 percent in 1986, when American manufacturers battered by a flood of foreign goods cut back plans to expand and modernize. Some economists said even the tiny 0.4 percent gain was unlikely if the recession turns out to be worse than expected. The estimate, they said, is based on a survey taken in October and early November. Since then, evidence has mounted that the downturn could be worse than originally believed. A report last week showed industrial output fell in November at the steepest pace since the end of the last recession in 1981-82. Sinai predicted that when the actual 1991 spending is totaled, it will show business investment falling anywhere from 3 percent to 5 percent. That would act as a further drag on the economy because business investment in each of the past two years has contributed about one-fifth of the economy's total growth. Evelina Tainer, an economist with First National Bank of Chicago, said the weak spending plans reflected ``producers' pessimism about the economy.'' The survey put total 1991 business investment spending at $524.2 billion. Earlier surveys for 1990 had put the spending advance as high as 5.5 percent. The latest estimate of a 4.1 percent increase was down a full percentage point from a 5.1 percent projection based on a survey released three months ago. In another report reflecting the sluggish economy, the Commerce Department said consumer spending remained sluggish in November, inching up just 0.1 percent after holding steady the previous month. Consumer spending represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. At the same time, the department said, personal incomes rose a scant 0.3 percent, just keeping pace with inflation. However, the rise was attributed entirely to increases in farm subsidies. Excluding those, incomes would not have changed. Analysts blamed weak spending on the weak growth in personal income. ``The combination of job losses, reductions in hours worked and a recession in manufacturing and other sectors is just not generating income in wages and salaries,'' Sinai said. ``It sets a very bleak picture in place for consumer spending.'' Many economists are looking for total economic activity, as measured by the gross national product, to fall by between 3 percent and 4 percent at an annual rate in the current October-December quarter. They believe that downturn will mark the start of the country's ninth recession since World War II. The government's first look at GNP in the fourth quarter will be released next month. However, some economists saw a glimmer of optimism in the fact that the business spending survey showed any increase at all in investment for next year. ``The fact that capital spending will slow but not actually decrease is commensurate with the view the recession will be milder than the postwar average,'' said economist Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers. Michael K. Evans, head of a Washington forecasting company, agreed, saying that any spending increase means ``the recession is going to be very mild and last only two quarters.'' All of the figures have been adjusted for inflation. Before adjusting for inflation, the survey projected a 2.4 percent increase for all businesses in 1991, to $546.7 billion, after gains of 11.4 percent in 1989 and 11 percent in 1988. It said the investment increase for all industries includes a 4.6 percent gain for manufacturing companies and a 5.6 percent advance for companies engaged in mining, transportation and other non-manufacturing businesses. Manufacturers are projecting investment spending of $193.6 billion. The gain includes a 1.4 percent increase by industries making durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last at least three years - and a 7.3 percent increase by those engaged in non-durables such as food and clothing.

DOC.HEAD: Primakov Among Several Possible Replacements For Shevardnadze
With AM-Soviet-Politics
DOC.TEXT: The next Soviet foreign minister will face a different world than Eduard A. Shevardnadze took on five years ago, but the possible candidates all appear to be dedicated followers of the policy he set down. Although Gorbachev could reach outside the Foreign Ministry for a replacement, speculation focuses on the foreign policy establishment. They have the kind of training Shevardnadze lacked when Mikhail S. Gorbachev appointed him in the summer of 1985 to take over for Andrei A. Gromyko. Unlike Shevardnadze's crusade for change in the last five years, the next foreign minister will need to maintain and cultivate the Soviet Union's new role as friend of the United States, a mediator in international disputes and partner in cooperation with Europe and the former members of the oviet bloc. The new foreign minister still will face old guard bureaucrats in some departments at the Foreign Ministry as he navigates new relations with Israel, the Vatican, Japan, South Korea and Germany, among others. There will likely be less financial and military aid to use as tool of Soviet policy because the government must deal with a crippled economy and a budget deficit. Here is a brief look at those considered prime candidates for the job: Yevgeny M. Primakov, the first candidate mentioned in the Soviet press after Shevardnadze's resignation, is a 61-year-old former professor known most recently for his shuttle diplomacy to Iraq and the search for a solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. His effort failed after several meetings with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, reported to be a longtime friend. But still it heightened his status as a savvy envoy who knows his war around the volatile Middle East. Before becoming a deputy foreign minister last year, Primakov was director of the Institute for World Economy and International Relations. An expert on the Middle and Far East, and with a doctorate in economics, Primakov helped devise the ``new thinking'' foreign policy that Shevardnadze was implementing. Valentin M. Falin, 64, became chief of the Communist Party's international department in 1988, before the party's credibility plummeted and the job lost some of its influence over foreign policies. Falin is considered a master diplomat and the leading Soviet expert on Western Europe. He rose through the Foreign Ministry's European departments and served as a Soviet attache in Austria and ambassador to West Germany. He was an adviser to Gromyko in 1965, a national legislator on the foreign affairs committee, a member of the government daily Izvestia's editorial board, and member of the party's policy-making Central Committee. Vladimir F. Petrovsky, a deputy foreign minister since 1986, has seen his stock rise lately because of his Middle Eastern knowledge. The 57-year-old diplomat was in Baghdad while the Soviet Union began dropping its cautionary tone and threatening to support force against Iraq if Saddam didn't pull out of Kuwait. He began his foreign service career as an English translator at the United Nations. He became chief of the Foreign Ministry's U.S. department, then head of the ministry's section that deals with international organizations. Yuli A. Vorontsov, 61, a rare generalist in Soviet diplomacy, worked in the United States, India and France before being sent as trouble-shooting ambassador to Afghanistan during the Soviet pullout in 1988. His experience includes meeting secretly in 1985 with Israel's ambassador in France to discuss restoration of ties, defending Soviet human rights policies at a rights conference in 1977, and leading disarmament talks in 1985 on U.S. and Soviet intermediate and strategic nuclear weapons. He later was brought back to Moscow and made first deputy foreign minister, solidifying his place in a new generation of flexible, innovative diplomats. Alexander A. Bessmertnykh, 57, an expert on U.S.-Soviet relations, was made Soviet ambassador to the United States in April and a time of several foreign service changes. He had served in the Soviet Embassy in Washington for 13 years before returning to Moscow in 1983, where he was a deputy foreign minister responsible for the United Nations and North America. He later rose to become one of three first deputy foreign ministers.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Returns From California
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Columbia returned home to Kennedy Space Center on Thursday, 10 days after its return to Earth. Bolted atop a 747 carrier aircraft, Columbia touched down on the space center's shuttle landing strip Thursday afternoon. The seven-man shuttle crew observed the universe through four onboard telescopes during a troubled-plagued, nine-day mission that ended when Columbia landed Dec. 10 at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. It was launched Dec. 2. Columbia's trip home from California began Tuesday, after a two-day delay caused by a major winter storm. Bad weather also dogged its two-day trek across the United States. The shuttle spent Tuesday night at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio and Wednesday night at Barksdale Air Force Base at Shreveport, La. Columbia's next mission is set for May 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Karami Chosen Lebanon's Prime Minister
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 2 grafs after 4th graf `Hoss, a' to UPDATE with Karami accepts task, quote. Picks up 5th graf `Traditionally, the' with minor editing to conform, DELETING 8th graf `Karami told,' which has been superseded
DOC.TEXT: President Elias Hrawi on Thursday chose Education Minister Omar Karami to form a new government aiming to end 15 years of civil war in Lebanon. But three militia groups have expressed doubts that Karami could carry out the task. The presidential statement said the choice was based on the outcome of daylong consultations by Hrawi with parliament blocs on a successor to Prime Minister Salim Hoss. Hoss, a Sunni Moslem, resigned with his 13-month-old Cabinet on Wednesday to make way for a broad-based national reconciliation government. Karami, 55, is also a Sunni. Karami told reporters at Hrawi's residence he accepted the designation and would promptly begin consultations to form the new Cabinet. ``We shall form the government and the wheel of peace and unity will roll and I hope all will get aboard,'' he said. Traditionally, the president has been a Maronite Catholic, the prime minister a Sunni and the parliament speaker a Shiite Moslem. Hrawi met with Parliament speaker Hussein Husseini after polling 61 deputies of parliament's 68 surviving members on a successor to Hoss. The statement said Hrawi then issued a presidential decree accepting the resignation of Hoss and his 14-member Cabinet and signed another decree naming Karami prime minister. Lebanese media said Hrawi wants the new government formed of a cross-section of 30 politicians and warlords to end the civil war, which had claimed more than 150,000 lives. But serious doubts have been voiced about the ability of Karami, a lawyer, to put together such a government coalition. Karami surfaced on the political stage only three years ago, when he inherited the leadership of the northern provincial capital of Tripoli from his elder brother, the late Prime Minister Rashid Karami. The elder Karami, the longest serving prime minister in Lebanon's 47 years of independence, was assassinated by a bomb explosion aboard an army helicopter in northern Lebanon on June 1, 1987. Karami's mission was jolted when the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, Iran's main ally in Lebanon, said it refuses to join his government. ``The new government is certain to lack the vision and the minimum degree of harmony required to resolve the nation's woes,'' said a statement by Hezbollah, which fields one of Lebanon's three strongest militias. The two other main militias, the Lebanese Forces of Christian chieftain Samir Geagea and Druse warlord Walid Jumblatt's Progressive Socialist Party, earlier expressed reservations about the government change. Jumblatt's party predicted Karami's would be ``an untidy government that would stumble upon its first steps. This could create a dangerous power vacuum.'' The Lebanese Forces, a traditional civil war foe of Jumblatt, voiced a similar concern, saying Karami lacked the statesmanship and national prestige of his predecessor. The statement said Geagea ``will not take part in the new Cabinet ... Because it looks like it is going to be a Tower of Babel.'' The new government faces the task of disbanding the warring militias and enforcing an Arab League-brokered peace plan that Parliament ratified Aug. 22. It must also fill 31 vacancies in the one-chamber Parliament by appointment and raise the number of seats from 99 to 108 to attain equality between Moslems and Christians as envisaged by the peace plan. Christians have had a 6-to-5 edge in Parliament since independence from France in 1943. The present Parliament was elected in 1972 for a four-year term. The civil war, which broke out in 1975, has prevented elections and the house has repeatedly renewed its mandate. Government troops reunited war-divided Beirut Dec. 3 by deploying in the capital and its environs after militias withdrew from Beirut to their areas of influence in north, east and south Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Heath Urges Against Hasty Declaration Of War
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former British Prime Minister Edward Heath told Congress Thursday to hold off declaring war on Iraq because the costs of such a conflict would be high and Saddam Hussein knows it. ``My own view is that it is essential that now we put the emphasis on the diplomatic action,'' Heath said before a hearing of the House Armed Services Committee. Heath, who visited Saddam on a humanitarian mission in October, said war might be necessary if, in the end, no other solution is found. For the time being, he said the United States and its allies should give U.N. sanctions against Iraq more time to work. The world community that opposed Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait should be trying to encourage a settlement of Iraq's grievances against Kuwait while trying to prod Iraq to withdraw its troops from the country, he said. ``It has become more and more obvious that the costs of any war now in the Gulf are going to be extremely high for both sides,'' the former Conservative Party leader said. ``I am convinced that President Saddam Hussein and those around him now recognize this.'' But Heath said, ``I wouldn't underestimate Saddam Hussein's capability of waging war.'' Iraq's million-man army developed its desert warfare skills in the eight-year conflict with Iran that ended July 1988. Heath played down the significance of Jan. 15 as a deadline for Iraqi troops to get out of Kuwait. The U.N. resolution stipulates such a date, but Heath said it could be easily ignored. Heath also said Saddam miscalculated the world reaction to his annexation of Kuwait, but he ``is certainly not mad and he is certainly not a Hitler.'' ``He's astute and it's noticeable in his policy that he does things which are unexpected,'' he said. ``He is a very determined person.'' If sanctions take their toll on Iraq as they eventually will, Heath said, Saddam might show some flexibility in withdrawing his troops from part of Kuwait. Ultimately Saddam does not want to be isolated from his Arab neighbors, Heath said, adding the conflict must be solved by Arabs. In an Arab settlement, Kuwait could agree to write off the debt Iraq owes it stemming from the Iran-Iraq war, and a buffer region could be set up between the two countries, he said. But Heath said Saddam deeply distrusts the United States and Britain and needs some assurances they will not attack him. He added that there were back-channel negotiations underway between various nations but refused to provide any details.

DOC.HEAD: Top Officer Plea Bargains, Will Release Names in Corruption Scam
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said Thursday they had agreed to a plea bargain by a senior Israeli Air Force officer accused of accepting millions of dollars in bribes while purchasing U.S.-made military equipment. According to the deal, Brig. Gen. Rami Dotan will be required to return $10 million in bribes and kickbacks he allegedly accepted while heading the Defense Ministry's department of military acquisitions in New York in 1984-85. Dotan also agreed to supply investigators with the names of other people involved in the scam, Israel radio said. In exchange, no charges will be brought against Dotan's wife, who was also accused of involvement, the radio said. The scandal shocked Israel's military establishment and raised concerns it might jeopardize the $1.8 billion in U.S. military aid Israel receives annually. In announcing the plea bargain, which was signed last week, chief military prosecutor Brig. Gen. Amnon Strashnov dismissed criticism that the deal could limit full disclosure of the corruption. ``There is no attempt to hide or to cover up anything here,'' he said. ``If we could have reached the truth ... without this agreement, I would have been the last one to sign it.'' Strashnov said that besides allegedly accepting bribes, Dotan is accused of fraud, breech of trust, receiving money illegally, and conspiracy to commit a crime. Israel Television said Dotan is also suspected of swindling the Air Force out of money and equipment. Chief of Staff Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron said Wednesday that the accusations, if proven, amounted to treason. But Strashnov said the charge sheet against Dotan would contain no such charge. The plea bargain must be accepted by the military court trying Dotan. Dotan was arrested in October and resigned as air force chief of logistics. He is one of the highest-ranking officers ever brought to trial for a weapons scandal.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher Proceeds with Charity Guide Despite Complaint
DOC.TEXT: A publisher has refused to halt distribution of a directory of charitable organizations that the Council of Better Business Bureaus says contains ``stale and unreliable information'' about the council's evaluations of charities. The action came to light Thursday as the council issued an alert to its members and to users of its Philanthropic Advisory Service. The alert says the council did not review, approve or collaborate on the directory published by the Taft Group in Rockville, Md. The directory is called Charitable Organizations of the United States. It lists about 700 charities, with information including whether they claim to meet the council's standards for charitable solicitations. James H. McIlhenny, president of the council, said in the alert that the book contains 120 references to evaluations by the council and 11 of them are wrong. He said Steven J. Cole, vice president and senior counsel of the better business group, wrote to the directory publisher last month asking that further marketing and distribution be suspended pending discussion of the council's objections. The alert said that Taft responded earlier this month that it is ``willing to discuss modifications in future printings regarding specific errors which you may wish to bring to our attention. Nevertheless, we unequivocally reject any request to discontinue or inhibit full distribution and sale of the present edition.'' Marty Mattare, president of the Taft Group, declined comment except to say that the issues raised by the council were under discussion between the two groups. She said officers of the council and the publishing firm would be meeting ``in several weeks.'' The Council of Better Business Bureaus says it promotes ethical standards of business practices and protects consumers through voluntary self-regulation and monitoring activities. It is a private agency whose members include major businesses and better business bureaus in the United States and Canada. The Taft Group is a division of Gale Research Inc. of Detroit, whic is affiliated with the Thomson Information-Publishing Group of Stamford, Conn., and Toronto.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Had Affair With Archbishop Received $20,000 in Church Funds
DOC.TEXT: A woman whose affair with the nation's highest-ranking black Roman Catholic prompted his resignation received more than $20,000 in church funds to pay her personal expenses, an audit revealed Thursday. The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta said it would not seek to recover the money sent to Vicki Long or to her creditors, said the Rev. Peter Dora, an archdiocese spokesman. Results of the audit by Coopers & Lybrand public accountants were published Thursday in the archdiocese newspaper, the Georgia Bulletin. The financial review of the archdiocese and two parishes found that about $5,835 from individual churches went directly to Ms. Long or to her creditors to pay her rent, utilities or charge cards. The archdiocese paid $14,556 in medical expenses for Ms. Long, the audit said. Ms. Long will not receive any more money ``directly or indirectly from the archdiocese of Atlanta or any of its components,'' Dora said Thursday. The archdiocese commissioned the audit after the resignations last summer of Archbishop Eugene Marino and the Rev. Michael Woods, a priest who said he had a sexual relationship with Ms. Long. Ms. Long denied having had a relationship with Woods, but claimed she was married to Marino. She filed a paternity suit in 1987 against another priest, the Rev. Donal Keohane of Columbus. A blood test later showed Keohane did not father her daughter. Ms. Long later said she was sexually exploited by Keohane and Marino. She also claimed to have been molested by a nun in Columbus. Marino, once the nation's highest-ranking black Roman Catholic, has undergone therapy at an undisclosed location since his resignation. The audit showed funds from two churches - St. Pius X in Conyers and St. John the Evangelist in Hapeville - went directly to Ms. Long and her creditors. Woods was pastor at St. John the Evangelist, where Ms. Long was a lay minister, for 10 years. He moved to a suburban Sandy Springs parish two years ago. The Rev. John Walsh of St. Pius told the archdiocese last fall he had given Ms. Long funds set aside for the poor. There was no indication of a relationship between Walsh and Ms. Long. Dora said the church would not discipline Woods or Walsh for disbursing the money. The audit did not review the personal finances of Marino, who church officials believe contributed more money to Ms. Long over a two-year period. ``Archbishop Marino pretty well lost his life savings,'' said Dora. ``Likewise, Father Woods is destitute.''

DOC.HEAD: Boschwitz Appeal Pays Off for Former Homeless Worker
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Rudy Boschwitz's appeal to colleagues to hire one of his employees has paid off for the woman, who was homeless when he hired her two years ago. Valerie Gaines, a 36-year-old typist, accepted a job Wednesday with Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., one of about 20 lawmakers who responded this week to Boschwitz's letter. ``My Christmas is really full,'' said Gaines, who became an overnight celebrity in Washington in 1989 after Boschwitz hired her. Boschwitz, who was defeated for re-election, leaves office next month. She had had just two job interviews prior to Boschwitz's appeal and her husband has been disabled by two strokes and cannot work, she said. The couple has two daughters, ages 6 and 8. ``Valerie hasn't found a new job ... and we need to place her quickly to avoid another debilitating bout with homelessness,'' Boschwitz wrote. Gaines worked for then-Sen. Lawton Chiles, D-Fla., for two years but lost her job when he retired in 1988. During the three weeks she was jobless along with her husband, their landlord evicted them and their belongings were stolen. Boschwitz's staff hired her not knowing that the address she gave was that o a homeless shelter. She now lives in an apartment in suburban Maryland.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Buy More Corn
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has bought more corn from the United States, boosting purchases this week to more than 1.3 million metric tons, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Officials said private exporting companies sold an additional 300,000 tons to the Soviets under terms of the current long-term supply agreement between the two countries. No prices or other details were disclosed. A sale of 266,500 tons of corn was announced on Tuesday, the first large U.S. grain order in two months. Another sale of 385,000 tons was announced on Wednesday. The pact, including a three-month extension, expires Dec. 31. A new five-year agreement will begin at that time. Although neither order of corn will be delivered to the Soviet Union by Dec. 31, all of the grain will be counted under the final quarter of the old agreement, the department said. The Soviets are committed to buy at least 1 million tons each of wheat and corn in the final three months of the agreement, along with 250,000 tons of soybeans. So far, officials said, corn sales total more than 1.34 million tons, and soybean meal, 387,000 tons. No final-quarter wheat has been sold. A metric ton of 2,205 pounds is equivalent to 39.4 bushels of corn. The 300,000 tons would be about 11.8 million bushels. Corn prices have been averaging about $2.18 per bushel at the farm level, according to a recent USDA five-day average. Thus, the latest sale could have a farm value of about $26 million.

DOC.HEAD: Young Man Sought in Spate of 7 Shotgun Killings, Investigators Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Brothers Eli Balovski and George Baloski are cq
DOC.TEXT: Investigators are hunting for a young man they believe fired the shotgun blasts that killed seven people since Oct. 30. The slayings, all within a 20-mile radius of this city in the state's northwest pocket, are raising fears and gun sales at the same time. The man being sought is between 20 and 35 years old, Portage police Sgt. Warren E. Lewis said Wednesday. ``Evidence has now linked the seven shootings,'' he said. He declined to say what that evidence is. But sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said shotgun casings from earlier shootings were matched to a shell recovered by police Tuesday at the scene of the slayings of two brothers in their tailor shop in Gary. The brothers, Ilija ``Eli'' Balovski and George Baloski, were killed by shotgun blasts to the head, Lake County Coroner Daniel Thomas said. The rash of slayings began Oct. 30, when a man and a woman were killed and at least three other people were fired at in separate incidents in the towns of Griffith, St. John and Cedar Lake. A male gas station attendant was killed Thursday, and a man and a woman were slain Saturday in two separate shootings. A special police unit was formed to investigate the shootings, which occurred in a parking lot, gas stations, a garage, a motel, at a bank and on the street. The psychological profile compiled by the FBI's National Center for Anaylsis of Violent Crimes in Quantico, Va., is that of a person who may have recently experienced a traumatic event in his personal life. ``Family friends or loved ones may well be aware of the change in this person's personality and lifestyle,'' the analysis stated. In the meantime, frightened residents apparently are arming themselves. Jack Batz, owner of Jack's Gun Shop in Burns Harbor, said Thursday his sales have increased fivefold since last week. ``We saw a big increase because people realize these are senseless killings,'' Batz said. Valparaiso Police Sgt. Al Eisenmenger said that adding to the fear are rumors of other shootings, which have abounded since the series of shootings began. ``The imagination runs wild because there is no apparent motive. We're trying to keep people from getting into the rumor mill,'' he said. Eisenmenger said officers are advising residents to take precautions. ``We tell them to keep in groups and lighted areas. But how do you advise people to be safe when there is no rhyme or reason to the shooter's motive?'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Postpones Forming Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with possibility that Mazowiecki might be considered for prime minister again; ADDS background on economic problems; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Lech Walesa on Thursday delayed naming a government and said he may put off parliamentary elections for a year to give the leadership he eventually selects time to attack Poland's problems. However, he said he may instead keep the spring vote on schedule and allow a modified version of the current government, led by Tadeusz Mazowiecki, to serve in the interim. Walesa, who Saturday will be inaugurated as Poland's first popularly elected president, will make a final decision after the Christmas and New Year holidays, said a statement issued by his spokesman Andrzej Drzycimski. He had been expected to name a new government quickly after his swearing-in. The president-elect has concluded that an entirely revamped government now would mean delaying Poland's first fully free parliamentary elections since World War II because the new team would need one year to work, the statement said. Walesa might instead keep Mazowiecki's government ``with essential corrections'' for a three-month transition, the statement said. Mazowiecki himself could be asked to stay ``if there is social approval for it,'' Drzycimski later told the PAP news agency. Parliament on Dec. 14 accepted Mazowiecki's resignation as prime minister. Walesa's former adviser in the Solidarity labor movement, Mazowiecki quit as head of government after losing the bitter campaign for president. He said he wanted to head a new political group, the Democratic Union, that would oppose Walesa. It was unclear if he now would consider remaining as interim prime minister. A spokesman for him, Boguslaw Piwowar, said Thursday night there would be no immediate reaction. Mazowiecki's deputy premier, Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, the architect of Poland's shock economic reform program, also is being mentioned prominently as a contender to lead the new government. ``Lech Walesa fully respects the will of the voters awaiting quick formation of the government. However he wants to act with reason,'' said his statement. The statement said Walesa was faced with two options. First, he could nominate a new prime minister and Cabinet that would ``live up to social expectations,'' but that would mean postponing the spring parliament elections for one year. Second, he could ``leave the old government, with essential corrections, which would survive up to spring elections.'' Under Poland's still evolving democracy, the president nominates the prime minister who is responsible for day-to-day running of the government. The president is the chief of state and commander-in-chief of the military and may dismiss parliament in certain well-defined circumstances. Jan Olszewski, an attorney designated by Walesa to hold talks on forming a government, gave up the mission Tuesday in what a source close to him said was a disagreement with Walesa over how large a role Balcerowicz would have. Balcerowicz refused to answer any questions about his prospects during a meeting at the Sejm, the lower house of parliament. Sources in the Solidarity labor movement, where Walesa first rose to prominence, said that as of Wednesday, Balcerowicz appeared virtually certain of getting the post. The Walesa spokesman, Drzycimski, confirmed Balcerowicz was under consideration for the premiership and in any case was sure to have a ``key role'' in the next government. Deputy Mieczyslaw Gil, chairman of the Solidarity parliamentary caucus, said just before a meeting with Balcerowicz that he would ``make a very good prime minister.'' Two other candidates once mentioned as possible premiers by Walesa ruled themselves out: Jaroslaw Kaczynski of the Center Alliance Party and Jan Krzysztof Bielecki of the Liberal Party of Gdansk. The newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza reported Thursday that Balcerowicz had accepted in talks with Walesa certain adjustments in the year-old economic reform plan. They were not detailed. A 43-year-old economist, Balcerowicz assumed head of the Finance Ministry and the deputy premiership in September 1989, in the East bloc's first non-Communist government. The ``shock'' plan, which bears Balcerowicz's name, took effect Jan. 1. It combined sharp rises in prices with an end of state subsidies on most goods, wage controls, and a stable, devalued zloty made largely convertible with Western currencies. It also calls for a breakup of big state monopolies and privatizing about 7,000 state-owned enterprises, a process just getting under way. Soon after the program's introduction, lines and empty shop shelves that had characterized the Polish economy for years disappeared. Private commerce blossomed, but production in the state sector fell sharply. Unemployment - previously unknown - rose to 1.1 million during the year.

DOC.HEAD: Warmth, Candor Marked Shevardnadze's U.S. Missions
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: His trademark was a dark, vested suit, but Eduard Shevardnzadze quickly got down to his shirt sleeves with James Baker. His candid description of the failure of communism on a flight to Wyoming in September 1989 convinced the secretary of state that Shevardnadze was committed to reform, and would not mislead the Bush administration. It marked a turning point toward a warm personal and geopolitical relationship. With all the talk of nuclear arsenals and, more lately, the rumblings of war in the Persian Gulf, Shevardnadze's mood remained as expansive as his native Soviet Georgia. When Baker took him to Jackson Hole, Wyo., he readily donned fishing boots and waded into the Snake River, genuinely enjoying the sparkling water and America's outdoors. He commented months later that ``we do our best work outside our capitals,'' and he reciprocated by taking Baker to Lake Baikal in eastern Siberia. ``We have a lot of business to do with the secretary of state, for 10 years maybe,'' Shevardnadze said only a few weeks ago. Baker invited the foreign minister to his hometown, Houston, where they plotted last week a U.S. aid package that will provide up to $1 billion in credits for the purchase of food and other agricultural commodities to help the Soviets through the winter. As they toured the Johnson Space Center, Shevardnadze quipped that maybe their next meeting ought to be held in space. And as he sat at the control of a mock-up Shuttle, Shevardnadze could not resist. ``I'm flying, I'm flying,'' he called out, with a broad grin. And he declared Houston the best city in America. At that same two-day meeting, Baker advised Shevardnadze that the heavy-handed approach the Kremlin was taking to separationists in the Baltics and to profiteers in Moscow and other large cities could imperil U.S. assistance. It was like preaching to the choir. A U.S. official, recalling Shevardnadze's more than five years as foreign minister, said ``he has come across consistently as a truly committed democrat. He said perestroika (economic reconstruction) and democratization cannot be separated.'' His resignation was attributed by this official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, ``to the domestic drift to the right.'' Baker and Shervardnadze met 19 times this year alone, from Siberia and New York to Paris, Moscow, Helsinki and Namibia. They were on a first-name basis, and Baker, at a news conference Thursday, paid tribute to his superpower partner. ``I have known Eduard Shevardnadze to be a man of his word, a man of courage, conviction and principle,'' Baker said. ``I'm convinced that he is committed to peaceful reform - political and economic - in the Soviet Union.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Attorney Draws Up Contempt Charges Against CNN in Noriega Case
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors worked on criminal contempt charges Thursday against CNN for allegedly violating a judge's order prohibiting the network from airing tapes of Manuel Noriega's prison telephone calls. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler announced his intention last week to press contempt charges against the network because it apparently defied his initial order banning use of the audio tapes. Hoeveler eventually allowed Cable News Network to broadcast the tapes, ruling they did not violate Noriega's right to a fair trial on charges of providing safe passage for Colombia drug traffickers through Panama. The contempt charges were expected to be ready in a few days, said Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office. Because the order is against CNN and parent Turner Broadcasting System Inc. as corporations, any penalties would take the form of fines - not jail terms, Ms. Cossin said. ``CNN is confident that if and when a trial is held on the issue of contempt, its actions will be vindicated,'' CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Takes Aggressive Posture, Warns Saddam of US Air Might
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Fitzwater on Waller, inserting 1 graf after 6th graf, Saddam must; adds 1 graf on Egyptian troops at end
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon adopted an aggressive stance a day after a senior officer questioned American combat readiness in the Persian Gulf, warning Saddam Hussein that U.S. air power could punish Iraq even if ground forces were not ready for all-out war by Jan. 15. Pentagon officials visiting the gulf and senior officers already there said Thursday that Saddam should not interpret the comments by the deputy commander of America's gulf forces as a sign the United States would not attack until well past the U.N. deadline for withdrawal from Kuwait. Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller began the controversy in comments Wednesday to reporters accompanying Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, on their week-long gulf trip. Waller said ground forces yet to arrive in the region might not be combat-ready until well into February and recommended that President Bush delay any military action until then. Bush talked over the gulf situation privately with members of Congress on Thursday, saying according to several of them that he believes Saddam is underestimating U.S. power and intentions. Saddam must be made aware that ``if we get into an armed situation, he's going to get his ass kicked,''' Rep. Elton Gallegly, R-Calif., quoted Bush as saying. Bush's remark was confirmed by another person at the meeting. As for Waller, Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said merely, ``It never hurts to build in a little uncertainty about what our intentions are as it relates to Jan. 15. ... It doesn't cause us any grief to have a little uncertainty in the mind of (Saddam Hussein) about exactly when you might choose to enforce the U.N. sanctions.'' The commander of Army forces in Saudi Arabia, Lt. Gen. John Yeosock, was far more optimistic that Waller in comments Thursday. ``Clearly, we are ready to perform whatever mission we are called upon to carry out,'' Yeosock said. He promised ``a violent, fast battle'' if war begins. Other officials did not dispute the essence of Waller's non-readiness assessment, though there was private criticism that he had been too open and might have hurt the effort to persuade Saddam that Bush might order an attack on Jan. 15 or very soon thereafter. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said merely that an important principle he learned in the Marine Corps was that ``it is critical to preserve the element of surprise.'' If nothing else, Waller's statements and those of other officials seemed to support the idea that an early attack would heavily feature air assaults designed to weaken Iraq's war machine and give still-arriving U.S. ground forces more time to prepare. Yeosock said that although Iraq continues to pour troops into Kuwait and southern Iraq the reinforcements are less capable troops and the Iraqi occupation force is near its maximum-force potential. Iraq also urged its citizens to stockpile oil in a new indication the Iraqis were girding for war. A Pentagon spokesman in Washington said an additional 10,000 U.S. troops arrived in Saudi Arabia this week, pushing the total American force to 280,000 soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines. The spokesman, Bob Hall, said U.S. intelligence sources put the Iraqi force in and around Kuwait at 510,000. In Saudi Arabia, as Cheney and Powell huddled in daylong, private meetings with commanders, spokesman Pete Williams said Cheney was ``not displeased'' by Waller's comments. But Williams issued a brief statement saying Cheney would not reach conclusions of his own about the status of the deployment until the end of his five-day trip and then, unlike Waller, would share his advice only with the president. And Williams, in a clear effort to attach a military threat to the U.N. deadline, said some of the U.S. firepower would be at full strength by the deadline. ``The air part of the force, for example, reaches its level of readiness earlier than the others,'' Williams said. A senior Pentagon official, speaking privately, said all combat aircraft committed to the gulf would be in place by Jan. 15 and Saddam should be deeply worried about that deadline. As for ground forces, Yeosock said, ``We will do everything in our power to apply maximum power in minimum time to maintain the highest, up-tempo battle ever recorded.'' Yeosock said American forces had taken extensive steps to prepare for combat on a ``dirty battlefield'' in the event Saddam uses chemical weapons. He said Iraqi forces are stacked behind each other in defensive lines and have dug extensive fortifications that include mine fields and barbed wire. Asked if U.S. ground forces could crash through, he said, ``I wouldn't say it's easy but we can do it.'' In other gulf developments suggestive of war preparation on Thursday: - Ireland urged its citizens to leave the region by Jan. 15, and Bangladesh asked its people to leave Iraq and Kuwait immediately. - Turkey was requesting reinforcements from fellow NATO members, asking that a land and air force of 5,000 men be in place on its border with Iraq by Jan. 15, said a senior NATO source in Brussels, Belgium. - A spokesman for Britain's Royal Navy said two landing ships will join two others already in the gulf by Jan. 15, giving Britain added capability for involvement in any amphibious assault on the coast of Kuwait. - Egypt sent more troops to Saudi Arabia, part of the additional 7,000 soldiers that President Hosni Mubarak has pledged to reinforce the 20,000-man Egyptian force in the kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Affirms FCC Decision to Pull Radio Station's License
DOC.TEXT: A Federal Communications Commission decision that the owner of a small radio station in Fredonia, N.Y., can neither renew his license nor sell the business was upheld on Thursday by the U.S. Court of Appeals. The FCC decided in March 1989 not to renew Catoctin Broadcasting Corp.'s license for the 250-watt station, WBUZ-AM, on grounds that owner Henry Serafin had discriminated in his hiring practices, lied to the commission and held a contest in which he kept the prize. ``We defer to the commission's expertise and judgment,'' a three-judge panel on the appeals court wrote. This was the first time in a decade that the FCC had pulled a license on character grounds. Only about 100 stations have lost their licenses since the FCC was founded in 1934. Serafin, who learned of the decision Thursday from The Associated Press, said he did not know what he would do next. ``I'm in shock right now,'' he said from the station, about 30 miles south of Buffalo. ``I have to take a day or two to think this thing out.'' He said he was considering asking the appeals court for a rehearing. Another option would be an appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court. In the meantime, Serafin said he could continue to broadcast. In 1981, Catoctin's application to renew its license was challenged by the Chatauqua County Rural Ministry Inc.; the Dunkirk, N.Y., chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People; and the local branch of the League of Women Voters. Among the charges against Serafin was that he had discriminated against a black job applicant in 1980. The three groups said Serafin had called the woman's employment agency and asked, ``Don't you have any white girls to send me?'' adding that the woman ``would make charcoal look white.'' In running a contest at the station in 1982, Serafin also allegedly kept the grand prize, a stereo system, for himself, and gave another prize, a trip to Niagara Falls, to a favored advertiser. In addition, Serafin repeatedly refused to make Catoctin's public file available to citizens. The file contains a station's filings with the FCC and citizen complaints. In 1986, an administrative law judge denied the station's application for renewal, saying that Serafin was ``dishonest, untrustworthy and unreliable.'' Serafin appealed the ruling and the case went to an FCC review board. The board concurred with the decision, which was affirmed by the full commission in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Credit Board President Named
DOC.TEXT: Kenneth L. Peoples, acting president and chief executive officer of the Farm Credit System Assistance Board, was named to that post Thursday by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. Peoples had been general counsel and corporate secretary to the board before being named to the acting posts Aug. 15. Yeutter is its chairman. The board is a government corporation created by Congress in 1987 to provide help to the Farm Credit System, a farmer-owned network of cooperative lenders. Yeutter also announced the appointment of Kathleen M. Mullarkey as general counsel and corporate secretary. She had been acting in that capacity since Aug. 15. Before that, she was deputy general counsel to the board.

DOC.HEAD: Advocates for AIDS Sufferers Call for Speedy Experimental Drugs Approval
DOC.TEXT: Advocates for people with AIDS called Thursday for the federal government and drug manufacturers to move faster in getting two experimental anti-AIDS drugs approved. They said many thousands of AIDS patients need access to dideoxyinosine, known as ddI, and dideoxycytidine, or ddC, because AZT, the only approved anti-viral AIDS therapy, does not work or is no longer effective for them. ``Our patients know these newer drugs are probably not cures and that all the research is not done to determine their long-term complications,'' said Dr. Peter Hawley, medical director of the Whitman-Walker Clinic in Washington. ``But many would be understandably happy to have a chance at having a `long-term' complication,'' he said. The Food and Drug Administration, whose job it is to approve new drugs, said neither of the companies making the drugs has applied for approval, and the agency cannot move ahead until they do. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. is providing ddI to about 1,750 people in clinical trials and more than 14,500 patients in an expanded access program, said spokeswoman Susan Yarin. This larger number includes patients for whom AZT does not work or who do not live close enough to a trial to participate. The company plans to submit a new drug application, or NDA, in the first quarter of 1991, which extends from January through March, she said. ``We are having an ongoing discussion with FDA regarding the makeup of the NDA submission,'' she said. Once submitted, FDA review of the data takes months. For AZT, the FDA moved at its quickest pace, approving it in four months. Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. is distributing ddC to about 1,000 patients in clinical trials and about 1,000 in an expanded access program, said spokesman Paul Oestreicher. Company researchers will evaluate the data next month and determine whether it is favorable enough to go ahead with an NDA, he said. Dr. Gene Zaglin, a Washington physician and a volunteer with Project Inform, an AIDS education group, estimated that as many as 20,000 people currently have no access to either drug but could benefit from them. These are people who have AIDS or who are infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Tusk Turns Out to Be That of Ancient Mastodon
DOC.TEXT: What some people initially believed was the tusk of a circus elephant shot in 1816 was actually that of an ice-age mastodon, museum officials said Thursday. Using two methods of radiocarbon dating, experts confirmed the tusk was 10,500 years old. It belonged to a mastodon that roamed Maine when Indians first ventured into the region, the experts said. ``What's so exciting about these dates is that until now we have had no evidence to suggest that the earliest Indians might have hunted elephants in the Maine region,'' said archaeologist Bruce Bourque of the Maine State Museum. Museum Curator Gary Hoyle learned about the tusk while seeking items for an exhibit on prehistoric Maine. Museum officials believed the tusk was that of a creature that lived sometime around the end of the last ice age, ``but we had to prove our analysis was right'' before putting it on display, said Paul E. Rivard, director of the state museum. The tusk, about 4 feet long, was unearthed in the southern Maine town of Scarborough in 1959. The discovery generated considerable interest, which faded when stories circulated that the tusk belonged to a circus elephant shot in 1816. Research verified the bones of the circus elephant, ``Old Bet,'' were exhumed after a brief burial and sent to the American Museum of Natural History in New York. Samples of the tusk, then housed at the University of Maine at Presque Isle, were taken to the state museum for radiocarbon testing. Rivard said confirmation of the tusk's age provides the first evidence that mastodons lived in Maine when Indians first arrived in the area. It's the only mammal bone yet to be identified from the end of the ice age in Maine. ``This is an extremely important find,'' Rivard said. Several rib bones were discovered with the tusk 31 years ago, but they cannot be located now. Experts believe the rest of the mastodon's skeleton may still be at the site. Museum officials hope to conduct more extensive study of the site next year, Rivard said.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Legislator Reported Questioned over Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors on Thursday questioned a governing party legislator about allegations he failed to pay $7 million in income taxes on stock profits, including some gained on insider information, news reports said. Officials at the prosecutor's office refused to comment on the case of Toshiyuki Inamura, 55, a member of the House of Representatives from Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's Liberal Democratic Party. He served as director general of the Environment Agency from July 1976 to November 1987. The party was rocked last year by a scandal over donations and discount stock deals for dozens of influential politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen by Recruit Co., an information services conglomerate accused of trying to influence government policy. The affair led to the resignation of two prime ministers - one to take responsibility for the scandal and the other to take responsibility for resulting election losses. Kaifu, chosen for his clean reputation, was installed as prime minister and vowed reforms to regain public trust in politics. In the Inamura case, however, the press reports said the stock earnings went for his personal use. The reports, in Japan's major national newspapers, said Inamura allegedly received $20.8 million in stock profits from 1986 to 1988, and evaded taxes on at least $7.46 million. Some of his stock transactions allegedly were based on information from Mitsuhiro Kotani, now on trial on charges of manipulating stock prices. The reports said prosecutors searched Inamura's home and offices on Wednesday, and questioned him Wednesday and Thursday. They said he allegedly used the names of secretaries and supporters in his stock transactions to conceal his income.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department to Review TWA-American Airlines Deal
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Thursday it would review a proposed $625 million deal between TWA and American Airlines to determine whether the sale of international routes and airport facilities would violate antitrust laws. The department made its announcement after receiving a request for an antitrut investigation from Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., who opposes the sale. Danforth, in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, said the proposed deal ``inevitably will lead to a dramatic reduction in domestic airline competition.'' Danforth is the senior Republican on the Senate Commerce Committee, which handles airline issues, and has been a leading critic of consolidation in the airline industry. TWA has a major hub of operation at the St. Louis airport. American Airlines earlier this week proposed buying all of TWA's routes from the United States to London and TWA's takeoff and landing rights at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport. It also would acquire TWA's gates at the Chicago airport. Gina Talamona, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department, said the agency's antitrust division would look at the transaction proposed by the airlines. She said the department would respond to Danforth's request, but it routinely reviews major acquisition agreements involving airlines. The route sales must be approved by the Transportation Department, but Danforth said the Justice Department has the power under antitrust laws to ``investigate and remedy market practices and structures that deny low-priced competitive air service to the traveling public.''

DOC.HEAD: Deep Freeze in the West and Plains; Rain in the Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Unusually cold and windy weather continued Thursday to move across the United States, bringing snow to unexpected places and frigid wind chills to others. Santa Maria, Calif., received their first recorded snow, though not enough fell to measure. Temperatures in the 20s were expected through the weekend in Southern California. Devastating wind chills were recorded at Rock Springs, Wyo., with 77 below zero, 75 below in Livingston, Mont., between 70 and 80 below zero over much of the Black Hills of South Dakota and 55 below in the Uintah Basin of Utah. Low temperature records set included 15 degrees in Astoria, Ore., 26 below in Casper, Wyo., 11 in Eugene, Ore., 25 below in Great Falls, Mont., 11 in Olympia, Wash., 23 in Sacramento, Calif., 14 in Seattle-Tacoma, Wash., and 21 below in Sheridan, Wyo. Daytona Beach, Fla. hit a record high 83 degrees and Jacksonville, Fla., reported a record 82. Rain fell at midday along the southern coast of California and in south-central Arizona, changing to snow over central and northeast Arizona. Snow fell over northern New Mexico, Colorado, Wyoming, southern Idaho, central and eastern Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, most of Kansas, the Oklahoma and Texas panhandles, much of Iowa, Minnesota, northwest Wisconsin and eastern upper Michigan. Freezing rain extended from southwest Oklahoma into southeast Kansas, northwest Missouri and south central Iowa. Rain reached from northern Mississippi through Tennessee, northern Alabama, into parts of Georgia and the Carolinas. Thursday morning's low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 28 below zero at Butte, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 24 below zero at Butte to 88 at McAllen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Episcopal Bishop Urges Bush to Eschew War
With AM-US-Gulf Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The highest bishop of President Bush's church, just just back from Baghdad, Thursday implored Bush not to resort to war to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Presiding Episcopal Bishop Edmond L. Browning said, ``I really believe in the deepest part of my conviction that God does not desire this kind of destruction.'' ``I don't think it would serve anybody's interests, to say nothing about our national interests,'' Browning told reporters outside the White House after meeting with Bush. Browning and 17 other U.S. religious leaders met with Iraqi religious figures in hopes of promoting a peaceful solution to the crisis. They also stopped in Cyprus and Jordan. Browning said he told Bush ``my belief from everything I heard on the trip - and it confirmed my own conviction - that war is not an option to solve the problems of either Kuwait and Iraq or any of the other Middle Eastern situation.'' Browning, leader of the United States' 2.5 million Episcopalians, said he told the president he believes this is ``a moment when there's the possibility for some real blessedness to happen'' to solve many problems in the Middle East. ``I said that I thought he could give that kind of moral leadership at this time in history,'' he said. Bush asked Browning, ``How can we morally not do anything?'' about Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, according to the bishop's account. And, he said, the president said it is not appropriate to try to link the problems of the Middle East together. Saddam Hussein has attempted to link a Kuwait solution to resolving the Palestinian question, and the White House has resisted such a linkage. The bishop carried a copy of an Amnesty International report on atrocities in Kuwait that Bush had given him. Bush told a congressional delegation earlier Thursday that he had ``crossed a Rubicon in his own mind in terms of being willing and able to use force and defend the principles involved,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Browning said Bush did not use that metaphor in their meeting. ``I hope that he hasn't crossed that line, and I was trying to be as persuasive as I could, calling upon his leadership to find another solution,'' said the bishop.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Joins in U.N. Vote Deploring Israeli Deportations of Arabs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Israeli, PLO quotes, monitoring specifics. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY32,134,136,JRL1,3
DOC.TEXT: The United States on Thursday joined in supporting a unanimous Security Council resolution that deplored Israel's deportation of Palestinians and called for U.N. monitoring of their safety. It marked the first time the council moved to actively involve itself and the secretary-general in protecting Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories, seized in the 1967 Middle East War. Arab diplomats called it a major step forward in achieving international protection of Palestinins. At the same time, Washington achieved a diplomatic victory over Arab and nonaligned states in the council by preventing any reference to a Middle East peace conference in the resolution. The U.S. demand had held up the vote for weeks. Instead, the issue was included in a separate, nonbinding statement by this month's council president, Yemen, which was approved by the council. Thursday's 15-0 vote was the third time in two months that the United States declined to exercise its veto and shield its Israeli ally. Its vote was seen as a move to preserve the U.S.-led multinational coalition arrayed against Iraq's Saddam Hussein. A U.S. veto on an issue considered vital to Arabs could have undermined their confidence in the U.S. Persian Gulf mission, diplomats said. The resolution asks U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to become involved in assuring the safety of Palestinians in the territories and ``to monitor and observe the situation ... on an urgent basis.'' It asks that U.N. personnel and resources already in the region be used to help protect Palestinians and that the Security Council be kept informed. Israel rejected any such deployment of U.N. personnel and change of mandate of U.N. organizations in the region to deal with Palestinians. Its ambassador, Yoram Aridor, told the council: ``We will not accommodate any discriminatory procedure or treatment.'' The United States joined in opposing any change in the role of U.N. organizations in the region. It was not clear whether the council's call for monitoring could or would be carried out in view of Israel's oppostion. Diplomats said U.N. personnel for any such observation team probably would be drawn from the U.N. Truce Supervision Organizaiton, which has 291 military observers in the region, or the U.N. Relief and Works Agency for Palestinians in the Middle East. UNRWA, with a staff of 2,300 staff, provides social services for about 700,000 Palestinians. Israel rejects U.N. involvement in what it calls its internal affairs in the territories. PLO observer M. Nasser Al-Kidwa termed the resolution ``an important and substantive contribution to provide protection to the Palestinian people under Israeli occupation and contribute to resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict.'' American Jewish groups denounced the U.S. vote Thursday. The Anti-Defamation League of B`nai B`rith said Washington ``fell into Saddam Hussein's linkage trip.'' It said the resolution ``still inflicts significant, undeserved damage on Israel.'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said the resolution did not indicate a change in U.S. policy on the Middle East. He said the U.S. vote ``is intended to demonstrate ... our deep concern about the situation in the occupied territories.'' But he also said: ``The council ought to be willing to say to the Palestinians that any use of violence to achieve their ends is plain wrong. We lament the continued violence, particularly in Israel, where innocent people have been the victims of numerous stabbings.'' Aridor complained bitterly in his speech that the council rushed to condemn Israel's decison to expel four Moslem extremists believed linked to the recent murders of three Jews - ``But the blood of Jews is not even worthy of a mention.'' Al-Kidwa of the Palestine Liberation Organization said in an angry rebuttal that only Israel was killing unarmed Palestinians in the uprising against Israel domination. In Thursday's separate statement, the council said an international peace conference should facilitate a lasting resolution of the Arab-Israeli conflict. But it said there was no agreement on when a conference shoud be held. The United States sought to ensure the resolution did not link resolving the Arab-Israeli conflict with settlement of the gulf crisis. To meet the U.S. demand, the presidential statement said the Arab-Iraeli conflict was a separate issue and had to be ``addressed independently on its own merits.'' Unlike the resolution, the presidential statement has no legal force. In the resolution, the Security Council ``deplores the decision by the government of Israel, the occupying power, to resume deportation of Palestinian civilians in the occupied territories.'' Israel has announced plans to deport four Palestinians it claims have terrorist links. Security Council efforts to address the Palestinian problem began after the Israeli police killed at least 17 Palestinians at the Al-Aksa Mosque on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem on Oct. 8. The resolution urges Israel to abide by the Fourth Geneva Convention of 1949 regulating treatment of civilians in occupied lands. Israel says the convention does not apply. The resolution asks Perez de Cuellar and the Red Cross to consider convening a meeting of the 164 signatories of the Convention to consider what measures might be taken under the convention to help Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Mayor Can Reassume Office Despite Conviction, Court Rules
DOC.TEXT: A flamboyant mayor forced from office six years ago by a felony conviction can resume his old job after winning a recent election, the state Supreme Court ruled Thursday. The court struck down two challenges to the eligiblity of Vincent A. ``Buddy'' Cianci Jr. to hold office. Cianci was forced to resign six years ago. A city charter prohibited felons sentenced to prison time from holding office. Cianci's 10-year reign as mayor was marred by public corruption and ended shortly after his 1984 conviction of felony assault on a man he thought was having an affair with his estranged wife. He ran for mayor in the Nov. 6 election and won by 317 votes. Those challenging Cianci's eligiblity to hold office argued that a 1986 state constitutional amendment prohibited felons from running for office until three years after finishing their sentences. Cianci's five-year suspended sentence ended in April 1989. The high court said the constitutional amendment did not apply to convictions that occurred before its adoption.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Amnesty Law Passed
DOC.TEXT: Parliament passed an amnesty law Thursday affecting all those sentenced by the former Communist regime since 1945 for crimes against the republic and other politial crimes, the state BTA news agency said. It also provides for restoration of confiscated property and reimbursement of fines levied on those sentenced for political reasons, the agency reported. BTA noted that other amnesty laws were adopted the past year but said none was as comprehensive as that passed Thursday. The report did not say how many people would be affected or what the reparations would cost. Communist one-party rule here ended with free elections in June. President Zhelyu Zhelev said Thursday he is confident that Bulgaria, with its new ``efficient'' government, can catch up with Hungary and Czechoslovakia in implementing political reforms. Parliament late Wednesday approved Bulgaria's first coalition government, which is no longer controlled by the former Communist Party, now the Socialist Party.
