Premier Dimitar Popov, an independent, 63-year-old lawyer, presented his new Cabinet after nearly two weeks of wrangling between the two main political groups, the Socialists and the Union of Democratic Forces. Popov was chosen on Dec.7 to lead a new coalition government after strikes and street protests forced Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov and his government to quit last month. For months Bulgaria has been embroiled in its worst political and economic crisis. Some foodstuffs and electricity are rationed. Other foods and many consumer items are in short supply or unavailable. Inflation is rising and stood at about 40 percent over the six-month period from May to November, published reports said. In a speech to foreign journalists in Sofia, Zhelev complained that ``valuable time'' was wasted in deciding on a coalition government. He said it was important the new government's economic departments are headed by people with common views on economic reform despite different political affiliations. Parliament approved Popov's Cabinet in a secret late-night ballot. Five ministers besides the premier are not affiliated with any party. Zhelev said the formula on which the new Cabinet is based ``makes it a strong and efficient government'' and forecast that help now would be coming from the International Monetary Fund.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here are extracts from the resignation speech of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
``I am resigning. Don't react and don't curse me. Let it be my contribution, protest if you will, against dictatorship.'' --- ``Dictatorship is coming - I say this with all responsibility. No one knows what kind of dictatorship it will be, and who will come - what kind of dictator, and what kind of system.'' --- ``The future belongs to democracy and freedom!''

DOC.HEAD: Democrat Declared Winner in Ohio Attorney General Race
DOC.TEXT: Lee Fisher was declared the winner Thursday in the race for Ohio attorney general - by 1,234 votes - six weeks after the closest statewide election in Ohio history. Fisher, a Democrat, defeated Republican Paul Pfeifer 1,680,698 to 1,679,464. The difference was 0.03 percent of the total vote, according to the recount involving all of Ohio's 88 counties. ``This election teaches us two things. Every vote counts and our election system in Ohio is a good system,'' said Secretary of State Sherrod Brown. Fisher could be sworn in Jan. 14, unless Pfeifer contests the election. Pfeifer's campaign has said it might challenge the results based on voting irregularities in Mahoning County. Fisher, a state senator, declared victory after learning of the vote. Pfeifer, also a state senator, was not immediately available for comment. There was no answer late Thursday at his legislative office.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Workers Restoring Nicaragua's Service After Strike
DOC.TEXT: A small group of replacement workers manned the country's international phone lines Thursday, a day after riot police persuaded long-distance operators to end a strike. Wednesday's strike by operators loyal to the leftist Sandinista Front put the country out of touch with the outside world for five hours. The strikers were acting to support about 400 telephone employees in three provinces south of the capital who stopped work two weeks ago to demand 40 percent salary increases. Ernesto Robleto, deputy minister of the state telecommunications company Telcor, said international lines were back under control Thursday, but only a handful of non-Sandinista operators were working. Usually, about 30 operators connect callers with Mexico and Central America, while another 30 work calls to the rest of the world. On Thursday, however, a total of 15 replacement operators handled all calls. Direct-dial customers account for only about 5 percent of calls. The non-Sandinista replacements were brought in after riot police were able to convince strikers to end their occupation of company telephone offices. With so few operators, international telephone lines to the outside world were jammed Thursday and callers faced long waits, especially to reach Mexico and Central America. Police units were stationed at the two main Telcor buildings and access was restricted. There are 4,400 telecommunications workers nationwide. Nicaragua has been wracked by successive waves of labor unrest since President Violeta Chamorro won February elections, ousting the Sandinista government of President Daniel Ortega. The Sandinistas, now in the opposition, remain in control of much of the country's workforce as well as its administration. Most telecommunications workers are holdovers from the leftist Sandinista government. Sandinista-allied workers held national strikes in May and June that forced Mrs. Chamorro to drastically modify her plans for cutting government spending. The telephone workers now want a 40 percent pay raise, reversal of the dismissals of 30 workers, and a resumption of pay for the employees in the three southern provinces who started the strike. Robleto, the Telcor deputy minister, said he decided to call riot police Wednesday night when Sandinista workers took over the rooms where international operators work. About 18 riot police talked the strikers into leaving the occupied rooms, where they had holed up for five hours. ``The police told us that if we didn't leave the good way, they'd make us leave the bad way,'' said Carlos Olivares, who has worked for three years as an international operator. ``Because most of our comrades are women, we decided to leave peacefully. We didn't want them to get hurt,'' Olivares said.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Says 300 Executed in Chad
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International said Friday that members of Chad's Presidential Guard killed more than 300 political prisoners shortly before President Hissein Habre fled to Cameroon on Dec. 1. The human rights organization said the victims had been detained in secret at Habre's headquarters in N'Djamena, the capital. Many bodies were found in the headquarters and others appear to have been thrown in the Chari River, the group, based in London, said in a written statement. Amnesty urged Chad's new president, Idriss Deby, to introduce measures to prevent similar killings in the future. It proposed an inquiry into the fate of hundreds of political prisoners who ``disappeared'' between 1982 and 1990 during Habre's presidency. The organization said hundreds of political prisoners were released after Habre's ouster. Released prisoners have said many of those detained in 1987 and 1989 were executed in secret, usually at Habre's headquarters. Others died as the result of torture, malnutrition, illness and medical neglect, Amnesty said. Chad, an African nation with more than 5.4 million residents, became independent from France in 1960.

DOC.HEAD: Resignation Ends a Special Relationship
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT spelling Shevardnadze, restoring dropped ``S.''
DOC.TEXT: The abrupt resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze removes from the warming superpower relationship a close ally of Mikhail Gorbachev whose candid revelations of his country's troubles and hopes prompted an amiable U.S. response. But Baker, at a news conference Thursday, said he had been reassured by the Soviet president there would be no change in Soviet foreign policy. ``Since the United States-Soviet partnership serves the interest of peace internationally and the process of reform domestically, we, of course, expect that to be the case and we will be watching events closely in the weeks ahead,'' Baker said. ``I am proud to call this man a friend,'' Baker said. He called Shevardnadze ``a man of his word, of courage and conviction.''
DOC.HEAD: This year, 5th graf
White Supremacists Sentenced in Black Man's Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Two white supremacist ``skinheads'' were sentenced Thursday to life in prison for gunning down a black man in 1988. Matthew Faessel, 19, and Michael Stringer, 18, were sentenced on first-degree murder convictions for the killing of Tony Montgomery. The two must serve at least 26 years in prison before they are eligible for parole. In addition, they received 18-year terms for conspiracy to commit murder and firing a weapon into an occupied building. Faessel blamed alcohol and drug abuse for the fatal shooting Dec. 10, 1988, and expressed sorrow for Montgomery's family. Montgomery, 27, was shot in his sister's front yard. ``I hope they feel justice has been served,'' Faessel said. A jury convicted the men in October and recommended life terms. The 18-year sentences are to run consecutively with the life sentences. During the trial, Angela Stanley, 18, testified she accompanied Faessel and Stringer on a hunt for a black man to kill following a party attended by neo-Nazi skinheads. She testified the men were enraged when a woman at the party said she had been raped by a black man. Ms. Stanley said she drove the car, Stringer rolled down the window and Faessel fired the fatal shot from the back seat. She also testified that Faessel and Stringer laughed as Montgomery lay dying. Ms. Stanley pleaded guilty to second-degree murder and was sentenced to 15 years. Stringer's attorney, John Ohlson, argued that his client should receive less prison time because he did not pull the trigger. Assistant District Attorney Ed Basl said both shared equal guilt.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Psychology Professor Will Return to The Classroom
DOC.TEXT: The University of Western Ontario is letting professor Philippe Rushton return to the classroom, saying it no longer fears his controversial ideas on race and intelligence will prompt violent protests. Since the beginning of this academic year, Rushton has been forced to tape his 90-minute lectures on Theories of Personality. Students enrolled in the course are obliged to pick up the tapes, view them and telephone the professor with any questions. Rushton created an uproar last year by announcing that his research showed whites are more intelligent than blacks, Orientals are more intelligent than whites, and the reasons are genetic and evolutionary. University officials said last fall that forcing Rushton to tape his lectures was necessary to prevent possible disturbances on campus. There had been a demonstration by about 300 students last spring. Rushton claimed the university was infringing on his academic freedom and disrupting the teacher-student relationship. ``I'm very happy to report that I have won the battle not to have to instruct by videotape,'' Rushton said Wednesday in a telephone interview from his office at the university in London, Ontario. ``I'm absolutely delighted,'' he added. ``I'm looking forward to it. After the sterility of teaching by tape, it will be a great joy to actually see flesh-and-blood students.'' Beginning with the new term beginning next month, he will teach two courses, Introduction to Personality and The Psychology of Pro-Social and Anti-Social Behavior. ``This was simply the decision we had in mind all along,'' said Tom Collins, vice president for academics at the university. ``Things seemed relatively peaceful the first term,'' said Collins. ``The protesting students seemed to understand and recognize that people have rights to teach and be taught, and we are putting him back in the classroom in the belief that those who wish to protest will respect the rights of others.'' Rushton, 46, has been at Western Ontario for 13 years. He created an uproar in January 1989, when he described his theories during a 20-minute talk to the American Association for the Advancement of Science in San Francisco. Describing his theories, he says: ``I conclude that on 50 or 60 different measures, Orientals and blacks are at opposite ends of a continuum with whites, or Caucasoids, falling consistently somewhere in the middle. These measures include intelligence, sexual behavior, brain size, law-abidingness, social organization skills, personality and temperament and speed of physical maturation.'' Rushton claims there is ``a virtual self-imposed taboo on the scientific study of race differences from a genetic perspective.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Appeared on ``Geraldo'' Sues Show for $28 Million
DOC.TEXT: A man who appeared on ``Geraldo'' sued the host, Geraldo Rivera, and a producer Thursday for $28 million, claiming they revealed his identity after promising not to do so. Carl J. Ober said in his lawsuit that he appeared on a segment of the syndicated television show titled ``Telephone Terror,'' with women who were victimized by telephone harassment. Ober, from Albany, appeared as an alleged telephone harasser under a written and verbal agreement with Rivera that his identity would not be revealed, the lawsuit said. On at least two occasions during the show, Rivera called him ``Carl'' and on at least two other occasions referred to him as Carl Ober, the lawsuit said. The show aired Feb. 15, 1990. The lawsuit said Rivera disclosed Ober's occupation and place of residence and identified a psychologist who is treating him. The lawsuit said that on at least four occasions, Ober's face was shown with the words, ``Made obscene phone calls,'' and Rivera called him a ``sick person'' who ``verbally raped'' women. There was no answer Thursday night at the show's offices. Named as defendants in the lawsuit are: Rivera; a producer, Marilyn Kaskel; and the Investigative News Group Inc., Rivera's production company. The lawsuit said Ober suffered ``ridicule, embarrassment, vexation, humiliation, mental and emotional distress.''

DOC.HEAD: Slovak Government Apologizes to Jews
DOC.TEXT: The Slovak government Thursday for the first time formally apologized for World War II deportation of thousands of Jews, many of whom were murdered in Nazi death camps. ``Today, after one year of life in liberty, we ... as the representatives of Slovakia feel the moral obligation to publicly declare to our fellow Jewish citizens our remorse for this crime,'' a declaration of the Slovak government and parliament said. It was carried by the state CTK news agency. Czechoslovakia was split in two during World War II. A German protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia was set up on the occupied Czech territories. Meanwhile, the country's eastern part formed a fascist Slovak state, deporting most of its Jewish citizens to death camps between 1942-44. Official Czechoslovak history in four decades of Communist rule was silent about the deportations, while condemning the fascist regime for other reasons. After Czechoslovakia's democratic revolution last year, Slovakia is seeking more independence and to establish its own national identity. War crimes committed by the Nazi-puppet Slovak regime during World War II are now considered one of the most shameful episodes in Slovak history. There were about 315,000 Jews in pre-war Czechoslovakia, and the capital of Prague was a traditional center of Jewish culture. Now, Czechoslovakia's Jewish community numbers only about 12,000.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Workers' Union Chief Denies Alleged Control by Mob
DOC.TEXT: The president of a union local representing Atlantic City casino workers on Thursday denied federal charges that it is mob-controlled. It was the first public response from William Roy Silbert, president of Local 54 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union to a civil lawsuit filed by the Justice Department. The anti-racketeering lawsuit seeks control of the local, which represents 22,000 hotel, bar and restaurant workers in Atlantic City casinos and in other southern New Jersey cities. The lawsuit also seeks to restrict the union's international president from involvement in the local's affairs, the removal of Silbert and five other officials and the forfeiture of profits it says were obtained illegally. ``The announced civil RICO suit ... comes as a shock,'' Silbert said at a news conference, referring to the Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations statute. ``My first reaction is one of outrage and ... any allegations that individuals others than Local 54 members have influence on our activities are totally false,'' he said. ``The government knows that neither Local 54, nor any of its officers, have any `mob' ties or hidden agendas,'' said Silbert, president since 1984. ``They know that. We will not permit union-busting to succeed.'' The lawsuit alleges that the local has been controlled from prison by convicted mob boss Nicodemo ``Little Nicky'' Scarfo. Now serving a 70-year federal prison term in Marion, Ill., for racketeering, Scarfo also has been sentenced to life for murder. ``This is all fantasy,'' union lawyer Bernard Katz said. U.S. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said the government's case was based on evidence gathered in more than two years of investigating, including information from mob informants. The government alleges Scarfo handpicked Silbert for the local union's presidency. Silbert succeeded Francis Gerace, who was forced to step down by the Casino Control Commission because of alleged mob connections. Thornburgh said a court-appointed trustee should run the local because mob members ``through their brutal and often deadly acts of violence and intimidation have destroyed the integrity of the union and its leadership.'' The complaint also contended the mob helped keep control of the local by the 1973 killing of Joseph McGreal, president of Local 170 in Camden, N.J., and the 1980 slaying of John McCullough, who led the roofers union in Philadelphia. Silbert, in a three-page statement he read aloud, said the accusations bewilder him. ``None of us involved in Local 54 activities have done anything wrong,'' Silbert said. ``On the contrary, we serve the cause of collective bargaining and membership representation in the finest manner. Perhaps that is why we are singled out for this vexing government-instituted litigation.''

DOC.HEAD: First Opposition Party Registers in Zambia
DOC.TEXT: Campaigners for Western-style democracy Thursday registered Zambia's first opposition political party in 17 years, pledging to fight elections for control of the presidency and parliament. The Movement for Multiparty Democracy will pose the first major threat to the founder of the nation, President Kenneth Kaunda, and his ruling United National Independence Party since independence from Britain in 1964. It is also the latest in a series of African opposition movements to emerge since the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe. ``It marks a milestone not only in the history of the (Movement for Multi-Party Democracy) but in the history of our country,'' said Arthur Wina, the new chairman, as he formally launched his party in the Lusaka suburb of Kalundu. ``We are confident that we are a majority party,'' declared Wina, who served Kaunda in several Cabinet posts. ``We are only waiting to have this confirmed by the elections results.'' Bowing to mounting pressure for political pluralism, Kaunda amended the Constitution on Monday to legalize opposition parties. Previously, he said multiparty elections for the presidency and the 135-member legislature, now a rubber-stamp body, would be held before October 1991. Wina said the new party favors the promotion of private enterprise, protection of human rights, and guarantees for the accountability of elected representativee. Kaunda's critics have long complained centralized controls have wrecked the economy, private enterprise has been discouraged, civil rights have been violated, and corrupt and inept politicians and bureaucrats have gone unpunished.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Convicted Boss Slain as `Warning' to Dad
DOC.TEXT: The son of a convicted mobster who is considered one of Italy's most powerful crime bosses was shot to death early Thursday in what might be a warning to his imprisoned father. Roberto Cutolo, 28, was shot 10 times in the stomach in Tradate, news reports said. Police say his father, Raffaele, is a key leader of the Camorra, a criminal organization based in the Naples area. Investigators say the elder Cutolo continues to direct his clan's activities from his prison cell in Naples. The father is serving a life term for convictions of various mob-linked crimes, including murder. The Italian state television network RAI reported investigators were looking into the possibility that the son was murdered as a warning to Cutolo from rival clans dealing in drug trafficking and extortion. The younger Cutolo had served a few years in prison for criminal association and had been granted provisional liberty while awaiting trial on charges of extortion and running a prostitution ring. Judicial authorities had ordered him to live in northern Italy and report twice a week to police.

DOC.HEAD: Aircraft Carrier Returns from Mideast for Holiday Homecoming
LaserPhoto GO1
DOC.TEXT: The aircraft carrier USS Independence returned Thursday from the Persian Gulf to a holiday homecoming for its crew of 5,000. ``It's definitely a gift from God,'' aviation ordnance specialist Karl Schroeder said as he held hands with his wife, Cheryl. ``I'm so glad to be home, man.'' The carrier was one of the first U.S. naval vessels deployed to the Gulf after Iraq grabbed Kuwait on Aug. 2. Beside Schroeder on the pier at North Island Naval Air Station was his buddy, Petty Officer Tim Gale. Cradled in Gale's arms was the 4-month-old daughter he was seeing for the first time. ``Check her out. She's beautiful,'' Gale said. Gale's wife, Faye, gave birth to Kayla two months into the Independence's six-month deployment. About 1,500 people greeted the carrier with balloons and signs reading, `Thanks guys,' `Welcome home daddy,' `We love the air boss,' and `Yahoo.' No one seemed bothered by a rare and sudden downpour. ``We can handle anything. We're so excited. We couldn't have asked for a better Christmas present,'' said Jane Zackary as she waved to her husband, Cmdr. Fort Zackary Jr. Mrs. Zackary made the cloth ``air boss'' sign for her husband, who runs the carrier's flight deck. The couple's three children: Fort, 18; Brian, 16; and Erin, 14, held it aloft for their father to see. ``We tried to stay positive (during the Gulf deployment). We knew they would be prepared for whatever came their way but it's a relief to have them home,'' Mrs. Zackary said. She said she still worries that her husband could be recalled to Mideast duty if hostilities break out. The United Nations has set a Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or risk military action. For now the family has set such worries aside, Mrs. Zackary said. ``We're going to savor the moments that we have and hope that we don't go to war,'' she said. ``Nobody wants war.'' The Independence was the third warship to dock in San Diego on Thursday. The guided missile cruiser USS Jouett and the frigate USS Reasoner arrived earlier in the day. The USS Antietam, a guided missile cruiser that spent the past three months in the Gulf supporting Operation Desert Shield, also returned Thursday, pulling into its home port of Long Beach.

DOC.HEAD: Togo Bans Formation of Political Parties; U.S. Aid Doubled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to ADD that U.S. aid is for 1990-91, CLARIFY that government took step away from promises, sted took back promise. Pickup graf 4 pvs, `In its...'
DOC.TEXT: The military government on Thursday took a step back from promises to install a multiparty democracy, announcing that no political parties would be formed for at least another year. The statement came the same day U.S. Ambassador Harmon Kirby said Washington was more than doubling its aid to this West African nation ``to support its development and efforts to install multipartyism and respect for human rights.'' Kirby met Thursday with Togo's leader, Gen. Gnassingbe Eyadema. The ambassador told reporters afterward that the U.S. Congress had decided to increase development aid to Togo from a proposed $4 million to $9 million for 1990-91. In its announcement Thursday, Togo's Ministry of Interior and of Security said the formation of political organizations was banned until the adoption of a new constitution, scheduled for the end of 1991. The ban appeared aimed at inhibiting numerous political movements that have sprung up under the guise of ``social organizations'' since Eyadema promised Oct. 30 to install a multiparty state. It was not clear how they would be affected. Eyadema was forced to make the October announcement after Togo was hit by the strikes and pro-democracy protests and riots that have swept West Africa the past year. In the worst violence, police opened fire on rioters in Lome on Oct. 5, killing three and wounding 34 by the government's count. Since promising democracy, Eyadema has tried to give the impression of moving toward more political freedom. His critics remain unconvinced, joking that Eyadema wants a multiparty democracy without any political opposition. His government has set up a commission to rewrite the constitution to allow political pluralism, but no opposition leaders are among the 109 commission members. Eyadema has dismissed opposition demands that he step down or hold a national conference on democracy. The general has ruled Togo as a one-party state since he seized power in a 1967 coup.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Peace Talks Open, Chief Rebel Leader Absent
DOC.TEXT: Rebel and government leaders began talks Thursday aimed at formally ending Liberia's yearlong civil war but absent was a chief rebel commander. Charles Taylor, chief of the largest rebel group, sent an aide to the talks and breakaway rebel leader Prince Johnson stormed out of the meeting, saying he would not take part in any talks unless Taylor also attended. Representing Taylor at the talks was his aide, Tom Woewiyu. Brig. Hezekiah Bowen, who commands the remnants of slain President Samuel Doe's army, attended the talks, sponsored by the Economic Community of West African States. Conference sources said Johnson met with the leader of Liberia's interim government, professor Amos Sawyer, after he left the meeting and they expected he would be persuaded to return to the talks. Taylor has called Sawyer a West African puppet and has rejected his offer to participate in his caretaker government, which was chosen by Liberian exiles and includes members of rebel factions. Taylor has previously insisted he must lead any interim government. Sawyer's administration is installed in the Liberian capital but a compromise on its composition is a major aim of the negotiations. Taylor's forces control most of the country outside the capital of Monrovia and his agreement is essential for a lasting peace. Johnson and Bowen control most of Monrovia. Gambian Foreign Minister Omar Sey opened Thursday's meeting by urging the rivals to ``seize the momentum gained in Bamako to avoid the recurrence of the scourge of violence and usher in a durable peace.'' All three sides signed a cease-fire agreement in Bamako, capital of Mali, on Nov. 28. Under a West African peace plan, neither Sawyer, the interim president nor his deputy would contest elections proposed next year, to ensure voting is fair. Sey said delegates at the meeting will discuss how a five-nation West African intervention force sent to Monrovia could police the cease-fire. They will also negotiate the composition of an electoral commission and the rules for elections that will be overseen by the West African community and international observers, he said. More than 12,000 civilians were killed and two-thirds of the nation's 2.3 million people were displaced by the Liberian civil war, which began last December when Taylor's forces invaded from neighboring Ivory Coast. Taylor's forces invaded to overthrow Doe, whom they acused of human rights violations and nepotism, but the fighting quickly degenerated into tribal-based killings.

DOC.HEAD: B-1B Bombers Grounded Because of Engine Failures
DOC.TEXT: The Strategic Air Command has grounded all 97 of its B-1B bombers because of recurring engine failure. The command, headquartered here, said Wednesday it would return the bombers to full flying status as soon as possible. The action marks the fifth time in less than two years that the bomber fleet has been grounded. Gen. John T. Chain, Jr., SAC commander-in-chief, ordered the planes grounded after a B-1B engine failed Wednesday while flying near Dyess Air Force Base, Texas. On Oct. 4, an engine on a B-1B based at McConnell Air Force Base, Kan., failed while the bomber flew over southeastern Colorado. In both cases, the bombers landed safely and no one was injured. B-1Bs have four engines. SAC said it suspected fan blades at the front of the engines caused the failures. The grounding means that B-1Bs cannot be flown except for in case of war. The bombers will remain on nuclear alert at U.S. air bases, ready for launch if needed. The planes are permanently based at Ellsworth Air Force Base, S.D., Grand Forks Air Force Base, N.D., Dyess and McConnell. B-1Bs have been certified for use in conventional bombing missions, but SAC still has not trained the bombers' crews for anything other than its strategic nuclear mission. SAC said Chain ordered the planes grounded after discussions with Gen. Charles C. McDonald, commander of the Air Force's Logistics Command in Ohio. Logistics Command is working with the engine's manufacturer, General Electric, to solve the problem, SAC said. Previous groundings occurred in March 1989 for fuel tank problems, in April 1989 for escape hatch problems, after a crash at Dyess in November 1989 and after an engine fell off one of the planes at Dyess in October.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Pleads Innocent in Teaneck Shooting Case
DOC.TEXT: A white Teaneck police officer whose fatal shooting of a black teen-ager set off rioting and charges of racism pleaded innocent Thursday to reckless manslaughter. Officer Gary Spath, 29, bowed his head in prayer before his arraignment in the April 10 shooting death of 16-year-old Phillip Pannell. The slain teen-ager's mother, Thelma Pannell, sobbed. Superior Court Judge Charles DeGisi set bail at $50,000 and released Spath on his own recognizance. The officer was suspended with pay after the shooting. Pannell's death caused community leaders to re-examine race relations in Teaneck, a New York City suburb that had prided itself on tolerance since voluntarily desegregating its schools in the early 1960s. Spath, an eight-year veteran of the Teaneck police force, and a partner responded April 10 to a report of a youth brandishing a gun near a schoolyard. Police said Pannell was reaching into his pocket for a gun when Spath shot him after a brief foot chase. Witnesses say the youth's hands were raised above his head as if in surrender, and an autopsy by a pathologist hired by Pannell's family supported that contention. A candlelight vigil in honor of Pannell the next night turned violent as mobs of angry teen-agers overturned police cars, smashed windows and looted stores. If convicted, Spath faces up to 10 years in prison. A grand jury in July refused to indict Spath. State Attorney General Robert Del Tufo immediately empaneled a second grand jury, saying the county medical examiner botched the autopsy and tainted the first proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Assembly Speaker Pleads Innocent in Alleged Co-op Scam
DOC.TEXT: The speaker of the state Assembly pleaded innocent Thursday to mail-fraud charges stemming from an alleged real-estate scam. Mel Miller and his top aide and former law partner, Jay E. Adolf, pleaded innocent at their arraignment before U.S. District Judge Raymond J. Dearie. Dearie allowed the men to remain free without bail. He set a tentative trial date for Sept. 10. The men were named in a 19-count indictment filed last week in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn, charging them with mail fraud, conspiracy and falsifying documents. Each count is punishable by up to five years in prison and $250,000 in fines. Miller, the state's second-ranking Democrat, would be expelled from the Legislature if convicted. He has been an assemblyman since 1970 and was elected speaker in 1987. Miller told reporters outside court that overambitious prosecutors were stretching the law to make a case against him. Assistant U.S. Attorney Matthew E. Fishbein defended the indictment. Miller and Adolf are accused of cheating clients of their now-dissolved Manhattan law firm in a series of complex cooperative apartment conversions during the mid-1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Military Mourns Comrades Who Died in Helicopter Crash
DOC.TEXT: Military men and women paused in prayer Thursday to remember three members of a Persian Gulf-bound air ambulance company who died in a helicopter crash. ``The conflict in the Middle East has been brought ever so close because of the lives and deaths of these three soldiers,'' Chaplain Alan Heneisen told about 200 people in the chapel at this south-central Missouri army post. Some of the uniformed mourners attended the funeral earlier in the day of 1st Lt. Peter J. Rose in Lincoln, Neb. Funerals were scheduled Friday in Sullivan, Mo., for Chief Warrant Officer Carol L. McKinney, and Saturday in Barnett, Mo., for Staff Sgt. Dallas R. Cooper. The Pentagon said Ms. McKinney was the first woman killed either in the Persian Gulf or the United States in activities connected with Operation Desert Shield. Three gleaming helicopter crew helmets were arranged on a table draped in black near the pulpit of Soldier's Memorial Chapel. Two lighted candles and an open Bible were placed on another table covered with a white cloth. A U.S. flag and two decorated Christmas trees stood nearby. As the quiet chapel was washed with golden late-afternoon sunlight, Heneisen praised the three flyers for their courageous service. ``These people were volunteers for a difficult mission and they really represent America's finest,'' the chaplain said. Heneisen said the three were ``put to the ultimate test: giving their lives. ``We today are gathered under the umbrella of death ... we suffer together as family.'' Maj. Karl Poulsen, commander of the 1267th Medical Company, reflected on the personalities and attitudes of his dead crew members: - Ms. McKinney, 36, possessed ``extraordinary pilot skills.'' She was a ``quiet professional,'' he said. - Cooper, 35, took ``extra professional pride'' in maintaining his helicopters. He didn't hesitate when asked to volunteer for Gulf duty: ``you've got to be someplace,'' he told Poulsen. - Rose, 26, raised horses with skill, and demonstrated devotion to his crew of Nebraskans who joined the Missouri air ambulance company in October, when their crews were merged for Gulf duty. ``Everything he did, he did with caring,'' Poulsen said. Later, Poulsen said he had no new information about the cause of the Dec. 14 crash, which happened in fog north of Houston. ``Until we can get the facts together, we can't say for sure what happened,'' he said in an interview. The crash is under investigation by military authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrations in Timisoara, Students Prolong Strike
DOC.TEXT: The vice president of the ruling National Salvation Front Party announced on Thursday he would resign from Parliament as he was booed off the speakers' platform by workers rallying in Timisoara. Claudio Iordache left the Opera Square stage as 15,000 workers continued more than a week of anti-government protests in the Western city where last year's revolution began. In Bucharest, student leaders decided to continue indefinitely their two-week-old strike. After two days of debate, the Convention of Bucharest Students announced they would continue pressing demands first ired on Dec. 7, including the resignation of President Ion Iliescu. An estimated 100,000 students in Bucharest, Timisoara, Craiova, Cluj, Iasi and other cities were on strike. The students and workers are demanding the resignation of Iliescu and the National Salvation Front government, charging it has failed to bring sufficient democracy to Romania and revive its moribund economy. In Timisoara, union officials estimated Thursday that 75,000 workers were on strike, with 27 local factories either striking or functioning only partially. Large anti-government demonstrations were expected Friday in Bucharest, marking a year since the revolution spread to the capital. The Front took power during the revolution and won elections in May, but it has lost popularity since economic reforms caused widespread price hikes two months ago. For the past two weeks, people from many sectors of the economy have been on strike. In an attempt to end one of the most damaging strikes, government officials met Thursday with representatives of the navigators of the national airline Tarom, whose six-day-old walkout has paralyzed all internal flights. International flights were either canceled or delayed, and Bucharest's Otopeni airport was flooded with transit travelers stranded in Romania. State TV Free Union head Dumitru Iuga, who has been on hunger strike for 20 days demanding the resignation of TV officials left over from the old regime, announced he was giving up his strike Thursday. ``I feel I must listen to those who have been telling me my place is with the workers,'' said Iuga. In Timisoara, the rallying workers had previously marched through most of the sites where the army and secret police killed protesters in the first rallies against the Nicolae Ceausescu regime. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were slain on Dec. 25 by a firing squad.

DOC.HEAD: Wind Whips West with Killer Cold
LaserPhoto DX1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `Nebraska Gov. ...' to CORRECT state to North Dakota, sted Nebraska. Winter begins in the northern hemisphere at 10:07 p.m. EST Friday.
DOC.TEXT: An Arctic front menaced the West and northern Plains with killer cold and blowing snow Thursday, and forecasters warned farmers, stranded truckers and strained power companies to brace for more this weekend. ``There's no place to park. No place to stand. People are just trying to stay warm. Their trucks are frozen up. It's a terrible day, I can tell you that,'' said Darrell Kruljac, who owns a truck stop in Rock Springs, Wyo. Drivers jammed his and other truck stops in Wyoming, waiting for a snowy 100-mile stretch of Interstate 80 to reopen as the wind chill reached 77 below. The combined effect of the wind and cold was expected to drop the wind-chill index as low as 60 below in Minnesota and the Dakotas, the National Weather Service said. The wind chill made it feel like 75 below at Livingston, Mont., on Thursday, the day before winter officially begins. ``The system will modify early next week, but until then it will be just brutally cold - stiff winds, and wind chills well below zero,'' said David Wert of the weather service's office in Norman, Okla. The cold trailed a snowstorm that arrived Tuesday from Canada. Together, they brought an early Christmas vacation for many students, threatened wheat, appleand other crops, and pushed electricity demand to record levels. The storm system was blamed for at least 12 deaths since Tuesday, in California, Oklahoma, Oregon and Washington. Record lows Thursday included minus 26 degrees in Casper, Wyo.; 25 below in Great Falls and Helena, Mont.; 22 below in Billings, Mont.; 11 at Olympia, Wash., and Eugene, Ore.; 14 at Seattle; 15 at Astoria, Ore., and 23 at Sacramento, Calif. Temperatures dove into the 40s in Los Angeles and single digits in Oklahoma. ``It's been colder earlier, but it hasn't turned cold this fast all at once,'' said Bobby Gray of Alva, Okla. The highest high temperature predicted for Montana on Thursday was minus 2 at Libby, in the northwestern corner of the state. Most of Montana faces lows ranging from minus 10 to 40 below zero through Monday. ``This is an unusual storm. It's a very cold storm,'' said Steve Brown of the weather service in Boise, Idaho. Blowing snow and freezing temperatures stranded about 400 passengers on 10 Greyhound buses in Salt Lake City overnight, company spokesman George Gravley said Thursday in Dallas. North Dakota Gov. George Sinner ordered public schools closed statewide Friday. Temperatures of 20 to 35 below zero were expected to combine with northerly winds of 15 to 25 mph to create a wind chill factor of 60 to 80 degrees below zero. Most southern Idaho school districts shut down and even ski resorts were closed by the bitter cold and strong winds. In Gallup, N.M., schools and the airport were closed. Many schools in Washington state canceled classes for the rest of the week as wind damage and high electricity demand left tens of thousands of people in the dark. ``Puget Power is fighting a losing battle,'' said Tim Ortner, a sheriff's deputy in Whatcom County on the Canadian border. ``Wind is just ripping up trees all over the county. They can't keep up with it.'' Farmers dragged out their winter arsenal of frost- and snow-fighting equipment. ``There is the potential for real doom and gloom,'' said Bob Perkins of the Riverside County Farm Bureau in California. ``They are using orchard heaters, helicopters, wind machines and irrigation to prevent damage.'' The storm's beneficiaries were businesses that profit from snow, such as ski resorts in Colorado and the California mountains. The Colorado Avalanche Information Center issued an avalanche warning for Colorado's entire mountain area as winds gusted to 90 mph in the southern mountains. High winds blew snow and downed trees in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., with up to 18 inches of snow falling on the Mammoth Mountain ski area in the Sierra. Less than a week ago, the resort opened a soup kitchen for seasonal workers left jobless by lack of snow. Santa Maria, Calif., had about 20 minutes of snow showers, the first on record in that valley near the Santa Barbara County coast. In Idaho, 5 inches of snow fell in Boise in a 12-hour period ending early Thursday, and Mountain Home had 6 inches. By contrast, Erie, Pa., which is used to shoveling out from Canadian storms that ride across Lake Erie, faces the prospect of a rare green Christmas after getting only 5.6 inches of snow this season. Forecasters said the Western cold would linger during the weekend, with frost reaching Southern California beach communities such as La Jolla and heavy snow falling in mountain areas of northern Arizona. Four traffic deaths in Northern California, five in Oregon and one in Oklahoma were blamed on slippery roads. In Washington, a falling tree killed a Bainbridge Island man in his backyard and a man apparently froze to death at a transient encampment underneath a highwy along Seattle's waterfront.

DOC.HEAD: Stalin Statue Comes Down in Tirana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with last Stalin statue in European capital comes down. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The last statue of Josef Stalin to stand in a European capital was pulled down in pouring rain at the stroke of midnight Thursday, symbolizing the demise of Stalinism throughout Europe. A crane hoisted the bronze statue of the Soviet dictator onto a truck. Covered by a green cloth and lying on its back, the monument was driven off to an undisclosed final destination. The statue's exit coincided with Nexjime Hoxha's losing her last important political post. An official announcement said the 68-year-old widow of Enver Hoxha, Communist Albania's Stalinist founder, retired because due to her age from chairmanship of the Communist-led Democratic Front. The two events seemed meant to convey that Albania's Communist Party is serious about abandoning its 46-year legacy of harsh authoritarian rule. The few people who witnessed the statue's fall were happy to see it go, although restrained by long repression from openly expressing their joy. They were reluctant to talk to reporters and refused to give their names. ``It was a moment which had to come,'' said one worker. Asked if he thought this would be followed by demolition of the memorials to Hoxha throughout Albania, another said, ``No, no. Stalin was a foreigner.'' Albania still has the last city in Europe named for Stalin, who served as a model for Hoxha after the Albanian took power in 1944 and imposed iron rule until his death in 1985. Stalin's statue had gazed down on Tirana since before Stalin died in 1953. It occupied a spot on central square until it was moved in 1968 and its place taken by Skanderbeg, Albania's 15th-century national hero. A statue of Vladimir I. Lenin, founder of the Soviet state, still stands across from the vacant plinth where Stalin stood. In Tirana's so-called Student City, the ramshackle room that now serves as headquarters for Albania's first opposition party is reminiscent of the makeshift operations that bred revolution across Eastern Europe last year. But the new democrats here face a much tougher struggle to overturn Communist rule. Those who buzz around the new Democratic Party of Albania's dilapidated headquarters seem undaunted. A primitive duplicating machine clanks out copies of the party's program, while a harried girl produces another document on an ancient typewriter. Three crudely made wooden chairs are available for visitors. A slogan on a nearby wall reads, ``Freedom and democracy. We need them now.'' Party founders dash in and out under the gaze of curiosity seekers, many of whom still can't quite believe this change has come to Albania. Gramoz Pashko, a Tirana University economist who helped found the new party, said their curiosity highlights the problems faced by the Democrats. ``These people were educated under a dictator,'' he said. ``There's this paternalistic psychology that you go to someone you know, and knock on his door and your problem then gets solved or not.'' Albanians with grievances against the Communists already have started flocking to the headquarters, expecting help, Pashko said. In the 10 days since protests over the slum-like student dorms in Student City swelled into demands for democracy, Albania's nascent opposition has encountered numerous obstacles. The biggest is the Communist Party. One month ago, Albania's president and party leader, Ramiz Alia, contended there was no need for political pluralism in Albania. Now, he says, a decision to permit other parties is irreversible. Nevertheless, Pashko said, local Communist officials still hinder party activists traveling to provincial cities to spread word of the new party. The opposition also faces entrenched support for the Communists in the media. Although the Communist daily Zeri I Popullit, or Peoples' Voice, reported the new party's registration Thursday, it gave no information about its program or leaders. The Democrats want their own daily, to be called Democratic Renewal. That probably will not be enough to counter Communist efforts to maintain power. The Communists are playing tough, cracking down on riots in four cities last week with a huge show of army and police force and handing out sentences of up to 20 years to those arrested. The Communists also seem likely to revamp themselves along reformist lines to confront the challenge from the new opposition. Mrs. Hoxha's loss of her last political position indicates Alia is moving strongly against old-time conservatives. The Communists are to hold a key meeting next Wednesday, when they are likely to announce a government reshuffle promised when the students first pushed for reform. The Communist Party's election program also will be published at that time, and Democratic Party spokesman Genc Pollo says he expects it to move the ruling party toward a more democratic path. The opposition faces the threat of further violence. When riots erupted in Shkodra, Elbasan, Durres and Kavaje, Pashko and other party leaders joined the Communists in condemning the ``hooligans'' they contended were responsible. The condemnation aroused suspicions that the new party is not a genuinely independent opposition. Party leaders insist this is a misunderstanding. They plan an official protest over the trials of rioters, who they say are being detained without adequate legal defense and are at times beaten.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say `Chaka' Defendant Under Suicide Watch
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who allegedly spray-painted the word ``Chaka'' on thousands of public places statewide was declared by a court Thursday to be a danger to himself, authorities said. Daniel Ramos, 18, was declared ``gravely disabled'' during a court hearing, said Mike Qualls, a spokesman for the city attorney. Ramos is housed at Metropolitan State Hospital in Norwalk under a suicide watch, Qualls said. He said he didn't know the circumstances of Ramos' admission to the psychiatric hospital. A hospital spokeswoman would not say whether Ramos was a patient, citing confidentiality laws. The case was continued to Dec. 26. The word ``Chaka'' has been scrawled on thousands of walls, utility poles, curbs, rail cars and traffic signs from Orange County to San Francisco in what authorities describe as the worst case of graffiti in the nation. Damage has been estimated at $500,000. Law enforcement officials say the name ``Chaka'' was apparently taken from the name of a mischievous character in the children's television series ``Land of the Lost,'' which ran on NBC from September 1974 to November 1976 and February 1978 to September 1978, Qualls said. Ramos was arrested Nov. 18 and charged with 28 misdemeanor counts of vandalism and trespassing. Last week prosecutors added 20 more counts. If convicted, he could receive up to six months in jail and a $1,000 fine on each count.

DOC.HEAD: British Prime Minister Arrives
DOC.TEXT: New British Prime Minister John Major arrived here Thursday night for discussions with U.S. officials. Major, prime minister only three weeks, arrived in a Royal Air Force transport at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington. He is scheduled to visit congressional leaders and Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday before flying by helicopter with Bush to Camp David in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains, the presidential retreat. Bush and Major will have a joint news conference on Saturday. Like his predecessor Margaret Thatcher, Major has pledged wholehearted support for the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Britain is sending 21,000 troops. It has become traditional for new British prime ministers to visit the White House soon after assuming office. Major has visited the United States three times before as chancellor of the exchequer.

DOC.HEAD: Iditarod Racer, Actor Head List of Outstanding Young Americans
DOC.TEXT: Dog-sled racer Susan Butcher and Chris Burke, the television actor with Down's syndrome, head the list of Ten Outstanding Young Americans for 1991, the U.S. Jaycees announced Thursday. The 53rd annual award is given to 10 Americans, ages 21 through 39, based on such factors as contributions to society, personal accomplishment and public service. Previous honorees include former Presidents Kennedy and Ford, Elvis Presley, athletes Gale Sayers and Bruce Jenner, and consumer advocate Ralph Nader. The 1991 recipients were recognized for achievements in science, entertainment, sports, law, community service, human improvement and law enforcement. They will be honored Jan. 19 in Tulsa. Ms. Butcher, 36, of Manley, Alaska, has won the Iditarod dog-sled race across Alaska four times. She and fellow racer Joe Redinton are the only people to reach Mount McKinley, North America's highest point, by dog sled. Burke, 25, of Point Lookout, N.Y., plays Corky Thatcher in the television series, ``Life Goes On.'' He is the spokesman for the National Down's Syndrome Congress. Another recipient is Nick Lowery, a placekicker for the Kansas CityChiefs. Lowery, 34, holds the National Football League record for most field goals beyond 50 yards (18), and entered the 1990 season with the highest percentage of field goals made in a career. Lowery also helps raise money for cerebral palsy through the ``Kick with Nick'' program and is part of a group in Kansas City that works with inner-city high schools. The other recipients are: - Shari Aaker-Gilchrist, 27, of Redfield, S.D. Once the victim of domestic violence, she began volunteer work in Oklahoma at the Woodward Domestic Crisis Service Center. She founded the Family Crisis Center Inc. in South Dakota, which helps women and children who have been abused. - Joel Frederick Bresser, 36, of Houston. He founded Molecular Analysis Inc., which has developed methods of measuring cellular material used to understand AIDS and cancer. - Dale Ellis, 38, of Houston. Ellis overcame poverty and a spinal disease to become an attorney and chairman of the American Bar Association General Practice Section Bankruptcy Committee. - Melba D. Marsh, 38, of Cincinnati. Ms. Marsh is a judge in the Hamilton County Municipal Court. She formerly was an assistant prosecutor and the first woman in Ohio to successfully prosecute a death penalty case. - Deborah Crouch McKeithan, 37, of Charlotte, N.C., who was thwarted from becoming a nurse because of paralysis and blindness. Instead, she began Handicapped Organized Women Inc., a support group to help disabled women. - Pat Murdoch, 38, of Albuquerque, N.M. Murdoch was appointed a district court judge in 1985, the youngest ever appointed in New Mexico. He was partially paralyzed from a childhood bout with polio and has been active with March of Dimes since serving as the state poster child in 1957. - Jonathan Clark Owen, 33, of Dallas. He is one of 38 police officers in Dallas to win the Medal of Valor, which he received for saving two people from a burning car while he was off-duty.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Over Beating of John Wayne's Daughter Ends in Mistrial
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial was declared Thursday after a jury deadlocked on charges that thugs hired by the ex-husband of John Wayne's daughter beat her up in a bitter child custody dispute. Prosecutors vowed to retry Aissa Wayne's former husband, Thomas Gionis, and a Jan. 24 hearing was scheduled to consider the possibility of a new trial. Gionis, 37, would not comment. His lawyer, John Barnett, maintained his client's innocence. Gionis faced a prison term of up to eight years. He was charged with eight felonies, including conspiracy and assault with a deadly weapon, stemming from the Oct. 3, 1988, attack on Miss Wayne and her then-boyfriend, Roger Luby. Miss Wayne would not immediately comment on the mistrial. The couple were attacked in the garage of Luby's Newport Beach home. Miss Wayne, 34, and Luby, 54, were knocked to the ground and injured. Deputy District Attorney Christopher J. Evans said the attack was an attempt to intimidate Miss Wayne and prevent her from testifying in a child custody hearing involving their daughter, Anastasia, now 4. Evans said Gionis hired a private investigator, who in turn hired two men to commit the assault. The prosecutor relied heavily on telephone records showing Gionis and private investigator O. Dan Gal were in constant contact leading up to the attack. Juror Diane Brown, who voted to acquit Gionis, said there was no actual proof that it was Gionis on the telephone with Gal. ``Just because he was in control of the (home) telephone and the car (phone) doesn't mean he was answering the phones,'' Brown said, noting others had access to the telephones. Authorities were expected to reach a plea bargain arrangement with Gal for his role in the case. One of the attackers, Jerrel Hintergardt, 39, was convicted of assault and sentenced to eight years in prison. Jeffrey Bouey, 37, pleaded guilty to participating in the attack and he testified against Gionis in a plea-bargain deal with prosecutors. He has yet to be sentenced.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Astronauts Say Mission's Success Yet to be Known
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts said Thursday they returned home with a ``rich harvest'' of scientific information gathered during their astronomy mission, despite several technical problems. The shuttle flight's troubles that repeatedly delayed their stargazing efforts were widely publicized, but the seven crew members said they believe they were successful in studying some of the hottest spots in the universe. ``The astronomy results will be the proof of this mission,'' Columbia commander Vance Brand said at a news conference at the Johnson Space Center. ``It will take a few months for those results to come out, but we're hoping for very good results.'' The $150 million Astro observatory examined 135 celestial objects such as quasars, stars and galaxies that emit X-rays and ultraviolet waves that cannot penetrate the Earth's atmosphere. That number was a little more than half the number scientists had hoped to achieve. Precious viewing time was lost during the recent nine-day mission with the failures of two computer terminals and problems with an instrument pointing system. A line that dumps wastewater overboard clogged, but it didn't interfere with the observatory's work. The problems often forced the four astronomers aboard the shuttle to manually guide the three ultraviolet telescopes toward celestial targets with a joystick and some guidance from ground controllers. The X-ray telescope was unaffected because it had its own guiding system and was controlled by ground commands. The manual process was cumbersome at first, but the astronauts said they adapted fairly quickly. ``We went up there to do astronomy and we could tell from what we'd seen that we had reaped an immense harvest of data about ultraviolet astronomy,'' said astronaut Samuel Durrance, a payload specialist. ``I think the final results will more than prove the benefits of this flight,'' Durrance said. Columbia landed Dec. 10, the same day the National Aeronautics and Space Administration released results of a top-level review of the program. The review recommended shuttle flights be confined to those that require human involvement and that the proposed space station be redesigned completely. The astronauts said their flight, with its technical troubles, was one that demonstrated the need to have astronauts in space when things go awry. ``The other thing I think people will remember about this flight is how man was used to ... solve some pesky problems and continue on,'' Brand said.

DOC.HEAD: 40 Kashmiri Militants Surrender
DOC.TEXT: Forty Kashmiri militants from six separatist groups surrendered to security forces Thursday, news reports said. An additional 54 were reportedly arrested elsewhere in the region. Officials said security forces shot to death three Kashmiri militants Wednesday night and arrested 81 who tried to cross into Jammu-Kashmir state from Pakistan. They said a snow avalanche killed at least 12 other militants in Kupwara, a northwestern area of the state bordering Pakistan. Security forces captured 47 AK-47 Russian assault rifles, six machine guns, 44 pistols, and several rocket launchers and land mines, they reported. The officials said the arms seizure was one of the biggest since Kashmiri militants stepped up their violent campaign for independence last January. Press Trust of India said 40 militants from six separatist organizations surrendered to security forces Thursday in the mountainous region around Srinagar, the state's summer capital, and 54 militants were arrested elsewhere. PTI quoted an official spokesman in Jammu as saying the militants gave up in response to a state government call to down arms and resume normal lives. The spokesman said he expected more militants to surrender soon. India accuses Pakistan of training and arming Kashmiri youthwho regularly cross over the border. Pakistan calls the allegations baseless but acknowledges its sympathy for the militants' cause. Both India and Pakistan claim Jammu-Kashmir state, the only Indian state with a Moslem majority. Since independence in 1947, Pakistan and India have fought two wars over Kashmir. Pakistan is mostly Moslem and India overwhelmingly Hindu.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Finds Negligence by City, Former Yankee, Caused Dancer's Injuries
DOC.TEXT: Negligence by the city and former New York Yankee infielder Andre Robertson were responsible for a 1983 car crash that left a ballerina unable to walk, a jury decided Thursday. Jurors were to return Friday to determine monetary damages for Shenikwa Dawn Nowlin, who was left paralyzed from the waist down by the accident. Her lawsuit blamed the Aug. 19, 1983, crash that broke her back on an improperly placed sign warning of a curve on Manhattan's West Side Highway. She contended the sign was in the middle of the curve and therefore too late to warn drivers. The jury agreed. The panel found the city 67 percent liable and deemed Robertson 33 percent liable because he exceeded the 40 mph speed limit entering the curve. Nowlin was a passenger in a car driven by Robertson. Nowlin, 31, who uses a wheelchair and practices law in Dallas, said she was happy with the jury's findings. By the age of 14, Nowlin was dancing with the Dance Theater of Harlem, the youngest member of the corps. She is seeking $20 million in damages. ``All of a sudden I heard Andre scream,'' Nowlin said of the accident. ``He pushed on the brakes real hard and the car crashed to the left. Then it jerked to the right. We hit the wall on the other side and my back just snapped.'' Robertson, 33, left the Texas Rangers farm club and baseball in December 1989. He now works in a steam generating plant in Orange, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Honduras Says No to Refugees from Other Central American Nations
DOC.TEXT: Honduras, which has served as a shelter for thousands of refugees the last decade, has closed its doors to people fleeing other Central American countries, the government said Thursday. ``This is the new policy adopted by the Honduran government, because our economic situation won't permit it,'' Foreign Minister Mario Carias said in an interview. An estimated 150,000 people from other Central American countries had sought refuge in Honduras the last 10 years, but only 1,500 remain. Another offensive on the war in neighboring El Salvador could send more refugees to the country. ``If El Salvador's civil war flares up again, Honduras cannot absorb new refugees of that nationality,'' Carias said. Carias said Honduras has stopped accepting refugees because it is facing ``the worst economic crisis in its history.'' International monetary agencies have said Honduras is the poorest nation in Central America. It has a $600 million deficit and annual inflation is 40 percent. In the 1980s, 80,000 Nicaraguans, 60,000 Salvadorans and 1,000 Guatemalans fled to Honduras to avoid armed conflicts and social turmoil in their countries. During the same period, 13,000 U.S.-backed Nicaraguan rebels had base camps in Honduras. The remaining refugees, 1,500 Nicaraguans, are slated to return home this month. Carias suggested that Salvadorans displaced by the war be cared for in their own country. ``With the permission of the Salvadoran government, the United Nations should establish camps for the displaced within El Salvador, not in Honduras, to protect the civilian population,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: State's High Court Sets Framework for Donor Transplants Involving Minors
DOC.TEXT: A parent may consent on behalf of a child to donate bone marrow to a sibling, but only when it would be in the child's best interest, the Illinois Supreme Court said Thursday. Justices made the ruling to explain their decision Sept. 28 to uphold a judge's order refusing to force a leukemia victim's young half-siblings to be tested as potentially life-saving bone-marrow donors. The leukemia victim, 13-year-old Jean-Pierre Bosze, died Nov. 19 at his home in the Chicago suburb of Hoffman Estates after a two-year illness. In dealing with that case, the high court cited three factors that must be weighed in future cases to determine when a parent or guardian can approve a child's being a transplant donor: -The parent or guardian must be informed of the risks and benefits inherent in the donation. -Emotional support must be available to the child from his caretakers. -A close relationship must exist between the donor and recipient. ``The evidence clearly shows that there is no physical benefit to a donor child,'' wrote Justice Harold Calvo for the court's majority. ``If there is any benefit to a child who donates bone marrow to a sibling it will be a psychological benefit.'' Calvo said the psychological benefit is grounded firmly in the fact that the donor and recipient know each other as family. Jean-Pierre's father, Tamas Bosze, had petitioned for a court ruling to force Nancy Curran - his former girlfriend and the mother of Jean-Pierre's twin half-siblings - to have the 3-year-olds tested as possible donors. Attorneys for the father and a court-appointed guardian for Jean-Pierre had urged the justices to order the testing of the twins on the legal theory that if the twins were adults, they would agree to it. However, the high court refused to apply the legal doctrine of substituted judgment. No dissents were filed. ``Because each twin is only 3{ years of age, neither has yet had the opportunity to develop `actual, specific express intent,' or any form of intent, with regard to serving as a bone marrow donor,'' Calvo said. Edward Jordan, an attorney for the father, said he was disappointed the court rejected his arguments, but optimistic about cases to come. ``We have established a framework that can save lives in the future,'' he said. Charles Fleck, the court-appointed guardian for the twins, applauded the justices for taking a common sense approach. ``They didn't want to get into a `Brave New World' situation where people start taking minors to save the life of Mother Teresa or the president or somebody else,'' he said. ``They focused on the best interests of the minor.''

DOC.HEAD: Five Shot From Passing Car Going Home From School
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf: ``John Olden,'' to upgrade conditions of children; SUBS 6th graf: ``Two children,'' weapon unknown
DOC.TEXT: Five children from 6 to 13 years old were shot Thursday afternoon while walking home from school. Police said someone opened fire on them from a passing car. The victims were taken to Children's National Medical Center for treatment of gunshot wounds, said hospital spokeswoman Barbara Cire. Police did not know a motive for the shooting, and no suspects have been arrested, said police spokesman Walt Ferguson. John Olden, 13, Clarence Richmond, 14, and Brian Lewis, 12, were listed in critical condition at first, then upgraded to serious condition. The conditions of Troy Gray, 15, and Xaziver Paul, 6, were upgraded from serious to fair. ``The two younger children, thank God, had more superficial injuries,'' Dr. Marty Eichelberger said. ``Hopefully the injuries that they have are injuries that we can deal with. However, we'll have to wait and see as time goes on.'' Two children were shot in the chest, two in the abdomen and one in the arm, Eichelberger said. Police said they were not sure what kind of weapon was used. Relatives of the children rushed to the hospital as news of the shooting spread. The shooting took place near 5th and O Streets N.W., a low-income residential area.

DOC.HEAD: Sunken Barge Threatens River Commerce
DOC.TEXT: A tugboat searched the rain-swollen Allegheny River Thursday for a sunken scrap barge that halted traffic through the nation's largest inland port for a second day, officials said. A 4-mile stretch of the river was closed while a salvage crew used a 15-foot pole to probe the water for the barge, said Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Rhea Giacoma. The search was suspended later Thursday after a search of two miles of the river proved fruitless. The waterway is about 40 feet deep. ``One little barge like this is more of a nuisance than anything else,'' said U.S. Army Corps of Engineers spokesman John Reed. ``But if you don't know where it is, it could create a much bigger problem.'' The Coast Guard asked the barge's owner, Azcon Scrap Corp., to acquire more sophisticated equipment so the search can resume Friday, Ms. Giacoma said. The steel barge broke loose from its moorings at Azcon's scrap yard Dec. 14. Two workers jumped to safety and the barge sailed over a dam, stuck in the mud and bent at a 45-degree angle. When a record two inches of rain fell Tuesday, the barge broke ree and sank down river.

DOC.HEAD: Albanian Guards Reportedly Kill Four Fleeing Albanians
With AM-Albania
DOC.TEXT: Albanian border guards shot at Albanians trying to flee to Yugoslavia on makeshift rafts, killing at least four of them and wounding others, the Croatian news agency HINA reported. It quoted Yugoslav police as saying Albanians used rafts made of tractor tires and rubber inner tubes to flee to neighboring Yugoslavia across the Bojana river; that 23 men, women and children crossed safely, but that four bodies were found on one raft and a number of refugees were reported wounded. HINA, reporting from the Yugoslav border town of Ulcinj, said Albanian border guards began shooting at the rafts at about 1 a.m. Thursday. A group of 28 Albanians successfully crossed at the same place Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Refuses to Publish Guilt Ads
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper publisher has refused to accept court-ordered advertisements of guilt from people convicted of misdemeanors. Kenneth Andrews of the Pensacola News Journal said Wednesday his newspaper, the only daily in town, would not run the ads Judge William White began ordering last week. ``Although we understand Judge White's intent, the newspaper as a matter of policy does not wish to become a vehicle for court-ordered public humiliation,'' Andrews said in a prepared statement. White, an Escambia County judge, last week ordered about a dozen defendants charged with soliciting for immoral purposes, drunken driving and shoplifting to buy the ads. Under the law, he can't re-sentence the defendants, all convicted of misdemeanors. ``I'm not going to force people to do something they can't do,'' White said after he was told of Andrews' decision. ``I've asked my secretary to call the defendants and tell them that I'm waiving the advertising requirements.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Halt Slovenian Independence Referendum
DOC.TEXT: Federal Premier Ante Markovic says Slovenia has the right to hold a referendum on possible secession from Yugoslavia, and on Thursday the Constitutional Court in Belgrade backed his position. The national Parliament and federal presidency oppose the western republic's plans to hold a plebsicite this Sunday. But the court rejected a parliamentary request for a temporary injunction forbidding the referendum to be held. Markovic said in an interview late Wednesday it is the view of his federal government ``that it is the right of each (republican) parliament, to decide on a referendum ... seeking the opinion of its citizens. ``The citizens have the right to express their opinions ... (and) to reply to the questions posed.'' He cautioned, however, it was ``a different question'' whether such a vote has legal consequences. Most of the 1.9 million Slovenes were expected to vote for complete independence from Yugoslavia, now a federation of six republics and two provinces. After Slovenian deputies walked out Wednesday, Parliament unanimously agreed the planned plebiscite was tantamount to secession from the federation. It referred to ``an anti-constitutional act striving to impose on other Yugoslav republics a solution, irrespective of their rights and interests.'' But the Constitutional Court rejected its request for an injunction, the state news agency Tanjug reported, saying: ``The plebiscite, as a form of expression of the will of the people, cannot be prevented, and the Constitutional Court cannot base its decisions on suppositions about what the outcome will be.'' This week, Yugoslavia's collective presidency told Markovic's government to take ``indispensable'' but unspecified steps to preserve Yugoslav unity. Markovic refused to say what his government's reaction would be to a referendum calling for Slovenian independence. Slovenia ousted Communists from power in free elections this year and is dissatisfied with the pace of democratic reforms in the rest of the country. After the Communists, renamed Socialists, won overwhelmingly in the first free elections in the largest state of Serbia on Dec. 9, Slovenian leaders intensified preparations for the referendum. Leaders of Slovenia and neighboring Croatia, which also voted Communists out of power, have stressed they prefer to leave Yugoslavia unless this Balkan country of roughly 24.1 million people is turned into a loose confederation. The Serbs insist Yugoslavia must remain a federation amid threats from the armed forces to intervene should national unity be threatened. Markovic insists it matters little what Yugoslavia will be called as long as his radical reforms, designed to introduce market economy, are implemented. He has won world praise for cutting back inflation, boosting state reserves and making the dinar, the national currency, convertible. Under the constitution, a republic can secede only if the other republics agree.

DOC.HEAD: Miami Boycotters Issue Further Demands
DOC.TEXT: Organizers of a black economic boycott said Thursday they would consider calling off the action if Miami area politicians issue Nelson Mandela proclamations of welcome and keys to their cities. Boycott leader H.T. Smith called on Mayor Xavier Suarez, Miami Beach Mayor Alex Daoud and Dade County commissioners to issue the keys and proclamations, saying that would constitute the apology blacks demanded when they began the boycott five months ago. ``Nelson Mandela is the living personification of self respect and human dignity,'' Smith said. ``To disrespect him is to disrespect freedom-seeking people everywhere who truly believe in civil and human rights for all.'' At a press conference in Miami's impoverished Liberty City neighborhood, Smith said boycott organizers would deliver the keys and proclamations to Mandela in South Africa if the politicians prepared them. ``An apology will not end the boycott,'' Smith said. ``However, once the foundation has been laid, we can begin to work together to build a community where all people will be welcome.'' Smith criticized Suarez' recent statement that he regretted the way city officials handled the June visit of the anti-apartheid leader, saying it wasn't enough to end the boycott. ``While we acknowledge that his statement is a sign of progress, neither the content nor the context of Mayor Suarez' statement indicate that it is an apology,'' Smith said. Suarez was in Washington on Thursday night and could not be reached for comment. Daoud said he would be ``very pleased'' to give Mandela a proclamation of welcome and a key to his city. ``We are very pleased to welcome Mr. Mandela, but not his friends,'' Daoud said. ``They are enemies of the United States.'' Instead of the enthusiastic welcomes and ceremonies Mandela received elsewhere on his U.S. tour, he got an official snub and criticism from Suarez, Daoud and others because he refused to repudiate the African National Congress' staunch supporters, Fidel Castro, Yasser Arafat and Moammar Ghadhafi. The Greater Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau reported earlier this week that eleven groups canceled their gatherings - some planned as far in the future as 1993 - costing the city nearly $5.5 million. Other tourism officials estimate the city has lost as much as $12 million. Smith said the keys and proclamations would pave the way for negotiations on the three other boycott demands: Greater business and employment opportunities for black citizens; a review of federal immigration policy regarding Haitians, who routinely are detained and deported while Hispanics are admitted to this country; and a federal investigation of the Miami police's violent breakup of a July protest by Haitians.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Observes Invasion Anniversary With Mixed Emotions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10 grafs for 6-13 bgng `But the...' to UPDATE with graveside ceremony; CORRECT death toll from human rights commission and invasion date to Dec. 20 sted 21; pickup graf 14 `Of the...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY28
DOC.TEXT: With a mixture of gratitude and indignation, Panama on Thursday observed the anniversary of last year's U.S. military invasion that ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. ``That action itself cannot lead us to proclaim a national holiday, because it was an invasion and no Panamanian likes to see his country invaded, with the consequences of deaths and injuries,'' said Foreign Minister Julio Linares. ``Neither can we say it is a day of national mourning because it liberated us from dictatorship.'' The government dubbed the date a ``day of national reflection,'' while the families of Panamanians killed in the invasion set a ``grand black march'' of protest for the evening. Hundreds of families left homeless by the invasion demonstrated for government housing at a rally that began Wednesday night and lasted into early Thursday. Families of victims killed in the invasion held a ceremony Thursday honoring the dead at the side of a common grave where 123 are buried. ``One feels impotent in the face of the U.S. presence in Panama and the unconditional surrender of our leaders, who to this day haven't even been able to define what happened to Panama,'' victims' family committee vice president Arturo Rodriguez said. But the streets of Panama City were mostly filled with Christmas shoppers on anniversary morning, and a scheduled picket of the U.S. Embassy did not materialize. Newspapers reflected the ambivalence that is the invasion's legacy. ``Panama is a country with a future that is more promising every day. And that is the principal difference between the country today and the country of one year ago,'' the newspaper La Prensa said. But the daily La Estrella warned against continued U.S. military presence in the country. ``Our territorial integrity continues to be seriously damaged and at times disastrously compromised even by the federal government,'' it said. Joint U.S.-Panamanian military patrols were scheduled to end this month and have not. The U.S. Army was called out at President Guillermo Endara's request to put down a minor police revolt Dec. 5. About 10,000 U.S. soldiers are stationed in Panama under the Panama Canal treaty, providing security for the waterway. About 14,000 other U.S. troops participated in the invasion last year, but all those soldiers were withdrawn. There are varying estimates for the number of people who died in the invasion. The Panamanian Human Rights Committee released recent figures showing that 403 people died or disappeared. Earlier, it had put the number at 385. The U.S. Army Southern Command says 345 died in the Dec. 20 invasion. Of the 1,243 families left homeless by the invasion, 596 whose dwellings were wrecked by bombs in the Chorillo neighborhood where Noriega's headquarters stood are still at a refugee shelter awaiting housing. The country has been it by high unemployment and economic stagnation. Endara, who came to the presidency following Noriega's overthrow, urged invasion victims to take courage. ``We will preserve our democracy. We will improve it every day,'' he said on the eve of the anniversary.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Resigns, Warns of Coming Dictatorship
LaserPhotos MOSB4,6,7,13, Lasercolor MOSB104,107
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 17th graf, It was ... to UPDATE with German reaction. Picks up 18th graf, In his ...
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, shocked by his foreign minister's resignation, denied Thursday his presidency was slipping toward dictatorship and condemned Eduard Shevardnadze for quitting in a time of crisis.
