DOC.BYLINE: Asthmatics Can Exercise Despite Cold ^By IRA DREYFUSS
DOC.TEXT: It can be hard enough for an asthmatic to walk in cold, dry air without gasping or wheezing - and it can be tougher still to exercise. But doctors say asthmatics can stay active outdoors in winter if they take precautions. The trick is to control the allergic reaction in the airway that sets off the attack, said Michael A. Kaliner, chief of allergic diseases at the National Institute of Allergies and Infectious Diseases in Bethesda, Md. Although experts don't know exactly how the reaction works, they know that exercise and cold, dry air are separate causes. ``If you exercise outside in warm weather, you can have trouble, and if you don't exercise in cold weather, you can still have trouble,'' said Dr. Henry J. Fishman, an asthma specialist in Washington, and an assistant clinical professor at Georgetown University Hospital and George Washington University Medical Center. Combining both problems just makes things tougher, said Fishman: ``Jogging in the cold is one of the hardest things an asthmatic can do.'' Exercise, in some ways, takes care of itself - an asthma attack generally won't take place during exercise, but will instead wait until three to five minutes after the workout ends, said Kaliner. ``It's usually not denial - it's usually people who are very committed to health and want to exercise,'' Fishman said. However, some victims may not realize they have asthma, and may consider their breathing difficulty to be simply part of their usual pattern after exercise, he said. Asthmatic exercisers may, however, benefit from a phenomenon known as the refractory period that can make the next workout easier, said Dr. Oded Bar-Or, an asthma researcher at McMaster University in Ontario. ``When you exercise and rest, the second time, you do not have an attack,'' he said. ``The period in which you are at least partially protected is the refractory period.'' The period generally is 45 minutes to an hour, but the intensity varies from individual to individual, and its cause is not known, said Bar-Or. Because vigorous exercise makes a person breathe hard, exercising in the cold can make an asthmatic suck in more cold dry air than he would ordinarily, said Bar-Or. To cut down on the problem, keep the air you breathe as warm and humid as possible, he said. For mild exercise, such as walking, you can simply breathe through your nose, he said. This can let cold, dry air mix - before it can set off an allergic reaction - with air that your body has already warmed and humidified, he said. For more vigorous exercise, Bar-Or recommends putting a scarf over the mouth and nose. The space between the scarf and the face holds warm and humid exhaled air to be mixed with colder air, he said. A surgical mask may do the same thing. Medication can also make it easier to exercise in the cold, Kaliner said. Some preparations can prevent the mast cells in the airways from releasing the histamines that trigger the asthma, he said. Others keep the airway open even though the histamines are released, he said. Asthmatics can avoid the problem by working out indoors. Swimming is considered one of the best exercises for asthmatics.

DOC.HEAD: Deer Carcasses Searched for Tick that Causes Lyme Disease
DOC.TEXT: Deer carcasses hunters bring to state check stations are being searched for the ticks that can carry Lyme disease in a multistate effort to find clues to the spread of the disease in the Northeast. ``We examine the face, ears and down one side of the neck of the deer,'' said John Edman, an entomology professor at the University of Massachusetts. Ticks have been found consistently on deer shot near the Connecticut border, he said. But this fall, for the first time, they have been found on significant numbers of deer shot in the central part of the Connecticut Valley to the north, he said. ``It's an epidemic that has crept up on us,'' said Durland Fish of the medical entomology lab at New York Medical College. ``And it is crucial that we know where the ticks are found. You can't get the disease unless you are bitten by a tick.'' Nationwide, there were about 14,000 cases of Lyme disease reported last year. The bacterial infection can cause an arthritis-like inflammation of the joints and damage to the nervous system if not treated. Usually the first sign is a red, circular rash around the tick bite, often accompanied by fever, fatigue and other flu-like symptoms. ---

The U.S. economy was still growing at a weak 1.4 percent annual rate from July through September, the government said, but most economists believe it since has slipped into a recession. The Commerce Department Wednesday reported its final estimate of the third-quarter gross national product was even slower than its initial estimates. In another report, the department said housing starts jumped 9.3 percent in November, their first increase in 10 months. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Reserve, amid fresh evidence of a weakening economy, lowered another key interest rate, analysts said. The Bush administration said it expected banks to follow the Fed's lead, but there was no rush to do so. Economists said the central bank on Wednesday injected reserves into the banking system to push the federal funds rate - the interest that banks charge to make loans to each other - to 7 percent. A day earlier, the Fed cut its discount rate, the interest it charges for direct loans to commercial banks, from 7 percent to 6.5 percent, the first reduction in four years. --- WILMINGTON, Del. (AP) - Continental Airlines received a federal bankruptcy judge's approval to sell its prized Seattle-Tokyo route to healthy rival American Airlines for $150 million. The sale was one of a number of actions sanctioned Wednesday by Judge Helen Balick. The Houston-based Continental, which like many companies is incorporated in Delaware, is among the weaker commercial carriers in an industry that's under enormous pressure from a slumping economy that has discouraged air travel. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Housing starts rose in November for the first time in 10 months, but construction of single-family homes plummeted to a level not seen since the last recession, the government said. The Commerce Department Wednesday said starts of new homes and apartments rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.13 million units, advancing for the first time since a 23.2 percent gain in January. But the advance was due solely to a 102 percent rebound in multi-family starts, which had dropped 28 percent a month earlier. Multi-family starts totaled 357,000 at an annual rate in November. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - President Bush will consider taxing imported oil as part of a national energy strategy, the Department of Energy said. The tax will be among some 67 policy options the department is preparing for Bush, DOE spokeswoman Joelle Ziemian said late Tuesday night. An import tax allows domestic oil producers to raise their price and increase profits but it forces consumers to pay more for both imported and domestic oil. Word of the possible tax drew immediate fire from New England lawmakers who thought they had finally defeated the idea during the October budget deficit debate. --- LONDON (AP) - Britain's economy shrank 1.2 percent in the third quarter, the biggest contraction in 10 years, the government said. The Central Statistical Office said Wednesday a cut in oil production was to blame for the drop in its average estimate of gross domestic product. The Treasury's top official, meanwhile, said the outlook was for a weak performance in the fourth quarter of 1990 and early 1991. --- BEIJING (AP) - China's first computerized stock market opened in Shanghai with almost no stocks for sale. Instead, government bonds are the main offering and even their sale will be tightly restricted. The new Shanghai Securities Exchange, which opened with great fanfare on Wednesday, falls far short of what economic reformers envisioned several years ago when they proposed setting up a nationwide stock market. The exchange listed only seven stocks on opening day, reflecting the government's fear of allowing financial speculation. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - A former Hughes Aircraft Co. employee dropped his $9.6 billion ``whistle blower'' lawsuit accusing Hughes of covering up flaws in 4.75 million microchips installed in defense systems, Hughes said. The suit was abandoned by Michael C. Denlinger, a former engineer at Hughes' Ground Systems Group, who had insisted he was pursuing the action for the public good despite threats on his life. Denlinger claimed Hughes took a shortcut in its soldering methods during a five-year period in the 1980s. Richard Dore, a spokesman for the defense contractor, said Wednesday Denlinger dropped the suit last month. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Kuwaitis have spent $5.64 million for a public relations firm to promote the country's cause after the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2, Justice Department records show. The money was paid to Hill & Knowlton Inc., for the period Aug. 20-Nov. 10, according to records the firm filed with the foreign agents registration office. Citizens for a Free Kuwait, a group that receives most of its money from the Kuwait government-in-exile, hired Hill & Knowlton to ``provide counsel on a national media program, strategic planning and message development,'' the records said. ---

Stock prices finished mixed to slightly higher Wednesday, bogging down after a sharp rally Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average finished Wednesday's session unchanged at 2,626.73. Bonds dropped sharply. The dollar finished higher. Gold jumped. Oil futures were stagnant, grain and soybean futures prices closed sharply lower and livestock and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Lower Interest Rates Make Some Happy, Others Uneasy
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Homeowner John Scott feels about $400 a month richer these days thanks to a recent drop in interest rates and the likelihood of further declines following the Federal Reserve's move to ease credit. The 41-year-old real estate broker said he recently refinanced the mortgage on his four-bedroom contemporary, replacing a 12 percent fixed rate with an 8\ percent adjustable rate and lowering monthly expenses to $1,400 from $1,800. ``I'll probably refinance again some time in the next two years because I think rates will continue to drop,'' said Scott, of Hilton Head, S.C. That scenario, though, troubles people like Judy Schub, a lobbyist for the American Association of Retired Persons. ``For the elderly person who depends on income from savings ... as interest rates decline, their incomes decline,'' she said. Nonetheless, many economists say interest rates could ease through early next year as the Fed attempts to make credit more available to help inject new life into the nation's sagging economy. It gave a clear signal on Tuesday, when it cut its discount rate to 6{ percent from 7 percent, and on Wednesday, when it injected more funds into the banking system, thereby pushing down the federal funds rate. The discount rate is the Fed's fee on loans to member banks, while the fed fund rate is what banks charge each other in overnight lending. Although neither rate directly effects consumer borrowing, some experts predict banks' lower borrowing costs could trickle down to average Americans and businesses. ``The reduction in interest rates will change the attitude of consumers and make them feel more positive,'' said Donald W. Grigley, a senior vice president for Connecticut National Bank, where demand for certain loans, such as auto and personal loans, has dropped off recently. Yet lenders like Grigley and other businessmen aren't so sure that lower rates will necessarily motivate consumers to go on a buying spree any time soon. ``There's enough uncertainty about the economy and the Middle East crisis to cause people to sit back,'' said Willard Gourley, vice chairman of BarclaysAmerican-Mortgage Corp. in Charlotte, N.C. ``Some people also are predicting rates will go lower. They're trying to find a bottom ... so they don't want to jump in at the moment.'' For those who have, such as Scott, the Hilton Head real estate broker, lower rates have made family finances more bearable, especially in light of recently rising inflation. Scott, who refinanced about 1{ months ago, said he obtained his original mortgage about 18 months ago at a time when rates happened to shoot up. Mortgage rates have remained fairly stable throughout most of 1990, staying in the 10- to 10.5 percent range for fixed-rate conventional loans. In recent weeks, they've fallen well into single-digit territory. According to HSH Associates, a Butler, N.J.-based mortgage research firm, rates on 30-year mortgages averged 9 percent last week, a three-year low. The company said some rates had fallen even as low as 8} percent. Angelo Mozilo, president of Countrywide Funding Corp. in Pasadena, Calif., one of the nation's largest mortgage lending companies, says the downward tend could prompt more people to refinance their home mortgages. That would include homeowners with adjustable rate mortages that might want to lock in a low fixed rate as well as those with high fixed rates, Mozilo said. He said he already has seen that happen. He said loans for refinancing at his firm today make up about 30 percent of business, up from nearly zero at the start of this year. While mortgage rates have fallen in recent weeks, not all consumer loans have followed suit, and they may not, based on past history, said Robert K. Heady, publisher of Bank Rate Monitor in North Palm Beach, Fla. He said that auto loans are actually higher, averaging 12.26 percent in December, vs. 12.23 percent in November and 12.11 percent at the start of the year. Personal loans are also up, rising to 17.34 percent on average from 17.30 percent in November and 17.19 percent in January, Heady said. But at the same time, he said, savings rates on things like certificates of deposits have fallen. Average rates on six-month CDs, for instance, dropped to 7.48 percent in December from 7.57 percent the previous month and 7.89 percent in Januaury. ``The consumer is getting shafted,'' said Heady. ``There's no doubt about it. He's earning less on his savings ... but he's forking out more to make personal loans.'' Heady and Schub, the AARP lobbyist, say that elderly Americans are one sector of the population likely to feel the effects of this type of discrepancy. Few are in the market for new homes, so they won't be taking advantage of the lower mortgage rates, but many will continue buying on credit, they say. What's worse, a significant number lives on a fixed income and depend on the interest on CDs or bonds.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas in Syracuse: a Season of Ups and Downs and a Few Gambles
LaserPhoto SUC1 of Dec. 19
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: By JOYCE M. ROSENBERG
DOC.TEXT: With a population of about 170,000, Syracuse is considered a typical American city, so it should come as no surprise that retailers here are having a typical recession-year Christmas. Some storeowners are reporting bang-up business while others say sales are down. Some retailers are taking a chance by setting up shop just as consumers are cutting back. The retail business in Syracuse is much like that of many other American cities. Parts of the downtown, once a shopping hub, resemble a ghost town because consumers have taken most of their business to suburban malls. On Salina Street, a former Sibley's department store sits empty. The Atrium, a new office building, is advertising space. Downtown shops were having a slow season going into the last 10 days of the season, a crucial time for all retailers across the nation. At a Paul Harris store, part of a chain of clothing stores, business has been ``OK, but not as good as last year,'' said store manager Stefanie Kahn. Sales were picking up as Christmas approached, but it was taking longer than usual to sell some merchandise, she said. Prices were marked down, but the reductions were part of a company-wide sale. Down the street, Bud Elliott, manager of Albert's jewelry store, said business has been ``down a little bit but not all that bad.'' ``I can't be alarmed too much,'' said Elliott, noting that Albert's, in business for 47 years, has a cadre of regular customers. ``I think it is going to be all right,'' he said. Department stores in Syracuse - like many department stores elsewhere - were hurting going into the final days of the season, so the retailers cut prices to lure customers. At Addis & Dey's, signs advertised 20 percent or 25 percent off many items. Even Christmas merchandise and women's and children's party clothing, once exempt from pre-holiday markdowns, were on sale. The strategy worked. Salespeople reported the downtown store, which had been quiet in the days after Thanksgiving, was mobbed at lunchtime once the sale began. Some Syracuse retailers have escaped the recession. One is Ra-Lin, which sells appliances, housewares, sporting goods, luggage and jewelry in a small crowded building in a commercial area but off the beaten track. Ra-Lin has been busy. This past Friday, for example, a security guard directed traffic outside, while inside, customers were taking three and four small appliances apiece to the cash register. Rich Robin, merchandise manager in the home appliance section, said the store had a slight lull after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, but business picked up soon afterward. The major appliance department has hired extra sales help, said President Jerry Heller. Heller said the secret of Ra-Lin's success is longevity - the store has been in business for 40 years, and has sold major appliances for 15 - and its low prices. He invited customers to compare his prices with those of competitors, whose newspaper ads he posted on a wall. It has also been a good Christmas at Carousel Center, a 1.5 million square-foot mall that rests like a palace of light and glass near Lake Onondaga. Pyramid Cos., which built the mall, tried to make it different from the standard malls in suburban Syracuse, so it brought in acres of Italian marble for the floors and miles of decorative brass stripping. An 80-year-old refurbished carousel sits inside the center. But perhaps more significantly, Pyramid sought out stores that have never been in Syracuse, including such upscale names as Williams-Sonoma and Lord & Taylor. One of Pyramid's own Bonwit Teller stores is at the mall. Carousel Center sounds like a big gamble in these recessionary times. But Bruce Keenan, a partner in the real estate developer, was confident that Syracuse, although largely a middle-American city, can support a tonier mall. For one thing, Pyramid placed a similar mall in Buffalo, N.Y., a working class city, several years ago and it has been thriving, Keenan said. Carousel Center is the first mall inside the city limits, but its appeal extends beyond Syracuse and its immediate suburbs. Keenan said the mall has been drawing customers willing to travel 30 miles or more. But what happens after the novelty has faded? Keenan was not worried. Stores that have leased space in Carousel Center are ``doing long-term planning rather than short-term,'' he said. By the time Christmas is over, Pyramid expects the mall, which opened Oct. 15, to have drawn 3 million shoppers. This past weekend, the mall was very busy, even late at night, but so were the malls in Syracuse suburbs.

DOC.HEAD: Retailers Having Gloomy Christmas in Britain Too
LaserPhoto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Britain's retailers are facing the worst Christmas selling season in 10 years as an economic downturn and 14 percent interest rates cause Britons to pinch their pence. The slump, worsened by unusually cold weather, is driving an unprecedented number of shops to open illegally on Sundays, inciting debate about Britain's trading laws and prompting Prime Minister John Major to call for reform. Even the big chains have joined hundreds, perhaps thousands, of independent shops as outlaws, and more shopkeepers might be panicked into opening up this coming Sunday. The lawbreakers, who risk fines of up to 1,000 pounds (about $1,930) and court injunctions shutting them down, say they are meeting customer demand. The main shop workers union USDAW and the Keep Sunday Special pressure group say they are ruining Sundays and preventing employees from spending the day with families. They also accuse the outlaw retailers of stealing sales and jobs from midweek business and from the law-abiding majority. Major told the House of Commons Tuesday that the two sides should reach an agreement that could be the basis for reform. He described the 1950s Shops Act which bars English and Welsh stores from opening on Sundays as bizarre. He noted that Scottish shops are allowed to trade on Sundays. Like storeowners in the recession-tainted United States, many merchants also are slashing prices before the traditional January sales period, because they're finding it the only way they can generate business. At the same time, retailers have reported a pickup in sales in recent days and are hoping for a last-minute surge. December retail sales are expected to fall from a year ago, the first decline since Britain's 1980-81 recession, said Roy Maconochie, an analyst with the London investment firm James Capel and Co. The combination of heavy markdowns and below-target sales coinciding with rising costs do not bode well for profits, Maconochie said. He recently downgraded his profit forecasts for many of Britain's top retailing companies, whose shares then took a battering on London's Stock Exchange. The economic slowdown and high interest rates mean more Britons are losing jobs and struggling to pay their adjustable rate mortgage payments. Inflation running at 9.7 percent doesn't help. ``Consumer confidence is at a low at the moment generally,'' said James May, director-general of the Retail Consortium, a trade group which says it represents 90 percent of the British retail industry. An unusual snowstorm on the weekend of Dec. 7 and continuing bitterly cold weather also has hurt sales, the experts said. Among the stores that have stayed open Sunday is Hamley's, Britain's biggest and oldest toy store. Management said the move was justified by the 30,000 people who passed through the doors of the Regent Street shop that day. The store was undeterred by an 800-pound ($1,544) fine imposed last week for trading on Sunday in October 1989. It said it might open again this Sunday. ``Being not the best of economic years, we're running a little high on our inventory,'' said chief executive Duncan Chadwick. ``It gives us an opportunity to liquidate that.''

DOC.HEAD: Departing Stock Exchange Chairman Sees Slump Continuing
LaserPhoto NY22 of Dec. 19
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The departing leader of the New York Stock Exchange said Wednesday he expects the downturn in the nation's financial markets to last another six to 18 months. But John J. Phelan Jr., who steps down Dec. 31 after six years as NYSE chairman, called the three-year industry slump just another business cycle and predicted the markets would be ``roaring'' again by the mid-1990s. In an interview in his Wall Street office, Phelan also said the Big Board was on course for a plan to institute limited after-hours trading for the first time in its 198-year-history. He further said the often-discussed possibility of a merger with the smaller American Stock Exchange likely will be raised again in the future. Phelan, 59, said he will serve on several corporate boards, head an executive education group and continue as chairman of an international stock exchange association. A birder, Phelan also said he plans to raise money for the Audubon Society. William H. Donaldson, a Wall Street veteran and co-founder of the brokerage Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., takes over for Phelan during a bear market that shows little signs of quickly reversing. ``We've got problems to get over,'' Phelan said. ``We had excesses in the '80s. The entire country overleveraged itself, from each individual right up through the majority of corporations. It's going to take us awhile to digest that.'' ``But I think we will do that ... without a major catastrophe,'' he said. ``I think by the middle of this decade you're going to have a roaring market again. We'll all be worried about capacity and volume again.'' After hitting an all-time high of 2,999.75 in July, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 21 percent by October before regaining some lost ground in the last two months. Average daily trading volume for 1990 through November was 156.9 million shares, NYSE figures show, a 5.8 percent drop from last year and 16.9 percent lower than 1987. Those declines, coupled with a deepening recession on Wall Street reflected by thousands of layoffs and across-the-board business declines at major investment firms, are expected to be exaggerated by the nation's economic woes. Asked when the market might turn around, Phelan said six to 18 months. Phelan leaves behind a legacy as a candid and forceful leader of the nation's No. 1 stock exchange. He is best known for safely guiding the NYSE through the 508-point stock market crash in October 1987. Phelan also presided over the greatest expansion and technological explosion in NYSE history. Despite the recent sell-off, volume today is 72 percent higher than in 1984 and more than eight times higher than when he arrived as a vice chairman in 1975. Phelan's major piece of unfinished business is a five-part plan for continuous round-the-clock trading announced earlier this year. The first step in the plan is for limited trading sessions shortly after the market close, now expected to begin in January. Phelan said the proposal is awaiting approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Phelan said the initial sessions would go on despite the recent low volume as a prelude toward more extensive trading. But Phelan said full-scale 24-hour trading is ``a long way off.'' He was skeptical of ``this whole theory of a couch potato sitting there at 2 o'clock in the morning dying to make a trade in something. Most people don't like to trade when the home market is closed. It's going to take a long time to change that.'' But he added: ``I think there's a good chance somewhere out there that in certain securities there may be a continuing demand and we ought to have something out there in case the demand comes.'' On other matters, Phelan said restrictions on computerized program trading instituted this year had helped prevent volatile movements in the market blamed for heightening investor anxiety. Now, he said, ``everybody's invited to the party but nobody's allowed to get drunk and disorderly.'' ``Clearly the investing public, whether it's the institutions or the individual, plus everybody who regulates the market ... felt more comfortable when there was no volatility,'' he said. Phelan also said one of the NYSE's biggest weaknesses has been its inability to market so-called derivative products such as stock and bond options. He said the strength of the rival American Stock Exchange may lead to a renewal of talks about a merger. ``I think it is something that will come up again,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Citicorp's Restructuring Underscores Bank Troubles
Graphic of Dec. 19
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Citicorp's severe restructuring is one of the most vivid demonstrations yet of how once-mighty U.S. banks have faltered in a weakening economy. Predictions are at least as grim for 1991, leading to expectations of more bloodletting. Analysts generally applauded plan by the nation's largest banking company, announced Tuesday, to cut its dividend by 44 percent, lay off 8,000 workers, and set aside $340 million for commercial loan losses. But the amount of money set aside for problem loans was ``a lot less than what many people on street were looking for,'' said Richard Goleniewski, banking analyst for Goldman Sachs and Co. Analysts' estimates of the bank's problem loans range as high as $2 billion. Raphael Soifer, banking analyst for Brown Brothers, Harriman & Co., said he assumes Citicorp's loan loss reserves are adequate for now because the bank just underwent a government examination. Results of the U.S. Comptroller of the Currency probe weren't released because of confidentiality rules. ``But it does raise a question about the future deterioration of the real estate portfolio,'' Soifer said. Fay Wong, a vice-president at Fitch Investors Service, predicted ``a bumpy year'' for Citicorp as it further pads its problem loan account. Citicorp is not alone with problem loans. About 30 percent of bank lending involves real estate, and the number of problem loans is expected to rise sharply as property values drop and building vacancies increase. Citicorp's real estate problems are especially thorny because the bank's portfolio has large holdings in the Northeast, among the hardest-hit areas in a recession now enveloping much of the country. The bank has $13.2 billion loans outstanding, according to reports, making it that largest commercial real estate lender in the country. Further, many large banks played a significant role in the leveraged buyout trend in the 1980s, which saddled many companies with risky debt. By some industry reckonings, highly leveraged loans account for 10 percent of the loan portfolio for the nation's seven largest banks. Like others, Brown Brothers analyst Soifer predicts Citicorp will set aside more cash to cover bank loans in the next year. ``It's hard to say how much because we don't know how bad the economy will get here,'' he said. The proposed dividend cut, to be presented to Citicorp's directors next month, surprised some in the banking community. Chairman John Reed stated recently a cut in dividends is an inefficient way to raise capital. ``They don't have a lot of choice here,'' said Goleniewski of Goldman Sachs. Banks have limited access to capital markets because they're greatly restricted in securities trading. Selling assets such as real estate holdings and subsidiary businesses are among the key alternatives to raising cash. Reed's action boosted investor confidence, said Ms. Wong of Fitch Investors. The credit rating agency reaffirmed Citicorp's senior debt rating at AA-minus late Tuesday. Ms. Wong said Citicorp's restructuring showed managers ``had the will'' to make painful adjustments in the face of bad financial news. ``It's an event that the analyst community has been anticipating. I think there is relief that Citicorp has come out with it prior to the fourth quarter announcement,'' Ms. Wong said. But a dividend cut places Citicorp in a very difficult position, said Soifer. Such a cut gives Citicorp just $260 million, hardly enough to cover the amount of its problem loans, believed to be at least $2 billion. He also said a cut in dividends might complicate future attempts to raise cash through the stock market. The banking company said it would sell some assets to raise cash, but did not elaborate. Few analysts are willing to speculate what might be sold. Such a sale is in line with economists' expectations of an overall consolidation in the industry. Bank of New England already has sold nearly $4 billion in assets in the face of the slumping economy. Timing of any sales will be crucial because of plummeting land values nationwide. The Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency charged with selling off assets of failed savings and loans, is generally viewed as depressing market prices as it tries to unload property.

DOC.HEAD: Major Bank Cuts Prime Rate to 9.5 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2 new grafs after 9th graf pvs, Today's prime ... to ADD comment from bank's economist; Picks up 10th graf pvs, Major banks ...
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's largest banks cut its prime lending rate by a steep 0.5 percentage point to 9.5 percent today, two days after the Federal Reserve lowered one if its key lending rates in an effort to prevent the recession from deepening. First National Bank of Chicago, the 13th largest U.S. banking company, said it would lower its prime rate from 10 percent effective immediately. Earlier in the month, a handful of regional banks took a more cautious step by easing their prime rates to 9.75 percent, but analysts said larger institutions were waiting for a cue from the Fed before following suit. The recent decline in the prime rate, which serves as a guide for bank lending charges for a host of business and consumer loans, marks the first cut in the rate in nearly a year. ``It is a long-overdue adjustment,'' said William Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The fact that this is the first major national money center bank to go might trigger others to follow soon.'' Sullivan noted that the 0.5 percentage point cut was a bit steeper than had been expected, but he said it indicated that banks ``are finally taking the message that the Fed wants rates lower.'' On Tuesday the Fed cut the discount rate - the interest it charges on loans to member banks - to 6.5 percent from 7 percent, the first decline in the rate since August 1986. But in addition, the Fed has also been gradually cutting the federal funds rate - the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans. The fed funds rate has been eased twice this month alone. It was trimmed a quarter of a percentage point on Dec. 7 and since has fallen to 7 percent. Today's prime rate cut ``is clearly in response to the Fed's recent actions, which included not only a drop in the funds rate but a downward adjustment in the discount rate,'' Sullivan said. James Annable, First Chicago's chief economist, said that by easing the fed funds rate, the nation's central bank ``is telling the market that we are taking this recession seriously.'' And once that rate moved lower, it was time to ``pass it on to our customers.'' Annable said consumers should see declines next month on loans that are tied to the prime rate, like home equity lines of credit. Major banks have hesitated to move ahead of the Fed because they are concerned about their own profit margins. The last industry-wide cut in the prime rate occurred on Jan. 8, when the rate when from 10.5 percent to 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Problem Loans Hurt Earnings Outlook
DOC.TEXT: C&S-Sovran Corp. said it's projecting a loss in the fourth quarter because of problem loans in the Washington, D.C., area. The banking company said it is setting aside $250 million this quarter to cover the possibly bad loans. ``Non-performing loans'' - those 90 days or more past due - are expected to rise by about $200 million in the quarter. But C&S-Sovran said it will report a profit for the full year and expects to declare a regular quarterly dividend of 39 cents per share in January. The company did not disclose its projected shortfall for the fourth quarter. Earnings for the year are expected to be about $210 million, or $1.60 per share, the bank said. That compares with $507.4 million, or $3.67 per share, for 1989. C&S-Sovran has $1.6 billion in loans in the Washington market, less than 5 percent of its $33 billion loan portfolio. President Dennis C. Bottorff declined to put a dollar figure on the current problems in Washington, but said non-performing assets there totaled between $40 million and $50 million before Wednesday's announcement. ``The D.C. market is definitely continuing to deteriorate,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Taj Mahal Must Present Financial Forecasts To Commission
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort has two weeks to submit its financial forecasts through 1995 as well as supporting documents for its restructuring of $675 million in bonds. In an unrelated matter, the state Casino Control Commission also ruled Wednesday against Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in admitting potentially damaging evidence in a discrimination case against the gambling hall. The commission said in its ongoing hearings on the financial stability of the 8{-month-old Taj Mahal that the casino must present its monthly forecasts for 1991 and quarterly predictions for the years 1992-95. The Taj Mahal must also submit fully executed documents to the commission that show how it plans to implement agreements with its lenders, Commission Chairman Steve Perskie said. Trump attorney Nicholas Ribis said he anticipated the financial forecasts and the documents would be ready by Dec. 28, adding that the Taj Mahal has successfully scrambled throughout this month to meet the commission's deadlines. ``The tough ones are behind us,'' Ribis said. The commission's hearings are looking at the stability of the Taj ahal, which renegotiated its $675 million in debt one day after failing to make a $47.3 million payment due Nov. 15. The casino intends to file a ``pre-packaged'' bankruptcy under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code and leave bankruptcy protection by spring. The Taj Mahal's restructuring would give bondholders half ownership in the Taj Mahal in exchange for accepting a smaller interest rate, 12 percent instead of 14 percent. Perskie said he anticipates conducting the next hearing on the Taj Mahal sometime in January after the commission can study all the data. The commission has the power to take away a license if it finds the casino operator is financially unstable. The commission also voted unanimously Wednesday to allow more evidence concerning charges that Trump Plaza discriminated against its black and female employees. The charges say Robert Libutti's racist demands prompted the casino to move the employees. He has denied he is a racist. Libutti, a much-coveted high roller from Saddle River who wagered as much as $10,000 on a roll of the dice, allegedly used epithets on at least 59 occasions between May 1986 and May 1988 to get white male dealers on his craps game. Perskie said Administrative Law Judge Lillard Law erred in his Aug. 17 ruling by not allowing consideration of evidence gathered against the casino after May 1988. The state Division of Gaming Enforcement, an arm of the state Attorney General's office, said the evidence would show Trump Plaza's reasons for moving employees were a pretext for its discrimination. ``If such evidence is relevant in proving whether or not the alleged violations occurred, it should have been admitted,'' Perskie said. The gaming division has proposed fines of between $590,000 and $975,000, either of which would be the largest fine in the 12{-year history of legalized gambling here. The casino contends the division failed to prove one specific instance where the casino discriminated against an employee.

DOC.HEAD: Food Company to Buy Hungarian Processor
DOC.TEXT: Sara Lee Corp. officials said they hope to expand business into Eastern Europe with the planned purchase of major interest in Hungary's third largest food company, Compack Trading and Packing Co. The move to acquire interest in Compack has been accepted by the State Property Agency of Hungary, Sara Lee announced Wednesday. Terms of the offer are subject to approval by the Sara Lee board of directors and were not disclosed. ``Sara Lee is very pleased with this partnership, which will expand our coffee and grocery positions into Eastern Europe,'' said John Bryan, Sara Lee chairman and chief executive officer. ``Compack's product line perfectly complements Sara Lee's European coffee and grocery business.'' Compack, headquartered in Budapest, is Hungary's largest coffee roaster. It also produces and sells teas, spices, rice and household products with annual sales estimated at $140 million. The joint venture will be managed by Sara Lee-DE, N.V., a Netherlands-based company that operates Sara Lee Corp.'s coffee, grocery and household and personal care businesses in Europe. Sara Lee markets food and consumer products under the brand names of Hanes, Champion, Kiwi, Jimmy Dean and Sara Lee, among others.

The stock market declined broadly today, unsettled by international worries and new questions about the interest-rate outlook. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 21.28 to 2,605.45 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 5 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 190 up, 923 down and 419 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 24.17 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the news of Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation as Soviet foreign minister had put many traders on their guard. The Bush administration indicated that it was awaiting more information before appraising the situation. Stock-market investors seemed to be in a similarly wary mood. In addition, brokers said doubts had spread in the past day or two over how much further the Federal Reserve might go in the near future toward easing credit conditions. After the Fed's announcement Tuesday of a cut in its discount rate, interest rates in the bond market turned upward Wednesday. Among actively traded blue chips, General Electric dropped { to 56[; Philip Morris ] to 50|; International Business Machines [ to 112|, and American Telephone & Telegraph \ to 31. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.27 to 179.08. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.38 at 305.27. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average was unchanged at 2,626.73. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 4 on the NYSE, with 844 up, 688 down and 504 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 180.38 million shares, against 176.46 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Coke Enterprises Buying Back More Stock
DOC.TEXT: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. announced Thursday it has finished one stock buy-back and is starting another. CCE said it repurchased about 1.5 million shares from public shareholders and the Coca-Cola Co. during the fourth quarter, completing a two-year program to buy back 25 million shares of stock. ``CCE's ability to make this kind of strategic investment without increasing its debt leverage is a testimony to the strength of our company's cash flow generation capabilities,'' said Brian G. Dyson, president and chief executive officer. The bottling company, which is 49 percent owned by the Coca-Cola Co., said its board of directors also approved a new program to repurchase up to 15 millions of shares of common stock. The repurchase will be funded from excess cash flow, which the company doesn't expect to begin spending until the second or third quarter of 1991. It said the Coca-Cola Co. will participate in the share repurchase program to maintain its ownership at the 49 percent level. The company has about 115 million shartes outstanding.

DOC.HEAD: Aetna Drops Personal Insurance in Oklahoma, Washington and Arkansas
DOC.TEXT: Aetna Life & Casualty Co. has announced plans to withdraw from personal insurance in Oklahoma, Washington and Arkansas because of financial losses and too little business. The company said Wednesday that nearly 27,000 policies will be dropped. Aetna has cut its number of personal auto policies nationally by nearly 16 percent since the end of 1989, from 2.1 million to 1.8 million at the end of November 1990. Aetna spokesman John Hawkins said withdrawals from more states are likely as the company continues to review its business. The moves are part of Aetna's decision to put capital behind business it expects to be profitable over time and to withdraw from states or lines of business that do not produce adequate returns on investment. Earlier this year, Aetna announced withdrawal from auto insurance in South Carolina, and from auto and homeowners' lines in New Mexico, Idaho, Nevada and Arizona. In addition, the insurer is no longer selling new personal auto policies in Pennsylvania or Rhode Island, and is suing Massachusetts over rules that make it expensive to withdraw from auto insurance there. Aetna has lost money in personal lines in Oklahoma, Washington and Arkansas, Hawkins said. No figures were available, he said. The company has only a small part of the market in the three states. In Oklahoma, for instance, where Aetna has 4,872 auto and homeowners' policies, the company is the 26th largest vendor of personal insurance, Hawkins said. In Arkansas, with 3,956 auto and homeowners' policies in force, Aetna is the 18th largest player in auto insurance. And in Washington, Aetna is ranked 15th in auto insurance with about 10,000 auto policies. The company has 8,000 homeowners' polices in Washington. Aetna will stop selling new personal policies in Oklahoma on Friday, in Washington by the end of the year, and in Arkansas in February, Hawkins said.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, Fiat Sign Tractor Deal
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. and Italy's huge Fiat Group signed final agreements to form a new agricultural implement company merging their FiatGeotech and Ford New Holland Inc. subsidiaries, the companies said Thursday. The companies said July 31 they had agreed in principle to form the new company in which Fiat would have an 80 percent interest. Ford would receive an undisclosed cash payment and own 20 percent. The transaction is subject to government approval. The companies said in July that Fiat would continue current pay and benefits under a United Auto Workers union contract with the Ford subsidiary headquartered in New Holland, Pa. The FiatGeotech and Ford New Holland brand names will continue to be used. The new company's headquarters will be in London. FiatGeotech has more than 13,000 employees in Italy, Brazil, France and the United States. Ford New Holland has about 18,000 workers in the United States, Canada, Great Britain, Belgium and Brazil.

The stock market gave ground today, unsettled by international worries and new questions about the interest-rate outlook. DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Continue Lower On Soviet News
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly in reaction to news of the resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Analysts said the resignation raises questions about future U.S.-Soviet dealings, including Soviet grain purchases and the willingness of the Bush administration to grant export credits to Moscow. Don Roose, grains analyst with U.S. Commodities Inc. of Des Moines, Iowa, said the early selling also reflected weaker cash markets and a general lack of positive news after indications of a large Soviet purchase of South American soybean meal pushed soybean futures prices down sharply on Wednesday. Soybean for January delivery dropped 7 cents a bushel Wednesday; grain futures also retreated. In early trading today, wheat futures were unchanged to 2\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $2.60{ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.34\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower with March at $1.13\ a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents to 3} cents lower with January at $5.73\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after a government report on Wednesday showed a larger-than-expected number of cattle on feed as of the end of November. In early trading, live cattle were .02 cent lower to .10 cent higher with December at 80.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent to .15 cent higher with January at 88.90 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .25 cent lower with February at 49.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .35 cent to .75 cent higher with February at 64.45 cents a pound. Cattle futures fell and pork futures rose on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Proposes Requiring Companies to Provide More Recent Information
DOC.TEXT: The accounting industry's rule-making board has proposed that businesses supply more up-to-date financial information to investors, a move that could prove costly to companies battered by a soft economy. The Financial Accounting Standards Board agreed late Tuesday to propose requiring companies to disclose in footnotes in their financial statements the market value of many assets that are now merely shown at their original cost. The New York Times said the proposal would apply to nearly all categories of financial instruments, including stocks, bonds, options and, in the case of financial institutions, customer deposits and loans. The proposed market-based accounting rule could prove costly to companies suffering in today's softening economy. Earlier this month FASB approved a far-reaching change in the way businesses report health-care costs for retired workers, a move that has the potential to slash millions of dollars from comapnies' financial earnings. But the traditional approach, scornfully dubbed ``once-upon-a-time accounting'' by critics, may have little relation to actual worth in a slumping economy. It has been faulted for contributing to the crisis facing financial institutions by letting them avoid revising loan portfolios to reflect falling values. The proposal on market values is open to public comment for four months before it can be made final.

DOC.HEAD: Portugal To Privatize Leading Daily Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The government said Thursday it plans to offer stock to the public in the prestigious daily newspaper Diario de Noticias, completing its privatization of the Portuguese press. Government spokesman Luis Marques Mendes did not give a date for the sale, but sources at the paper said it was expected in early February. The sale of 2 million Diario de Noticias shares is expected to bring the state about $75 million. The real estate value of the paper's offices on Lisbon's downtown Avenida da Liberdade accounts for almost half the price. Marques Mendes said 10 percent of newspaper's shares will be reserved for the paper's employees, 25 percent will be offered to cooperatives of journalists and other newspaper workers and 25 percent will be offered to other media groups. The remaining 40 percent will be open to general investors. Founded in 1864, the paper claims a circulation of 50,000. It is Portugal's fourth-largest daily. The paper is widely-respected for its sober and impartial reporting of national and international news. This year the paper has invested heavily in modernizing its editorial and production systems. Nine major daily or weekly papers in Portugal have closed in the past two years, but the paper popularly known as DN has prospered. It is expected to register a profit of $3.85 million this year. The privatization will conclude the plans of Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva to sell off newspapers brought under state control in the mid-1970s. In May, the government earned $57 million from the sale of the widest-circulation paper, Jornal de Noticias. The newspaper sales are part of a wider project to place state enterprises back into private hands. Eight companies, including banks, breweries and insurance firms, have been wholly or partly privatized this year.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Dixon in Fraud, Conspiracy Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 2nd graf to show Dixon convicted of 23 counts, sted 22; SUBS 5th graf to add Dixon's impassive demeanor.
DOC.TEXT: Don R. Dixon, one of the first savings and loan owners to be accused of fraud in the industry's nationwide debacle, was convicted today of using depositor money to finance a high-flying life. A jury of eight men and four women deliberated two weeks before convicting Dixon on 23 counts of a 38-count indictment that accused him of using thousands of dollars from Vernon Savings Association to finance extravagances that included California beach-house parties. Dixon, 52, owned Vernon from 1981 to 1986 when it grew 10-fold. The thrift's failure in 1987 cost taxpayers $1.3 billion and was one of the first costly collapses of the savings and loan crisis. Dixon had been indicted earlier this year for misapplication of funds, making false statements, and other crimes. If convicted on all charges, he could have been sentenced to 190 years in jail and fined as much as $9.5 million. He watched impassively while the verdict was read and embraced his tearful wife after the hearing concluded. U.S. District Judge Joe Fish set sentencing for Feb. 19. Testimony lasted more than five weeks with about two dozen witnesses, including Dixon. Some former Vernon employees testified Dixon directed them to reimburse themselves with the thrift's money for political contributions. Others said he ordered them to hire prostitutes for parties at a beach house near San Diego. Witnesses also said Dixon crafted a scheme to divert loan advances to pay rent on the house and doctored records to hide Vernon's ownership of the house from thrift regulators. Dixon also tried to curry favor from former Texas Savings and Loan Department commissioner Linton Bowman by taking him on trips to Kansas and California and arranging for women to sleep with him, witnesses said. Dixon testified that knew of no illegal activity at the thrift during the time he owned it. He blamed employees for the wrongdoing he said he learned about during the trial. The house at Solana Beach, Calif., was a hotel and office for Vernon as it expanded into the southern California real estate market, he said. The parties were a tiny part of $10 million that the thrift spent on marketing and public relations while he was owner, Dixon said. He said that in hindsight hiring women to attend the parties was inappropriate, but not illegal. The thrift's asset base grew more than tenfold under Dixon's ownership. One year, Vernon made a $50 million profit. But in 1986, more than 90 percent of Vernon's loans were not being repaid. Vernon's net worth had sunk to a negative $716.86 million when regulators took it over. The failure in 1987 helped galvanize the attention of the public and lawmakers to the troubles in the savings and loan industry. Regulators found Vernon owned 17th century castle doors and expensive art objects, including a Baccarat eagle and a silver-studded saddle. The thrift also owned a yacht in Washington, used by some members of Congress for parties. Seven other Vernon officials - including former chairman Woody Lemons - a consultant and two borrowers have been convicted or pleaded guilty to various crimes in connection with the thrift. Lemons in April was sentenced to 30 years in prison for misapplication of funds, conspiracy and bank fraud. It was the stiffest penalty handed a figure in the savings and loan crisis. But prosecutors and investigators for months have painted Dixon as the main culprit behind the crimes. Dixon also is the lead defendant in a $540 million federal fraud lawsuit filed in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Shares End Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices ended lower on London's Stock Exchange Thursday, as the resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze created uncertainty in the financial markets. The resignation ``does add to the general economic uncertainty which makes markets nervous,'' said John Reynolds, equity strategist at the London brokerage firm County Natwest Woodmac. Wall Street also was having its share of jitters over the news. Throughout most of the European afternoon, the Dow Jones industrial average was under pressure, although by the close of the session in London, Wall Street appeared to be reversing its losses. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 19.9 points, or 0.9 percent, at 2,158.8 at the close. The Financial Times 30-share index fell 19.9 points to close at 1,687.2. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 9.79 points to close a 1,143.22. Volume was 590.2 million shares compared with 509.3 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Short-Term Economic Prospects Worsening, Economic Group Reports
With AM-Economy Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The short-term outlook for the world economy has worsened markedly in recent months, the Organization of Economic Development and Cooperation said in a major report Thursday. The organization of 24 major industrial democracies said in a twice-yearly report that the rise in oil prices has boosted inflation and curtailed output. It said Eastern European countries face special difficulties as they try to convert to market economies. And it gave a gloomy assessment of the Soviet Union's economic health. Among the OECD's own members, the United States was repeatedly singled out as a cause of particular economic concern. ``Differences have become more accentuated between the buoyancy of activity in some countries, notably Japan and western Germany, and its weakness in a number of other countries, including the United States,'' the report said. ``Inflation remains under control in western Germany and Japan, but is relatively high in the United States,'' the report said. It noted that the dollar's weakness was contributing to inflationary pressures in the U.S. economy. The report said developments in the world's financial markets ``have been disquieting.'' ``Equity prices have plunged and market-determined interest rates have risen in many countries, only in part because of the Gulf situation,'' it said. ``Fragility persists in some sectors of U.S. financial markets where banks are limiting credits to certain classes of borrowers; and questions have risen about banks' balance sheets in Japan ...'' ``These developments, together with the effects of higher oil prices, have led to a less favorable view of the short-term economic outlook than before the summer; inflation is likely to be higher and output weaker.'' The OECD projected that economic activity among its members could expand by 2 percent in 1991, picking up to 2.5 percent in 1992. It said unemployment would increase from 6.25 percent of the labor force in the first half of 1990 to almost 7 percent in 1992. Consumer price inflation was likely to be 6 percent annually in the first half of 1991, but could drop to under 4.5 percent by late 1992. The projections were based on an oil price of $27 per barrel and noted that if prices rose further, ``the task of policy in containing inflation and supporting confidence would be harder.'' The report also said: - Government deficits in the United States and Germany will be greater than expected. The OECD estimated that the U.S. deficit would be about $250 billion in fiscal 1991 and could increase the following year. The recent U.S. budget-cutting agreement ``will substantially strengthen control over public expenditure,'' the report said. ``Nonetheless, the federal government deficit is likely to remain large for several years.'' - Global problems such as rising interest rates and higher oil prices will complicate the tasks of Eastern European countries as they switch to market economies. Although reforms have begun, ``output declined in 1990 in all these countries and is likely at best to stabilize in 1991, while inflation remains a widespread problem.'' ``In the Soviet Union, specific reform measures have not yet been agreed to, let alone implemented,'' the report added. ``Soviet output is falling, inflation is accelerating and ... the trade balance could deteriorate.'' The OECD said its members could help Eastern Europe by ensuring that their own markets were open. ``More liberal trade policies would contribute to a more stable as well as more prosperous world,'' the report said. The member nations of the OECD are: Australia, Austria, Belgium, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Regulators OK Takeover of Seabrook Nuclear Plant Owner
DOC.TEXT: The takeover of the troubled Public Service Co. of New Hampshire cleared another regulatory hurdle today as federal securities authorities gave their blessing to the reorganization plan. Connecticut-based Northeast Utilities wants to acquire the New Hampshire utility which is the majority owner of the Seabrook nuclear power plant. The Securities and Exchange Commission approved two alternative plans for Berlin, Conn.-based Northeast Utilities to acquire PSNH, the largest electric utility in New Hampshire. The acquisition is part of PSNH's plan to emerge from bankruptcy law proceedings. It sought court protection from its creditors in January 1988 so it could develop a plan of reorganization. Under one plan, PSNH would be come a wholly-owned subsidiary of Northeast, through Northeast's acquisition of a new issue of PSNH common stock. The new subsidiary would own and operate all of PSNH's assets, except Seabrook, which would be owned by another new Northeast subsidiary called North Atlantic. But that deal would have to be approved by Dec. 31 to take effect. More likely is a two-step plan, in which Northeast would provide money for PSNH to function on its own until the Connecticut holding company could actually take over PSNH and form it into a subsidiary. Although the SEC approved both plans, the deal is still subject to approval by federal energy and nuclear power regulators as well as several state agencies. The SEC regulates public utility holding companies - like Northeast Utilities - that maintain interstate facilities. There are about nine such electrical utilities. The PSNH reorganization is being held up by appeals of the state Public Utilities Commission's approval of Northeast's $2.3 billion takeover plan. In addition, the New Hampshire Electric Cooperative has filed a $200 million claim against Public Service. The claim says the co-op was defrauded in 1981 on cost and schedule projections for the Seabrook nuclear power plant, on which it based its decision to buy 2.2 percent of the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Polly Peck Chief Freed on Bail
DOC.TEXT: Asil Nadir, chief executive of troubled Polly Peck International PLC, was freed Thursday on $6.8 million bail after spending five nights in jail. James Perriss, governor of London's Wormwood Scrubbs Prison, confirmed the release of Nadir, a 48-year-old Turkish-Cypriot businessman who was arrested Saturday. He faces 18 charges of theft and false accounting in connection with the affairs of his troubled fruit and electronics conglomerate. One of his attorneys, Peter Knight, said Nadir would strenuously fight the charges of false accounting and theft of an alleged $48 million between June 1988 and July 1990. Nadir is required to live and sleep at his London address and to report daily to a police stationm, according to terms set by a magistrate. The businessman also had to surrender his passport and was barred from buying travel tickets. Scotland Yard's fraud squad in recent months has been investigating alleged irregularities in share dealings in Polly Peck. The company was turned over to court-appointed administrators in October after its shares collapsed on the London Stock Exchange. The administrators are trying to sort out the company's $2.5 billion in debt while it continues to operate under court protection from creditors.

DOC.HEAD: Famed California Vinter Hands Daily Winery Management to Sons
DOC.TEXT: Robert Mondavi, the globe-trotting chairman of the Napa Valley winery that bears his name, retired Thursday from daily management operations. He remains chairman. ``I've been a manager and I'll miss it,'' said the 77-year-old visionary, who is credited with dragging the sleepy California wine industry of the early 1960s into the arena of world-class winemaking. ``I want to see my sons achieve what I've achieved, and I think they will. ... The future is bright,'' Mondavi said of his sons Michael and Timothy, president and winemaker respectively, and equal managing partners. ``The Robert Mondavi family will continue its dedication to and active participation in the production and marketing of the highest quality premium varietal wines,'' Michael and Tim said in a joint statement. Mondavi left his family's Charles Krug Winery and in 1966 built the first new winery in California since Prohibition. The Spanish mission-style winery draws nearly 500,000 visitors a year. The Mondavi family also owns other California wineries.

DOC.HEAD: Expresses Disapproval Over Hong Kong Bank's Move
DOC.TEXT: China rebuked Hong Kong's leading bank Thursday for plans to reorganize under a British holding company, which has been viewed as a sign of eroding confidence in the colony that reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp., which in some ways acts like Hong Kong's central bank because it issues more than half the local currency, announced the reorganization Monday. The change reflected similar moves taken by hundreds of other Hong Kong companies, fearing what may happen to the capitalist enclave in the transition to Chinese sovereignty. But the bank's move was considered particularly significant because it is one of Hong Kong's most influential businesses. ``We believe that as an important financial and commercial institution, the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp. should see to it that any new measure it takes will help promote rather than undermine the stability and prosperity of Hong Kong,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing said. ``The Chinese government has all along worked to maintain the stability and prosperity of Hong Kong for the benefit of Hong Kong residents and the benefit of both China and the United Kingdom,'' Li said. William Purves, chairman of the bank, said the decision to reorganize reflected the bank's global reach and did not signal abandonment of the territory where it has flourished for 125 years. Under an agreement with Britain, the Chinese have promised to preserve Hong Kong's way of life for at least 50 years beyond 1997. But faith in that pledge was shaken by the June 1989 military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in China. Confidence also has eroded because of bickering between China and Britain over the exact terms of the takeover agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Second Quarter Earnings Increase
DOC.TEXT: Foods giant ConAgra Inc. said Thursday its earnings for the second fiscal quarter climbed 38 percent on a similar rise in sales, partly because of the recently-acquired Beatrice Foods Co. businesses. ConAgra said its net income for the quarter that ended Nov. 25 rose to $88.3 million, or 60 cents per share, from $63.9 million, or 52 cents per share, for the same period last year. Second-quarter sales also rose 38 percent to $5.33 billion from $3.86 billion. ConAgra's products range from Healthy Choice frozen dinners, Banquet and Chun King frozen foods, Butterball and La Choy products and the Hunt-Wesson brands. It also makes fertilizers and agriculture chemicals. For the first half, net income rose rose 28.4 percent to $146.2 million, or $1.06 a share, from $113.9 million, or 92 cents a share, a year ago. First-half sales rose 25 percent to $9.82 billion from $7.86 billion. Charles M. Harper, ConAgra chairman and chief executive officer, attributed some of the increase to the Beatrice business. ConAgra acquired Beatrice on Aug. 14 for a combination of cash and stock valued at $1.34 billion. Beatrice operations were included in ConAgra results for two weeks of the first quarter of fiscal 1991 and for the entire second quarter, the company said. Beatrice earnings to date have been ahead of plan, ConAgra said. Beatrice businesses such as Hunt-Wesson and Swift-Eckrich products and Beatrice Cheese were a key source of a major increase in operating profit in ConAgra's Prepared Food segment, the company said. ``ConAgra's second quarter was highlighted by good earnings balance, aggressive activity in new consumer products and excellent progress bringing the Beatrice businesses on board,'' Harper said. ``In fact, the Beatrice businesses added to the second quarter earnings per share, as well as making a substantial contribution to sales and net income,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Angola Re-enters Diamond Cartel
DOC.TEXT: Angola, a major diamond producing nation, is re-entering the De Beers diamond cartel after five years, De Beers said Thursday. Endiama, the Angolan state diamond company, and De Beers Centenary AG on Thursday signed an agreement re-establishing their relationship, De Beers said. Under the agreement, De Beer's Central Selling Organization will market Angola's diamonds from its Cuango region, or about three-quarters of the country's annual production of one million carats, said Roger van Eeghen, a De Beers spokesman. De Beers also will provide Endiama with a $50 million loan to increase production in the Cuango area, and another $50 million over the next five years to develop other diamond sources in Angola. Angola had been marketing its diamonds independently since 1985 after civil war prompted De Beers to pull out, Van Eeghen said. About 80 percent of the world's annual diamond production is sorted and sold by the London-based Central Selling Organization. It had diamond sales of $4.1 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slide on USSR News
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices fell Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid fears that Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation could lead to a halt in Soviet purchases of U.S. grain. The decline in prices reflected a worst-case scenario in which Soviet President Gorbachev also would quit and the Soviet militia would be called upon to quell civil unrest, said William Biedermann, research director for Allendale Inc., a commodities brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. Traders also feared that if Gorbachev were to resign or be forced out by conservatives, the United States would withdraw a $1 billion line of food export credit it extended to the Soviets last week. ``A military crackdown would not bode well'' for future credit offers, said analyst Don Roose of U.S. Commodities Inc. in Des Moines, Iowa. At the close, wheat futures were 1{ cents to 2} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $2.60\ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.34\ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 2\ cents lower with March at $1.11{ a bushel; soybeans were 2} cents to 5} cents lower with January at $5.71 a bushel.
