DOC.HEAD: Securities Firm To Report $250 Million Loss
DOC.TEXT: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. will report a 1990 loss of about $250 million, more than double what analysts had expected and a further sign of the malaise gripping Wall Street, its parent said Thursday. The Prudential Insurance Co. of America also said it had injected $200 million in new capital into the struggling investment firm, which has abandoned or reduced several key businesses in a major restructuring. The equity infusion is the latest move by a big corporate parent this year to contain losses at firms pummeled by a collapse in merger activity and the junk bond market. The securities industry has cut more than 50,000 jobs nationwide since the 1987 stock market crash. This year, layoffs have been concentrated in high-paying jobs such as investment banking. The anticipated $250 million loss at Prudential-Bache exceeds analysts' forecasts of $75 million to $100 million. Including 1990, Prudential-Bache has been unprofitable in three of the last four years. The firm lost $51 million in 1989. Prudential, an insurance and financial services company, in a statement attributed the loss at its securities subsidiary to drastic cuts in four core areas intended ``to reduce exposure to unprofitable businesses.'' Prudential-Bache in recent months laid off two-thirds of its investment bankers, or 120 professionals, closed its risk arbitrage trading operation, sold its Canadian arm and reduced its limited partnership activities. Prudential-Bache Chairman George L. Ball said in a memo to employees that the firm had spent $370 million on costs associated with the reductions, including severance payments. He said the lower total loss indicates ``very healthy core profitability in our other activities.'' In addition to the $200 million equity infusion, the parent company said it was acquiring all of Prudential-Bache's merchant banking assets and that the business in the future would be managed by the parent. Spokesmen for the companies declined to say how much the merchant banking assets totaled. The firm said it had a capital base of $1.6 billion and that the infusion was not made to meet federal regulatory requirements. Merchant banking is one of the areas hardest hit during the Wall Street slowdown. It involves investing a firm's own capital into merger deals, often with risky junk bonds. Many of those transactions have soured because of the market's decline and the shaky status of many takeovers. Prudential Insurance bought Bache Group Inc. in 1984 for $385 million and has invested more than $1 billion into the securities firm, which failed in an attempt to become an investment banking power and is returning to its retail brokerage roots. Prudential spokesman Joe Vecchione said the capital injection was a sign of support for the investment firm. He said the company and Ball ``have the full support of the Prudential.'' ``We're longterm investors,'' Vecchione said. ``We're willing to weather downturns in the business.'' Prudential-Bache, which has 17,000 employees, down from 19,000 a year ago, said it would focus on its individual investor and mutual fund activities, which made money in 1990. In his memo to employees, Ball said the firm would highlight ``the burgeoning financial needs of affluent individual investors'' in the United States and abroad. As part of its cost-cutting efforts, Prudential-Bache this week confirmed it is negotiating with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. to merge data processing operations for securities transactions. Firms expanded those operations in the 1980s but now have excess capacity because of a decline in the retail business since 1987. Perrin Long, an industry analyst with Lipper Analytical Securities Corp., said the $200 million capital injection would improve Prudential-Bache's balance sheet and help broker recruitment because it was a sign of stability. Other companies have been forced to help bail out securities subsidiaries this year. American Express Co. injected more than $1 billion and took full control of Shearson, and CS Holdings pumped more than $700 million into CS First Boston Inc. and assumed the bulk of the firm's outstanding ``bridge loans'' from problematic merchant banking deals.

DOC.HEAD: Acquisition of Seabrook Owner OK'd by Stock Regulators
DOC.TEXT: Acquisition of the bankrupt New Hampshire utility that controls the Seabrook nuclear plant was approved by federal stock regulators Thursday, eliminating one more roadblock to the power company's reorganization plan. Northeast Utilities wants to acquire Public Service Co. of New Hampshire, which holds the largest stake, 35.6 percent, in the controversial Seabrook plant. The Securities and Exchange Commission approved two methods for the acquisition of PSNH, the largest electrical utility in New Hampshire, by Berlin, Conn.-based Northeast Utilities. The acquisition is the key part of PSNH's plan to emerge from bankruptcy reorganization, which it entered in January 1988 to seek protection from creditors. ``The citizens of New Hampshire will be well benefitted from having a well-run, viable, economically sound, well-managed public utility company in place of a bankrupt one that cannot plan or look forward to future developments,'' said Marianne K. Smythe, head of the SEC's Division of Investment Management. The SEC regulates public utility holding companies - like Northeast Utilities - that maintain interstate facilities. There are nine such electrical utilities around the country. In a separate action, the SEC decided to submit for public comment proposed rules changes that would cut some of the red tape involved in offering foreign securities for sale in this country. The SEC gave its blessing to two possible ways for Northeast Utilities to acquire PSNH. Under the first method, PSNH would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Northeast, through Northeast's acquisition of a new issue of PSNH common stock. That new subsidiary, to be called New PSNH, would own and operate all of PSNH's assets, except Seabrook, which are valued at $1.62 billion. The Seabrook assets, worth an estimated $700 million, would be owned by still another new Northeast subsidiary called North Atlantic. That deal would have to be approved by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, state regulators and the courts by Dec. 31. More likely is the second, two-step plan in which Northeast would provide money for PSNH to function on its own until the Connecticut holding company could actually merge PSNH into a newly created subsidiary to be called Northeast Utilities Acquisition Corp. The acquisition of PSNH would be financed by cash and various new securities, including common and preferred stock, bonds and notes. While approved by the SEC, this plan is still subject to clearance by federal energy and nuclear power regulators as well as several state agencies. Northeast owns Connecticut Light and Power Co., Western Massachusetts Electric Co. and Holyoke Water Power Co. Meanwhile Thursday, an administrative law judge found the proposed PSNH-Northeast merger would be in the public interest and recommended approval by the FERC, subject to certain conditions. The FERC isn't expected to take up the matter until early next year, however. The PSNH reorganization plan is being held up by an appeal to the New Hampshire Supreme Court of a decision by that state's Public Utilities Commission to approve Northeast's $2.3 billion takeover plan. Another roadblock is a $200 million claim filed against Public Service by the New Hampshire Electric Cooperative. The claim alleges the co-op was defrauded on cost and schedule projections for the Seabrook plant, on which it based its decision to buy 2.2 percent of the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Sports Illustrated Plans Supplement for Time in Australia, New Zealand
DOC.TEXT: The international editions of Time magazine circulated in Australia and New Zealand will carry a monthly supplement drawn from Sports Illustrated starting in January, the sports magazine said Thursday. Joe Marshall, Sports Illustrated's director of special projects, said the inclusion of a 32-page supplement called Sports Illustrated: Special Australian and New Zealand Monthly will begin with the Jan. 7 issue of Time. He said the plan offered an opportunity to expose more Australian readers to the sports magazine. The international edition of Time has a weekly circulation of 145,000 in Australia and New Zealand, but there are only 496 subscribers to Sports Illustrated in those countries, spokesman Roger Jackson said. The supplement will include three to five stories taken from the previous month's issues of the weekly sports magazine. It will include 9{ pages of advertising along with 22{ pages of editorial material. Time and Sports Illustrated are both published by Time Inc. Magazine Co., a unit of the media and entertainment giant Time Warner Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor Says 4,000 Could be Laid Off
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. said Thursday that 4,000 workers could lose their jobs if the Navy's A-12 Avenger program is scrapped. The defense contractor said it will notify about 4,000 McDonnell Aircraft employees that they could be laid off as soon as Jan. 2. Officials said the layoffs will be across-the-board throughout the company and will not be limited to people working on the A-12 program. The majority of the 6,000 workers in the A-12 program are in St. Louis. The government has not decided whether the program will be cancelled, but it is considering that option because it believes McDonnell Douglas is in default on the A-12's fixed-price full-scale development contract. A decision on the program's status could come as soon as Jan. 2. The aerospace firm maintains it is not in default on the contract. It had earlier proposed that the contract be restructured. McDonnell Douglas and its partner in the project, General Dynamics Corp., have said they believe they have solved the major technical problems with the plane. McDonnell Douglas spokesman Jim Reed said that officials on the A-12 team will continue to hold discussions with the Navy and the office of the Secretary of Defense ``to resolve difficulties and assure continuation of this vital national defense program on a mutually satisfactory basis.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Surges On Shevardnadze Resignation
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished broadly higher Thursday as traders sought a safe haven in the wake of the uncertainties created by the resignation of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Gold prices rose in Europe but retreated slightly in U.S. trading. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $385.90 a troy ounce, off 10 cents from Wednesday. Later, Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $383.35 an ounce, down 55 cents. The dollar gained ground in European trading and continued its climb when dealings shifted to domestic markets. Though traders were buying dollars, much of the day's activity centered on selling the German mark on the theory that Germany is more widely exposed to the economic and political climate in the Soviet Union than other nations. ``Germany has large loans outstanding (to the Soviet Union), and because of German monetary union, there was great expectation that they would find a huge export market within the Soviet Union,'' said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago. John McCarthy, chief dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York, characterized trading as ``a flight out of Germany rather than a flight to quality.'' He predicted that ``we will have to see more disintegration in the Soviet Union before there is any real permanent effect'' on dollar trading. Still, Shevardnadze's resignation was dramatic enough to distract attention from the deepening U.S. recession and declining interest rates. Lower interest rates generally are bearish for the dollar because they erode the value of fixed-income securities. The move ``brings the market focus to the economic fundamentals of Europe and takes some of the focus off the economic concerns in the U.S.,'' Malpede said. Trading was active but typically thin ahead of the Christmas holiday, which accentuated the dollar's advance. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 134.58 Japanese yen from 133.27 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it rose further to 134.75 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 135.85 yen, up from 134.05 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9080 from $1.9316 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.8930 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9310. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.5125 German marks, up from 1.4783; 1.2995 Swiss francs, up from 1.2675; 5.1425 French francs, up from 5.0425; 1,139.20 Italian lire, up from 1,117.75, and 1.1593 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1588. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.4997 West German marks, up from 1.4780; 1.2880 Swiss francs, up from 1.2690; 5.1035 French francs, up from 5.0405; 1.6920 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6735; 1,132.25 Italian lire, up from 1,117.25, and 1.1593 Canadian dollars, unchanged. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $385.25 a troy ounce from $380.50 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $385 an ounce from $380. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $5.15 to close at a bid $382.62. Silver prices rose. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $4.199 a troy ounce, from $4.095 on Wednesday. In London the metal rose to a late bid price of $4.18 an ounce from $4.03.

DOC.HEAD: Plans To Appeal 10-Year Sentence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `In addition... to RESTORE to three years' probation; PICKS UP 5th graf, `Milken, the...
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for convicted junk bond financier Michael Milken have notified a federal court they intend to appeal his 10-year prison sentence. The legal notice of appeal was filed Wednesday in federal court in Manhattan. It does not state the basis for an appeal to the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, which must be made later. Milken, 44, was sentenced last month by U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood for his guilty plea to six felony counts related to illegal securities trading. In addition to his 10-year term, he was sentenced to three years' probation and agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. Milken is to report to federal custody in March. Milken, the former head of junk bonds at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., admitted to conspiracy, securities fraud, violating federal securities guidelines, mail fraud and helping to file a false tax return. A spokesman for Milken declined to comment of the notice of appeal. Criminal defendants normally do not have the right to appeal the length of a sentence. But when a judge considers allegations of unadmitted crimes, as Wood did after a two-week hearing in the Milken case, a defendant can try to argue that the hearing was unfair.

DOC.NOTE: For release 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: Find Bleak Expectations For Early '91 Sales, Profits, Employment
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Business expectations for sales, profits and employment in the first quarter of 1991 are at the lowest point since the 1982 recession, said a quarterly survey released Thursday by the Dun & Bradstreet Corp. Findings in the survey by the leading provider of business information were consistent with a broad array of other evidence that shows the nation has lapsed into a recession. Dun & Bradstreet's sales-optimism index, down 10 points in the last quarterly survey released after Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait, fell another 14 points in the current survey of 1,500 business executives nationwide. ``Business optimism is down sharply,'' said Dun & Bradstreet's chief economist, Joseph W. Duncan. ``Softness in the domestic economy, coupled with the uncertainty on the international scene due to events in the Middle East, has pushed expectations to their lowest levels in eight years.'' Despite oil-price inflation caused by the Middle East crisis, Duncan said, ``most businesses do not see opportunities to increase their own prices, so profit expectations have dipped to very low levels.'' The survey showed sales optimism fell in every major industry group, particularly in retailing, which has been weathering a rough Christmas selling season, historically its most critical time of year. Expectations for higher employment in the first quarter of 1991 also reflected the gloomiest outlook since the last nationwide recession, the survey showed. Dun & Bradstreet's latest survey, conducted between Nov. 1 and Nov. 20, queried executives in manufacturing, retailing and wholesaling on whether they expected an increase, decrease or no change in first-quarter sales, profits, prices, inventories, employment, exports and new orders. Based in New York, Dun & Bradstreet is the world's largest marketer of business information and related services, with worldwide revenue of $4.3 billion last year. It has conducted the quarterly survey on business expectations since 1947. In another economic report released Thursday, Standard & Poor's Corp., a leading credit-rating concern, said it expected a lower rate of inflation to be the one spot of good news in 1991 because of the nation's economic weakness. ``In a recession, inflation rates come down along with everything else,'' Standard & Poor's chief economist David Blitzer said in its semiannual Consumer Price Forecast. ``We expect to see some of the smallest price increases since the mid-1980s.'' Nonetheless, Blitzer said, if war breaks out in the Middle East, oil prices could reach $40 or $50 a barrel, vs. the current level of the mid-to-high $20s. In other areas, the Standard & Poor's forecast predicted air fares would rise along with higher fuel costs; clothing and food prices would rise modestly; and liquor, tobacco and health-care costs would rise sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Hits Lull Amid Holiday Doldrums
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices showed little change Thursday in lifeless trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. ``We're a sea of tranquility out here,'' said Bob Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Home heating oil contracts showed the most strength as traders responded to a forecast that frigid Arctic weather might spread across much of the country. But neither forecasts of weather nor forecasts of war were enough to lift the market out of its pre-Christmas doldrums. Heating oil rose 1.04 cents to 78.88 cents a gallon on contracts for delivery in January. Heating oil for delivery in most later months showed modest losses. Crude oil, which has been frozen into a narrow range of prices lately, eased back with little fanfare, though many traders are starting to view war in the Persian Gulf as more likely than peace. Contracts for delivery of light sweet crude in February fell 54 cents to $26.39 per barrel as traders kept watching for news that might indicate whether the United States and Iraq would be able to agree on dates for discussing the Middle East crisis. Crude for delivery in later months was also lower. Unleaded gasoline dropped for all delivery months, with January contracts down .74 cent at 66.68 cents a gallon. Traders had looked early in the session for heating oil to rally. When it failed to move up very much, they started selling off at the end of the day, bringing down other prices. ``The market was being bid up by the heating oil, and when there was no follow-through, it just turned around and collapsed at the close,'' said Brian Tagler, an oil broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``With this holiday volume being so low, they can't seem to get any momentum.'' The day's volume was some of the lightest on the Mercantile Exchange since before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The market begins a four-day holiday weekend beginning Saturday, and many futures players have gotten out to avoid the risk that the oil crisis could unexpectedly change and hand them big losses. Natural gas prices, which have been in a long decline amid the warm weather that persisited through much of the fall, bounced back somewhat. Natural gas for February delivery was up 2.3 cents at $1.920 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Spending of Health Accelerates
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf to give rough estimate of per-capita spending; INSERTS 8th graf, The share, to point out that GNP share also a record; ADDS one graf to explain different per-capita estimates. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's spending on health care climbed to a record of more than $604 billion last year, federal officials said Thursday. The growth rate accelerated in 1989, just as it has done every year since 1986, and the amount spent added up to roughly $2,400 for every man, woman and child in the country. ``The ability of society to meet other needs is affected by the growing share of economic resources claimed by health expenditures,'' said Gail Wilensky, chief of the Health Care Financing Administration, in releasing the new data. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said the growth in health costs is alarming. It cuts some people off from medical care and puts a heavy financial burden on people who are using the system. Sullivan is leading a Domestic Policy Council review of the nation's health care system. He has said he will present his recommendations after he evaluates two reports that are due out next year. The secretary has rejected government-financed national health insurance as a solution, and said he favors continuation of a public-private system. Health spending in 1989 accounted for 11.6 percent of gross national product, the total of all goods and services prdocued, and was 11.1 percent higher than it was in 1988. The gross national product rose 6.7 percent over the same period. The share of GNP was also a record. As recently as 1985, the share was 10.5 percent. Federal spending on health programs in 1989 amounted to 14.7 percent of the total federal budget of about $1.1 trillion, up from 14.1 percent of the previous year's budget. Of the total spent on health care last year, 33 percent was paid by private insurance, 21 percent came from the pockets of consumers, 17 percent was paid by Medicare and 10 percent was paid by federal-state Medicaid programs. Other government programs put in 15 percent and other private sources, 4 percent, according to the financing administration's figures. The agency plans to publish a more detailed account of health spending next month. It gave this breakdown of where each dollar went: -39 cents to hospitals. -19 cents to physicians. -8 cents to nursing homes. -22 cents was spent on dental and other professional services, home health care, drugs and vision products -The remaining 12 cents paid for administration, research and construction. Nearly $50 billion was spent on nursing home care. Of that, 44 percent of that was by paid directly by patients, the great bulk of it (41 percent of the total) out of Social Security income. Medicaid and Medicare paid 51 percent of the bill, and private insurance paid 1 percent. Overall per-capita health spending would amount to $2,360, based on an estimated 1989 population given by the Health Care Financing Administration of 256 million people. However, the Census Bureau has estimated that 1989 population was 248 million, which would mean spending of $2,435 per person. The financing administration did not explain why it used a different population estimate.

DOC.HEAD: Production Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 155,416 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 221,489, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 256,702 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. General Motors Corp. had about half of its assembly plants shut down this week because of a shortage of dealer orders. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 90,695 cars this week, compared with 125,742 a week ago and 135,680 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 34,328, compared with last week's 60,795 and last year's 75,545. Canadian automakers were to build 14,368 cars this week, down from 15,784 a week ago and last year's 18,162. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 16,025, compared with 19,168 a week ago and 18,162 in the same week last year.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market vacillated through a mixed session Thursday in an atmosphere of caution over international worries and new questions about the interest-rate outlook. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 25 points in the early going, was up 2.73 at 2,629.46 by the close. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 726 up, 813 down and 507 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 174.70 million shares, against 180.83 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 215.74 million shares. Analysts said the news of Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation as Soviet foreign minister put many traders on their guard. The Bush administration indicated that it was awaiting more information before appraising the situation. Stock-market investors seemed to be in a similarly wary mood. In addition, brokers said doubts had spread in the past day or two over how much further the Federal Reserve might go in the near future toward easing credit conditions. After the Fed's announcement Tuesday of a cut in its discount rate, interest rates in the bond market turned upward Wednesday. In Thursday's activity, prices of long-term government bonds dropped more than $5 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the neighborhood of 8.24 percent. Among actively traded blue chips, International Business Machines rose 1 to 113}; General Electric gained ~ to 57}; American Express lost } to 21{, and American Telephone & Telegraph dropped ~ to 30]. Citicorp rose { to 13}, rebounding from a ~-point loss Wednesday that followed management's proposal to reduce the dividend. Manufacturers Hanover, which maintained its regular dividend for the current quarter, led the active list and climbed 1| to 24[. Urcarco fell } to 3~, posting one of the day's biggest percentage losses. The company, which operates used-car lots, attributed the drop to a downgrading of its stock by a brokerage-house analyst. Russ Togs lost ] to 4}. The company omitted its dividend, citing a ``volatile retail environment and a difficult fourth quarter.'' International Multifoods, which reported higher quarterly profits, gained { to 37\. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $0.76 billion, or 0.02 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dipped .03 to 180.32. Standard & Poor's industrial index edged up .01 to 386.00, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down .08 at 330.12. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.08 to 372.30. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 306.49, down .16.

DOC.HEAD: Rise $856.2 Million to New Record
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 532 money market mutual funds rose by $856.2 million in the latest week to an all-time high of $428.86 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise reported by the Washington-based mutual fund trade group broke the previous record set a week earlier, when fund assets rose $2.88 billion to $428 billion. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 267 general purpose funds fell $14.2 million to to $150.64 billion, assets of 103 broker-dealer funds dropped $19.1 million to $166.12 billion, and assets of 162 institutional funds rose $889.5 million to $112.10 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.17 percent from 7.22 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.23 percent from 7.28 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 52 days, down from 53 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 5.95 percent as of Wednesday from 5.96 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained unchanged from a week earlier at 5.05 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.32 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.41 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.41 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.51 percent; 7.54 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.62 percent; and 7.77 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 7.86 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Dixon in Fraud, Conspiracy Case
DOC.TEXT: A former Texas thrift owner, dubbed the ``highest of the high fliers among the savings and loan crooks'' by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, was convicted Thursday of taking hundreds of thousands of dollars from depositors and spending it on himself. An eight-woman, four-man jury said Don R. Dixon of Dallas was guilty of illegally spending money from his Vernon Savings Association on a California beach house and prostitutes. The jury cleared him of charges he made illegal campaign contributions. Dixon, 52, was the 11th person and eighth Vernon officer to be convicted of criminal wrongdoing that contributed to the thrift's 1987 failure, which cost taxpayers $1.3 billion and was one of the first costly collapses of the savings and loan crisis. ``I've felt better, but I have no comment,'' Dixon said as he left the courthouse. U.S. District Judge A. Joe Fish set Dixon's sentencing for Feb. 19. Convicted on 23 of 38 counts, Dixon faces a maximum sentence of 115 years in jail and a $5.75 million fine, said Marvin Collins, U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of Texas. Prosecutors will seek a lengthy sentence, he said. Dixon's attorney, Billy Ravkind, said he had not decided whether to appeal. ``Don Dixon was the highest of the high fliers among the savings and loan crooks,'' Thornburgh said in Washington. ``His excessive lifestyle and illegal management practices stood as a symbol of the wrongdoing in our national thrift industry.'' ``Clearly this is a major conviction, not just for our district but nationwide,'' Collins said. ``We have now convicted persons all the way from the bottom of the ladder to the top of the ladder at Vernon.'' Woody Lemons, who was Vernon's chief executive officer, was sentenced in April to 30 years in prison, the stiffest penalty yet handed any figure in the savings and loan crisis. Dixon, Lemons and other Vernon executives are also defendants in a $540 million federal fraud lawsuit that was filed in 1987. Dixon owned Vernon from 1981 to 1986. It grew 10-fold under his leadership with brokered deposits and speculative real estate deals and made a $50 million profit one year. When Dixon sold Vernon in 1986, more than 90 percent of its loans were not being repaid. Vernon's net worth had sunk to a negative $716.86 million when regulators took it over the next year. Testimony in the trial lasted more than five weeks with about two dozen witnesses, including Dixon. The jury deliberated for 10 days. ``I think the verdict showed the jury was being very careful and selective,'' Collins said. ``They were considering the evidence in all of the counts individually.'' ``We believe it sends a message to the S&L community in the state of Texas that their own citizens will hold them responsible,'' said Robert Hauberg, an assistant U.S. attorney who prosecuted Dixon. Jurors apparently disbelieved some former Vernon employees who testified Dixon directed them to reimburse themselves with the thrift's money for making political contributions. Dixon testified that he told the employees to check with attorneys before reimbursing themselves. Other former employees of Dixon's said he ordered the hiring of prostitutes for parties at a beach house near San Diego. They said Dixon crafted a scheme to divert loan advances to pay rent on the house and doctored records to hide Vernon's ownership of the house from thrift regulators. The house at Solana Beach, Calif., was a hotel and office for Vernon as it expanded into the southern California real estate market, Dixon testified. He said that in hindsight hiring women to attend the parties was inappropriate, but not illegal. Regulators found Vernon owned 17th century castle doors and expensive art objects, including a Baccarat eagle and a silver-studded saddle. The thrift also owned a yacht in Washington, used by some members of Congress for parties.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Higher
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Dec. 10, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,318.0 billion from $3,309.7 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,087.2 billion from $4,075.4 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $820.4 billion from $818.8 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 3.4 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.3 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,318.2 billion, a 2.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,088.9 billion, up 0.4 percent, while M1 rose 4.2 percent to an average of $821.5 billion. In other reports: -The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $919 million. -The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excuding extended credit, averaged $133 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $99 million the previous week. -The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $584 million in the two weeks ended Dec. 12, down from $816 million in the previous two-week period. -The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $318.2 billion in the two-week period ended Dec. 12, down from $319.9 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: OJ Futures Soar on Florida Frost Uncertainty
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices soared to a 2{-month high Thursday on the New York Cotton Exchange as the faint prospects for a weekend freeze in the Florida citrus belt ignited panic buying for the second time this week. On other commodity markets, silver futures rose sharply while gold retreated; crude oil futures fell; grains and soybeans retreated; and livestock and meat futures were mostly lower. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures settled 5 cents to 9.95 cents higher in New York with the contract for delivery in January up 9.95 cents at $1.20 a pound. It was the highest settlement of a near-term orange juice contract since Oct. 11, when the November contract finished at $1.299 a pound ahead of a government crop report that stunned traders with a forecast for a 45 percent jump in Florida orange production over last year. Orange juice futures have generally fallen since then, hitting a four-year low of 99 cents on Dec. 10. Prices surged Tuesday and again on Thursday amid fears that the deep freeze now gripping the central and western United States could extend into the central Florida citrus region. A significant Florida freeze this weekend appears unlikely, although the cold air mass ``still needs to be watched and watched closely,'' said Ken Clark, expert senior forecaster with Accu-Weather Inc., a private meteorological firm in State College, Penn. ``Our feeling right now is that we're not that impressed that it's going to get cold enough to cause problems in Florida,'' he said. Speculators dominated Thursday's buying, said Celeste Georkakis, orange juice analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. in New York. Many who had earlier bet on falling prices hurried to offset those positions by buying contracts, she said, thus reducing their exposure to a freeze during the four-day Christmas trading break that begins Saturday. Even if no freeze occurs this weekend, the market likely will remain volatile until mid-January, when the Florida orange harvest is over, Georkakis said. Silver futures rose sharply on New York's Commodity Exchange in a technically inspired continuation of Wednesday's powerful gains, which were sparked by the Federal Reserve Board's decision to cut its discount rate. Gold futures fell modestly, following the crude oil market, after rising sharply on Wednesday. Gold settled 80 cents to $2.20 lower with December at $385.20 a troy ounce; silver was 10.3 cents to 10.9 cents higher with December at $4.199 a troy ounce. Crude oil and gasoline futures retreated on the New York Mercantile Exchange in technically inspired selling and pre-weekend position-squaring. Near-term heating oil futures rose, reflecting forecasts for a cold weekend in the Northeast. Light sweet crude oil settled 20 cents to 69 cents lower with February at $26.39 a barrel; heating oil was .75 cent lower to 1.04 cents higher with January at 78.88 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent to .74 cent lower with January at 66.68 cents a gallon; natural gas futures ended 0.5 cent to 4.3 cents higher with February at $1.92 per 1,000 cubic feet. Grain and soybean futures prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade amid fears that Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation could lead to a halt in Soviet purchases of U.S. grain. After the close, the Agriculture Department announced sales of a total of 300,000 metric tons of U.S. corn to the Soviet Union, the third Soviet corn purchase since the United States last week extended Moscow up to $1 billion in export credit guarantees. Wheat futures were 1\ cents to 2{ cents lower with March at $2.60{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.34{ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 1} cents lower with March at $1.12 a bushel; soybeans were 2{ cents to 5{ cents lower with January at $5.70} a bushel. In livestock and meat trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle settled .15 cent lower to .08 cent higher with December at 80.35 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .10 cent lower with January at 88.65 cents a pound; hogs were .35 cent lower to .10 cent higher with February at 49.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .03 cent lower to .60 cent higher with February at 64.07 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn Group Seeks USX Shareholder List
DOC.TEXT: A committee formed by investor Carl Icahn demanded that USX Corp. supply a list of shareholders who could be canvassed about selling USX's energy operations, documents disclosed Thursday. A co-chairman of the committee wrote Pittsburgh-based USX on Wednesday demanding the list to communicate with other stockholders on issues such as separating USX's steel and energy businesses, dividend policy and corporate governance. The letter, written by John Pound, director of the Corporate Voting Research Project at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, was disclosed in a filing Icahn made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Last month, Icahn wrote USX Chairman Charles Corry saying he was forming the committee and would seek a shareholders' list to begin canvassing USX shareholders about its proposals. Those proposals include the possible sale of all or part of its energy operations and eliminating the shareholder rights plan, or ``poison pill'' defense against possible takeovers. The committee consists largely of law, government and business professors at Harvard and Stanford universities and the University of Chicago. Icahn's five-page letter to Corry said the committee members would seek election to the USX board at the 1991 annual meeting unless it ``adopts a meaningful restructuring plan and corporate governance changes.'' One member of the committee, Paul F. Quirk, resigned Tuesday to avoid the appearance of a conflict with his post as executive director of the Massachusetts Pension Reserves Investment Management Board. Icahn, a takeover strategist who runs Trans World Airlines, has been a thorn in the side of USX management for years. But he has been laying low since last May, when his proposal to spin off most of the USX steel business in the form of a shareholder dividend was rejected by other stockholders.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Block MCA Buyout
DOC.TEXT: A judge refused Thursday to delay a Japanese company's $6.6 billion buyout of entertainment giant MCA Inc., and an attorney for the Arizona company seeking to block the merger said he would appeal. Go-Video Inc., a Scottsdale-based distributor of a patented dual-deck VCR, filed an antitrust action Dec. 6, claiming the MCA buyout by Matsushita Electric Industrial Co. violates U.S. laws designed to encourage competition. Judge Robert Broomfield of U.S. District Court in Phoenix denied Go-Video's motion for a temporary restraining order, saying he was ``simply not persuaded that the proposed merger is anti-competitive.'' Broomfield also said Go-Video failed to prove its claim that it would suffer irreparable damage were the restraining order not issued. Joseph Alioto, Go-Video's San Francisco lawyer, said an appeal would be filed Friday in the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco. He said the court would be asked to stall the merger pending a final ruling. ``If we do not prevail there, we will file an appeal with the U.S. Supreme Court,'' Alioto said. ``And if we do not succeed in staying the merger, we will proceed with the case and seek divestiture. We will ask a judge to unscramble the egg that is about to be scrambled.'' Arguments during Thursday's hearing on the temporary restraining order centered on whether the merger would cause irreparable damage to Go-Video, and whether the company had to prove that it would suffer immediate losses. Alioto said he had to show only that there is a ``threat of significant damage.'' The antitrust law is designed to block noncompetitive mergers before the damage actually is done, he said. Dan Schulman, another Go-Video attorney, said the MCA buyout would hurt Go-Video and other electronics manufacturers by ``lessening competition.'' ``The market will be altered so that anyone who goes into that market will be at a disadvantage. Anyone in that market will be at a disadvantage,'' he said. ``It will be more difficult for Go-Video to compete. It will be more difficult for Go-Video to produce hardware for that market.'' Alioto said the MCA deal, coupled with Sony Corp.'s recent purchase of Columbia Pictures, is part of what he called a conspiracy by Japanese manufacturers to gain control of the yet-to-emerge high-definition television industry. By controlling both the manufacture of the hardware and the making of the movies, the Japanese would be able to dictate which format is adopted in the United States for high-definition television, and eventually to dominate that market, he argued. ``These guys are looking at the future, 20 years down the road,'' he said. But Matsushita's lawyers said Go-Video had failed to prove that a temporary restraining order was warranted. They argued that there has to be a showing of ``immediate, irreparable damage.'' ``Under the antitrust language, you have to show, you have to demonstrate that you are going to get hurt and that you are going to get hurt fast,'' said Ira M. Millstein, a New York lawyer for the defendants. Attorney Michael Biowitz, representing MCA, said he believed not only that Go-Video failed to make a case for a temporary restraining order, but that the antitrust case against the Matsushita-MCA merger was weak as well. ``These companies don't compete with each other in any market in the world,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court: Eastern Must Rehire Striking Pilots
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled Thursday that Eastern Airlines, before rehiring replacement pilots in training, must rehire pilots who went out on strike last year. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld a district court ruling that Eastern may not hire new pilots who, at the time the striking pilots agreed to return to work, had not completed training and become certified by the Federal Aviation Administration. The ruling would displace about 200 of Eastern's 1,900 pilots, who were in training when the Air Line Pilots' Association ended its strike in November 1989. Also under the ruling, no new trainees would be hired until all former strikers who wanted to return had been allowed to do so. The union said as many as 800 pilots are seeking to get their jobs back. Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak said the Miami-based company had not yet reviewed the ruling, but planned to appeal. ALPA went on strike on March 4, 1989, in a show of sympathy with striking Eastern machinists. Eastern then began hiring and training new pilots. In August 1989, many Eastern pilots offered to return to work, but Eastern said no pilot positions were available to former strikers. Eastern's response was the same when the remaining pilots ended the strike three months later. Eastern placed the former strikers on an inactive recall list for future positions and filed suit against ALPA, declaring that ``new hire pilots in training are permanent replacements who may not be deprived of active employments by strikers.'' ALPA argued that pilot trainees are not permanent replacements under the federal Railway Labor Act until they fully complete training and operate their required regular flights. The Atlanta-based appeals court agreed in Thursday's ruling, saying the newly hired pilots are not permanent employees because they ``were not qualified to perform the work Eastern's pilots ordinarily discharged.'' ``First, the former strikers, unlike the trainees, have actually flown regular revenue flights for Eastern,'' the three-judge panel wrote. ``Second, the returning pilots are only required to complete requalification training ... substantially less than the time required to train and qualify the new hire pilots.'' Joel Gay, office manager for the ALPA's Eastern local in Atlanta, said the union was pleased with the ruling. ``We had been anticipating it all along, so we're not surprised, we're just happy.'' Gay estimated the number of former strikers wanting to return to work at between 250 and 800. Ms. Ceremsak said Eastern was not sure how many ALPA members' jobs were at issue.

DOC.HEAD: CMS Expects Fourth-Quarter Loss After Provision for Power Plant
DOC.TEXT: CMS Energy Corp. said Thursday it was taking a $450 million accounting charge against earnings to reflect costs it might not recoup on an unfinished nuclear plant, resulting in a fourth-quarter loss. Paul Knopick, spokesman for the Dearborn-based corporation, said company officials wouldn't speculate whether CMS, parent company of Consumers Power Co., will report a loss for the year. CMS reported a third-quarter loss of $21.4 million, or 26 cents a share, and a profit of $145million, or $1.78 a share, for the first nine months of this year. The company made $74 million in the fourth quarter of 1989. The $450 million charge represents a move to unsnarl financial tangles from Consumers' aborted nuclear plant project at Midland, Hyman said. ``It's not a loss that has anything to do with generating electricity.'' CMS stock closed at $27 a share, up $1.75, Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange. CMS announced the $450 accounting charge after receiving an administrative law judge's recommendation Thursday on its request to recover $2.14 billion in Midland nuclear plant costs through rate increases. Administrative Law Judge Robert E. Hollenshead recommended that the Michigan Public Service Commission let Consumers impose $1.34 billion in rate increases over 10 years. If the commission adopts the recommendation, which matches one by its staff, the $450 million will go toward making up the difference between the amount requested and the amount granted, Knopick said. Consumers Power spent $4.1 billion on the Midland plant before construction was halted amid financing and legal problems in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: GM Begins Class H Common Stock Repurchase
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. on Thursday announced a special one-year effort to buy back some of its Class H common stock from company officials who received the shares as part of their compensation. GM spokesman Bill Winters said about 2.7 million shares of Class H common stock may be eligible for the program. About 88 million shares of Class H stock are outstanding, about 65 million of which are owned by Howard Hughes Medical Institute. As many as 4,800 GM managers worldwide are eligible to receive Class H stock as part of their compensation, Winters said. It was not possible to tell how many of the managers may still hold the stock, he said. GM's Class H stock is linked to its GM-Hughes Electronics Corp. subsidiary. Winters said the company wants to repurchase the shares to have on hand for future employee compensation. He said Class H stock was not traded actively and the buyback would give managers an easy way to redeem their shares. GM said it will repurchase the stock at market prices. Class H stock rose 25 cents Thursday to close at $18.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. GM began repurchasing Class H stock on the open market in 1987 with a goal of buying about 10 million shares. Since then, GM has repurchased about 4.6 million shares. The automaker said that program will continue.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Letter of Credit To Buy Merchandise
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge Thursday approved a bank letter of credit for Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. to borrow money to buy merchandise from foreign suppliers in 1991 and 1992. The judge, Vincent J. Aug Jr., also allowed Federated to pay the state of Indiana about $1 million in unpaid sales tax from late 1988 and early 1989. Federated lawyers told Aug they are trying to get Kentucky to pay back about $1 million in sales tax the retailer overpaid to that state. The letter of credit from IBJ Schroder Bank & Trust Co. of New York is good for $100 million and could be extended to $150 million. It is effective through Feb. 6, 1992, and will replace a Citibank letter of credit expiring Feb. 3. The Citibank credit was good for borrowings of as much as $150 million. The retailers have used $70 million of that amount so far, Federated spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. Federted and Allied attorney Cory Lipoff said the new letter of credit should reassure foreign vendors that the companies' retailing operations are healthy. Federated and Allied, both based in Cincinnati and owned by Campeau Corp. of Toronto, have been operating under bankruptcy court supervision since January. Lawyers for the retailers said Indiana and Kentucky inadvertently received each other's tax payments from Federated for sales at Lazarus department stores from November 1988 to January 1989. Federated said it didn't learn of the error until last June and has been trying to persuade Kentucky to return the overpayment. Federated said it owes Indiana $969,676, which includes sales tax plus interest. Federated wants a reimbursement of $1.13 million from Kentucky, which has refused the request. Federated is threatening to bring the dispute into federal bankruptcy court if it isn't resolved. Federated and Allied together employ about 110,000 people and operate 255 stores in 28 states.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of Boston Predicts Fourth Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Bank of Boston Corp. Thursday predicted a substantial loss for the fourth quarter but said its 10 cent-per-share dividend will not be cut. Ira Stepanian, chairman and chief executive officer, said the fourth-quarter loss would be substantial but said results were expected to be better than the third quarter. The nation's 15th largest banking company reported a third-quarter net loss of $255 million. ``The prolonged deterioration in the commercial real estate markets and the ongoing downturn in the regional economy continue to adversely affect our operating results,'' said Stepanian. ``However, we are unwavering in our commitment in this environment to deal aggressively with credit issues and to maintain what we believe to be strong loan loss reserves,'' he said. First Boston paid a 31 cent dividend in the second quarter. The dividend is payable Jan. 25, 1991, to stockholders of record on Dec. 31, 1990. In another cost-cutting measure, Stepanian said pay raises would be deferred for more than 5,000 bank employees. By early 1991, bank officials want to layoff 1,500 employees, 8 percent of the company's worldwide work force of 18,500.

DOC.HEAD: NCNB To Increase Loss Reserves
DOC.TEXT: NCNB Corp. announced Thursday that it will increase its allowances for loan and lease losses in the fourth quarter by up to $65 million. The company also expects net charge-off to increase to approximately $125 million to $135 million in the fourth quarter, compared to $79 million in the previous quarter. NCNB estimates its annual net income will be between $360 million and $370 million. Nonperforming assets for the bank holding company, which has about $66 billion in assets, are expected to rise to $970 million to $1 billion by Dec. 31. Included in that total are nonperforming loans of approximately $750 million, of which more than $350 million are paying interest.

DOC.HEAD: News Corp. Stock Tumbles
DOC.TEXT: News Corp. Ltd. chief executive Rupert Murdoch said Thursday he was pleased with progress on crucial debt-rescheduling proposals, but the international media group's stock value plunged. Murdoch issued a statement in reply to a query from the Australian Stock Exchange after News Corp.'s share price plunged almost 23 percent to its lowest level this year. The stock fell to 4.20 Austrialian dollars, or $3.23, and later recovered to finish off 1.09 Australian dollars, or 84 cents, at 4.35 Australian dollars, or $3.35. In New York Thursday, the stock fell 87{ cents to $7.50. Murdoch said he knew of no reason for the share slump, and insisted a majority of bankers and other lenders had already indicated they agreed to News Corp.'s terms for a refinancing of $6.88 billion in debt that comes due within the next three years. Analysts attributed much of Thursday's share price fall to concern about a highly critical TV documentary to be shown on Britain's Channel Four Thursday, which concentrates on News Corp.'s financial position and its low tax payments. ``The company is very peased with the progress of its negotiations for the rescheduling of the major part of the News group's debt,'' he said. Earlier this month, Australian Ratings downgraded News Corp.'s short- and long-term debt close to default levels. It described the group's financial position as ``extremely fragile'' and said its debts totaled $10.66 billion. The downgrade followed a similar move last month by U.S.-based Moody's Investors Service Inc. News Corp. executives have recently held meetings with bankers in Australia, the United States and Europe. Murdoch plans to reduce debt levels through unspecified assets sales.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Express Reports Second Quarter Earnings of $37.5 Million
DOC.TEXT: Federal Express Corp. on Thursday reported a slight earnings increase in the second fiscal quarter as the company tried to cut expenses to offset higher fuel prices. The air freight company's earnings totaled $37.47 million, or 71 cents per share, on revenues of $1.99 billion. In the same period in 1989, the company reported earnings of $37 million, or 70 cents per share, on revenues of $1.72 billion. The company paid 55 percent more per average gallon of fuel compared with last year and 62 percent more than the first fiscal quarter. Total fuel expenses increased $73 million from the same period a year ago and $77 million compared to this year's first quarter. ``Strict adherence to cost-cutting programs provided a partial offset to significantly higher fuel prices, continuing international losses, a weak economy and slower volume growth,'' said Frederick Smith, chief executive. Federal Express's total volume for the second quarter was nearly 83 million packages, up from about 77 million a year ago. Average revenue per package was $17.59, up from $16.52 for the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Air Lines Orders 26 New Jets, Boeing Announces Record Year for Orders
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Thursday announced it has set a one-year record for airplane orders, passing last year's mark. Boeing 1990 orders have reached $47.7 billion. The previous record was $46.62 billion, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group spokesman Craig Martin said. Boeing also announced Thursday that Delta Air Lines had placed an order for six 767-300 twinjets. Previously, Delta ordered 20 other planes, but the deal was not announced until Thursday. The 20 other planes were: three extended range 767-300s, one 767-300, nine 757-200s and seven 737-300s. The 26 planes represent $1.8 billion in revenue for Boeing.
